content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												I enjoyed it tremendously.  Absolutely a unique experience.Playing as a ghost was well implemented in my opinion.  They used what I found were convincing concepts in order to limit your navigation where needed, establishing clear rules from the outset.The mystery-solving was great.  It reminded me of L.A. Noire some (but I much preferred L.A. Noire I must say, as a game and specifically in its mystery-solving methods).  My one problem with it is that there really isn't a penalty for being a poor detective.  It's up to you to challenge yourself by not selecting all the answers until you get it right.  Of course, your 'ranking' is lowered for each incorrect guess but that's not a gameplay penalty as much as a pride penalty.The story was compelling and the voice-acting was brilliant for anyone with a name you learn in the game.  Unfortunately, most of the NPCs with names you don't know, are comically wooden and not remotely human.  I loved Joy, notable given I thought I'd hate an angsty teen written by someone that's not an angsty teen, moreover one that's meant to be comedic and have an attitude; the media don't seem to be good at that in general, so this was a nice change.Then there's the voice acting in the ghost stories.  That was phenomenal.  The stories were well written and well performed.  Absolutely a brilliant touch.I really felt connected to Julia, your wife in the game.  She's hardly in the game, but you can collect her memories, and they're written.  If you read them, you begin to develop a real sense of who she is.  I have to commend that sort of characterisation.The main character is believable.  Probably someone I'd laugh at in real life (even though I'd still like him; he's a good person and he certainly takes things in stride), but I can't say I haven't known people like him.  And the writing and acting make that believeable.Speaking of taking things in stride, that's one flaw in the writing; too many people take too many things in stride.  But that's negligible in the face of everything else.The combat system isn't much of a combat system, but I felt it worked well.  In fact, had they called your one move 'exorcise' or something instead of 'execute', you could have had a true example of a great game utterly devoid of combat, where overcoming your enemy isthe best thing you can do for them.  There's a nice stealth element alongside the one move you have.The dæmons are extremely creepy in design.  I love it.The music is great, but I wish that in a place where it becomes tense for enemies, that it would become less tense once the enemies are neutralised.  It doesn't.  A minor flaw I suppose.The game feels like an indie game and was developed by Airtight Games, who were apparently independent according to Wikipedia.  I say this because the graphics are rather poor compared to contemporary games, and like many indie developers, the engine used was the old UE3 engine, rather than what was most current.There's a lot of history in the game.  Old Salem bleeds into the modern Salem as the main character (and all ghosts I imagine) sees things.  You can collect snippets of history, which were probably all accurate, as the ones I was familiar with were all correct.Bonus:I'm a linguist, and I liked that a lot of the accents were notably correct.  The game takes placein Salem, which isn't too far from Boston.  I'm very familiar with the Boston accent as it's rather high-profile in dialects of English, and moreover as it has a significant Irish influence.  I'm not terribly familiar with Salem's accent but a lot of characters possess Boston traits so I assume they were trying to localise the accent at least as Massachusetts, which is really interesting to someone like me.  Also, a lot of Irish turns of phrase are used, which on looking them up are apparently common in that area of America, from Irish emigrants.  Nice.  Not only that, a lot of people have Irish names, which is rather realistic and once again interesting.Oh, but the old-time Puritan accents were cat.  Absolute rubbish they were.Speaking of cats, you can possess cats and meow and climb things and jump on things.  Another nice touch.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												You’ve been murdered, it’s a real bummer. But now you get the chance to find out who it was and seek justice from beyond the grave. Or you would if you played this.Enter Ronan a bad guy turned good trying to stop a murderer on a killing spree but wouldn’t you know it you wind up just another one of their victims. But with unfinished business to attend to you hang around for a while and haunt the halls of Salem city searching for clues that could lead you to solving your own murder and ascending to heaven. Or at least that’s the plan but as the recently departed not many people will talk to you. Enter the one witness to your death Joy who also happens to be psychic, after a lot of convincing the duo team up and take down the evil together. The story is certainly an intriguing and unique one. I have not seen a murder mystery from a dead person’s perspective before and with the amounts of twists and turns that come flying at you as you progress it will get you enthralled right to the end.The game is stacked full of collectables, over a hundred of them to be precise, each with its own story. They all fit seamlessly into the town of Salem with its terrible past and not too stellar present. The world is more or less open world with you being able to travel from one location to another through the hub of the down town area. Each part of the world is beautifully designed and looks great mixing an old ghostly past with the present to make something new.The game also features a huge amount of side quests and cases to solve. Speaking of which the detective mode is also something of an oddity, find a crime and solve it with clues found in the environment and placed together like pieces of a puzzle, I found a lot of pleasure recreating crimes to try and figure out what had happened and who the culprit was.Now onto the main meat of the game combat…. There is none. Well that’s not true, there are a few enemies and by few I mean around 12 in the whole game and the only thing that happens is when they see you a QTE begins, win and you can proceed, lose and you have to start a short ways back. I would classify this more as an interactive novel than a game. Not that it’s a bad thing, but just be sure that’s what you are looking for before you delve in.This game offers a lot and is a great distraction if you are looking for a unique experience that’s heavy on the narrative but light in most other places. At full price I can’t really recommend it but on sale you should pick this up and just enjoy your time in purgatory.Have Fun ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Surprisingly enjoyable. A not so long adventure game with an original idea but plagued by an average execution.The positiveMurdered takes the interesting concept of playing a dead man stuck between two worlds and having to solve his murder to be able to get to heaven. I really love this idea, you're investigating in two embedded worlds : the living and the dead. You can clip through most environment from the world of the living but get stuck against the environment of the dead. The setting is very well made with ghosts appearing and disappearing as well as people in an alike situation as yours : unable to let go and go to heaven. There are 4 side quests where you're helping someone to understand his/her death.I personally loved the aesthetic of the game, a mix of color and black and white. The game also is very well optimised and runs flawlessly on my laptop (i7 4500U, Nvidia GT750m) @ 900p/1080p. The story is enjoyable for the most part and the collaboration and interactions between Joy and Ronan are well-executed. Finally, the game has a lot of collectibles (242 to be precise), this can be either a positive or a negative point depending on the player.The negativeThe gameplay is below average even for an adventure game. Every step of the story involves you looking for clues in a small area, when you have enough clues you are able to link a few of them to each other to solve one question.... and that's it, for the whole game. The clues are either stupidly obvious or stupidly useless and the solving questions are terrible. The combat system sucks terribly too, it's simply about sneaking behind enemies and doing a simple QTE. Murdered won't be remembered for its gameplay.The story is very unbalanced. The first hour is basically setting the story and characters, the pace is slow and isn't very compelling. When you start seeing a bit through how the investigation is going to take place, it becomes enjoyable and that until the end of the game where you are faced to a completely stupid and abrupt ending. The ending feels rushed and I hated it because of this, the last chapter is like 5 minutes long... The rest of the game isn't very long either, count between 6 to 8 hours depending on whether you want to find all the collectibles or not.ConclusionIt might seem that the game is terrible but I personally enjoyed it anyway despite all of its flaws. The aesthetic and most of the story felt original. Many good ideas, poor execution but still worth it in my opinion. I wouldn't recommend it at full price though, buy it on sale.

												You’ve been murdered, it’s a real bummer. But now you get the chance to find out who it was and seek justice from beyond the grave. Or you would if you played this.Enter Ronan a bad guy turned good trying to stop a murderer on a killing spree but wouldn’t you know it you wind up just another one of their victims. But with unfinished business to attend to you hang around for a while and haunt the halls of Salem city searching for clues that could lead you to solving your own murder and ascending to heaven. Or at least that’s the plan but as the recently departed not many people will talk to you. Enter the one witness to your death Joy who also happens to be psychic, after a lot of convincing the duo team up and take down the evil together. The story is certainly an intriguing and unique one. I have not seen a murder mystery from a dead person’s perspective before and with the amounts of twists and turns that come flying at you as you progress it will get you enthralled right to the end.The game is stacked full of collectables, over a hundred of them to be precise, each with its own story. They all fit seamlessly into the town of Salem with its terrible past and not too stellar present. The world is more or less open world with you being able to travel from one location to another through the hub of the down town area. Each part of the world is beautifully designed and looks great mixing an old ghostly past with the present to make something new.The game also features a huge amount of side quests and cases to solve. Speaking of which the detective mode is also something of an oddity, find a crime and solve it with clues found in the environment and placed together like pieces of a puzzle, I found a lot of pleasure recreating crimes to try and figure out what had happened and who the culprit was.Now onto the main meat of the game combat…. There is none. Well that’s not true, there are a few enemies and by few I mean around 12 in the whole game and the only thing that happens is when they see you a QTE begins, win and you can proceed, lose and you have to start a short ways back. I would classify this more as an interactive novel than a game. Not that it’s a bad thing, but just be sure that’s what you are looking for before you delve in.This game offers a lot and is a great distraction if you are looking for a unique experience that’s heavy on the narrative but light in most other places. At full price I can’t really recommend it but on sale you should pick this up and just enjoy your time in purgatory.Have Fun ^_^

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Great game on sale, got it dirt cheap not expecting too much but it ended up surprising me.  Would not buy it for full price though.  The only thing that sucks about the game are the demon encounters, they just feel out of place and unnecessary.  The game has a good enough story and investigation/exploration sections that it doesn't need the demon sections at all.  It's a real shame because the idea had potential too.  I was hoping for something in the vein of demons being disguised as regular ghosts trying to trick you into making bad decisions via dialogue options to steal your soul but instead they're patrolling enemies that you have to avoid and stealth kill.  The most annoying thing is when they detect you for no reason whatsoever or when you are in exactly the correct position to execute them and get no prompt to do so.  These sections are a pretty small portion of the game though and there's only a handful of them.  Anyone whose played any stealth oriented games will have no problems with them outside of the issues mentioned above.  Overall, it was a great story with a couple twists on the end that I just didn't see coming.  The game is worth a playthrough if you're looking for something different that's story driven and not action packed.  Voice acting was great too, Ronan and Joy are both likable characters with tons of personality.  Will probably play this again at some point to get all the collectables and do the side missions that I missed.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												I've played a lot of games, and I've died in a lot of games, sometimes quickly, but this is the first game where I died during the opening cutscene.  Kinda refreshing to just get that out of the way right off the bat.In Murdered:  Soul Suspect, you play a ghost.  You can walk through walls, affect things like lights and TVs, and blow papers on the floor.  You can possess people, but you can't really make them do very much.  Mostly, you just access their memories or influence them a little.This is a murder mystery, and you're trying to solve not only your own murder, but a series of murders you were investigating before you died.Along the way, you'll meet other ghosts, and some of them will help you, some will haunt you, and some will need your help.  Many of the ghosts have stories that they want to tell, and in a few cases, you will solve other murders.This is a beautiful and emotional game with a LOT of depth to it.  It was creative.  It was original.  It was intelligent.  Not flawless.  Not perfect.  But beautiful, and I don't mean graphics.  I mean this is a game where someone put some real love into developing it into something unique.There were only two things I didn't like about this game:1.  The name.  I think they should have just called it "Murdered".  More mysterious and dark that way.2.  The demons.  There are these demons that float around, and if they see you they will attack, and then it's game over.  I went into the config file and blinded them all.  I felt they went against the tone and feel of the game.  It's spooky having them their, but this, in my opinion, is not a game that needed action or combat.  So I essentially turned them off, and they became just more creepy atmosphere.Overall, I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is actually a really good game. Okay, maybe that's an overstatement, but I really enjoyed it's approach to detective work and solving the mystery of your own murder as well as the recent string of murders in Salem in a single night.You play Ronan O'Connor, a former petty criminal/turned detective who is hot on the trail of the Bell Killer, only the opening cutscene is your own death. The game picks up right from there as you search for clues and get used to being a ghost. The devs handled the ghost mechanics rather well as far as being unable to walk into buildings from the outside unless there's an open doorway or window. But you can move through walls, bushes, benches, etc.The story is really intriguing and it seemed like it was going to be predictable, but I was wrong. I didn't know who the killer was from the get go. So, I tip my hat to the devs for pulling a decent M Night Shamalamadingdong. Sound design is eerie, as it should be. Unnamed NPC's that walk around Salem that you can possess, well, a lot of them looked the same and had the same responses when reading their minds, that bugged me. And for being an open world town, it seemed more restricted than anything because of the ghost walls that you can't pass through. It just made the town section of the game seem a lot more linear, but like a maze.The graphics were decent enough, but it's clear that the game was held back due to last gen consoles. I mean, some of the modeling and textures look like games from 2010.The mystery work was a lot of fun though, searching for clues and whatnot. Good game.7.5/10

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect was a game I've been heavily anticipating ever since I saw it in action. I expected something along the lines of Ghost Trick mixed with L.A. Noire. What I got instead was essentially a much better Beyond Two Souls and that in of itself isn't a bad thing.Taking place in Salem, Massachusetts, you play as the deceased Detective Ronan O'Connor. Murdered by a mysterious serial-killer, he finds out that the only way to pass on to the afterlife and reunite with his dead wife is to figure out the murders identity identity so he may leave this mortal plane. It's a decent Whodunit story with a lot of interesting side-stories unlocked through collectibles.My biggest problem with this game is the gameplay or lack thereof. For what it's worth, I did enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect when you realize the game isn't trying to be Ghost Trick or LA Noire, but this is something you'll notice more and more as you'll go along. I actually think it starts out pretty well. You walk through walls, talk to fellow ghosts, discover their stories through detective work. It all seemed fine until you find out that's that where it stops. It never gets any harder, better more complex, better. The game doesn't offer much depth and at worse, becomes less interesting for the player. All you do is press X to evidence. There are no fail states in the investigation sections. There are no incentives to actually think logically and not randomly guess at what the game throws at you besides meaningless tokens and even then the game is incredibly easy. "Oh, I wonder what memory will remind this witness of the killer. Hmm... could it perhaps be this thought bubble right here called THE KILLER?" I admit, sometimes possessing a human and hearing his thoughts can be kinda cool, but it really doesn't enough with the concept. You never manipulate their actions unless it's for something incredibly mundane, never use them to walk around, there are no puzzles to solve, it just feels like a missed opportunity.Besides there's not really much to talk about. You can occasionally posses cats to find a new path to your objectives, you can try to find these loads of collectibles or.... fight random demons? Yeah, even though it's not relevant to the plot at all, you have to sneak past these dementor-like creatures or take these things down from behind stealthily, the latter being the most common. This isn't even a rare occurrence, this happened more then I could count. It's not all bad and sneaking past them does sometimes work, but why is this even here? This has no point other then to waste my time! The combat in this game couldn't be more tacked on even if you tried. I also thought using quicktime events to defeat them was incredibly annoying, because the buttons you need to press are randomized every time, but at the very least, you're given a surprisingly large amount of of time to get the right ones down so if there's one thing to praise them for it's that.It's with this that I realized that the game isn't trying to deep in terms of gameplay and that it's going for a specific audience who don't really want to put much thought into their gaming. With that said, I still had a good time with Murdered: Soul suspect. Like I said before, the story is good and that's really what they wanted to tell here. The lightning effects and shading are some of the best I've ever seen in a computer game however this comes with the unfortunate side effect of your game for thirty seconds just to load the next area. This isn't exclusive to the PC version, even the next-gen versions suffer from frame rate drops, stutters and others but technical hiccups aside, I'd say the game is still worth a purchase, but not for full price obviously. If you're still not convinced: all I'm saying is that I'll take a Murdered: Soul Suspect which simplifies a lot of aspects about its genre then the latest 6 Final Fantasy games or so.

												So MURDERED: Soul Suspect was such an amazing game that I decided to write a little review... At first the story is so good because you get everything told in the first few minutes. Something like a simple and small film after 15 minutes seeking would be better. BUT it's a great, game and it was very cool to play. A BIG I LIKE :))

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												If your dream has always been playing an undead fedora-wearing douchbag neckbeard solving criminal cases like some try-hard Maltese Falcon reject who can't come to terms with the fact that he neither lives in the 1940s, nor understands the actual era (dress code included) - this might just be the game for you. Douchehat McNeckbeard might be laughably slow in how he connects clues, but he comes with a full package of mangst in the form of a fridged (of course) Manic Pixie Dreamgirl wife, and the attitude you'd expect from a 40-year-old basement dweller. If that is what you enjoy in a game, this will be a dream for you - albeit an admittedly short one, since the game is as the most 10 hours, and that's when you take your time as I did.On a more serious note, this game did have potential, and I really wanted to like it. Tuning out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ protagonist and his ridiculous and frankly embarrassing fashion sense (which is explained away in the most ridiculous 'didn't even try' manner possible in the game), parts of the gameplay, particularly in the beginning, were fun. Sadly the really fun parts are tragically underused, and for the course of the game following the opening mission, you experience practically nothing new. The first bigger investigation was fun especially through learning all the things you could do to get clues - connect existing clues in your head for new revelations, possess people and prompt them to reveal what they knew by triggering the right clues in their heads, seeing through their eyes into computer files, etc - but there it ended. You acquire a few more fine-tuned skills later on (teleporting, most notably), but nothing that really stands out. The fun experimental trying and testing which witness might have seen what and respond to which clues turns into a tedious button-smashing 'where's the one tiny object in the room that I keep missing?' adventure. Gameplay stagnates and turns into the same thing over and over and over again, only for Mr Fedora to finally come to a conclusion that quite frankly you could have told him after or even before entering the building.The worst part by far is the writing. Not only are the main characters (most notably the supposed 'tough cops' who only come across as petty, ♥♥♥♥♥y, and whiny) utterly unlikeable, but the main story itself lacks any originality. For the sake of avoiding spoilers if you are for whatever reason still interested in playing, I won't go into the details further, but whatever 'twists' were apparently thought up by the writers have been done before and repeated to death, were foreseeable to the point I don't even want to call it foreshadowing anymore, and - due to the absolutely flat character writing - lacked any sort of emotional impact. I never thought a game centring around a murder investigation done by a GHOST in ♥♥♥♥ing SALEM could be boring, but this is. It's plain and simply boring, with slightly awkward, incredibly repetitice gameplay, and with the added disadvantage of the most obnoxious, annoying, self-centred, whiny wannabe-tough guy fedora-wearing neckbeard Gary Stu of a protagonist I have ever seen. It's like a bad '40s film noir rip off (BUT IN SALEM, WOOO SUPERNATURAL THINGS) gone completely wrong. And not even spectacularly wrong, just underwhelming, tedious, and most of all - disappointing.There are worse games, of course, but this game stands out mainly because it doesn't - it's all been done before, been done better, and there is literally nothing that this game has to offer. It's not the worst, not a spectacular train wreck, but it's poor, and it's sad. Good for a few minutes of fun, and if you really have to kill time and have absolutely nothing else to do.Overall, 2/5, and that's me being nice, because I enjoyed parts of the early gameplay. Suggested time to buy: at 90% off.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an interesting game. The gameplay mechanics are quite unique but the premise is fairly typical of a story with paranormal themes; a ghost partners up with the living to solve a series of murders. It's not mind-blowing but the way its handled in Murdered works quite well, mainly due to the decent voice acting, the supernatural abilities, and the clever art style that blends reality with a ghostly dimension.The majority of the game is quite fluid and offers little challenge (in a good way) but I have to say that the action sequences feel forced and really bring down the quality of this game. They break the flow of the story and the combat itself is often imprecise and sloppy for what are essentially quick time events. I figure that what happened to Murdered is the same as with Deadly Premonition in which this is something that the publisher demanded of the developers, who reluctantly and haphazardly complied by shoehorning in some janky action sequences in the final hours of development.If you're aiming for 100% completion I suggest collecting everything BEFORE entering the abandoned and decrepit house near the end of the game, as the final sequence will prevent you from collecting any more items within its level and there is no free-roaming afterward. I found this out the hard way, fortunately you can start a new game, collect what you've missed, and the relevant achievements will still unlock even if the collectibles counter has reset to zero.

But the thing that got me the most is the new environment, mechanics, and overall theme of the game, I wish they make a DLC or sequel eh, I recommend you to buy this.An intriguing game where it makes you think about what happens to a person after death. Very story rich like square enix's mangas and animes kek.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Good procedural detection sim. The gun in the detective's hand is not part of the game, fyi. This is about exploration and storytelling, not shooting things. Walking through walls is fun... when they let you.The story is alright. Nothing too moving. The metaphysics are wonky - while they give the Catholic Church a good character in the priest, they clearly didn't worry about keeping the theology of life after death in the traditional understanding. Took me out of the game a bit as your character tells lost souls to forgive themselves and they whoosh off in a bright light lol. Also, I wish the detective was more likable instead of some fedora-wearing clown. The graphics are ok, basically what is expected nowadays. However, some of the character models are pretty bad and voices randomly match up to models to hilarious results. I didn't encounter any gameplay issues. All around a competently made game. I had fun completing it, but would not buy except on sale at least half off.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												An excellent game! It's short like people have said, but it was satisfying nonetheless! The game is priced correctly for such a short game (~8 hours), at 10 dollars off a normal priced one. It's not something you'll be playing for weeks and I am actually refreshed by that. It's totally story driven and doesn't pretend to be something it's not. The creepy atmosphere always had me wondering what was around the corner (or what was through the next wall!). I tried my best to guess who the killer was and by all accounts I failed at that. If you want to take a break from that FPS and sit down with a good story-driven game, pick this one up! Totally happy with every aspect!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I bought the limited edition at € 35 (has a nice little book in it). It's a decent price for a decent game, I wouldn't have paid more for this.The game reminds me of LA noire sometimes, because of the way you find leads during a crime scene. What i reaaaaally liked about this game were the perks you get by being a ghost :D .The story itself is good, I didn't expect the ending, although some ppl might, but i didn't :) I did find little "mistakes" in the game that i find odd, but it didn't ruin the game for me: sometimes if i run too fast i get stuck in a dumpster for example and half of the people in Salem are exactly the same person.. :s I saw some criticism about the game due to the looks of the main character and the way a ghost works, but i find these comments just annoying. I think the guy looks cool and has a good personality in the game + nobody really knows how ghosts work because they are not real! I ignored these comments and had a good time playing the game :) Overall a good game but glad i didn't have to pay €50 for it.

content:
Posted: April 9
Dull. Disjointed. A collectible-based game with permanently missable collectibles.The investigation mechanic should be great, but its implementation is usually just okay. Other times, the game is weirdly picky about which facts contribute toward a conclusion, and on more than one occasion the expected answer to "what do I know about [thing]?" is just "[thing]." In grainy, prerendered cutscenes, the main character will react with astonishment at details he's already stared at and committed to memory. The investigation into his murderer starts at square one, despite the opening scene showing he knew enough to track down and confront the killer. At no point does this police detective seem to understand how, why, or even that he did.Since the game has only about eight level maps, the transition between well-developed, fully funded zones and "we're out of money, just make a maze with some combat arenas" is stark. One level (toward the middle, surprisingly enough) is unique in having items that can be examined and generate a little popup description like clues do, but aren't clues and contribute toward nothing. The stealth combat is slow and frustrating; the only way to win is to walk up behind enemies one by one, hiding as necessary if spotted. And you will get spotted, because your movement speed is low, the enemies can turn around instantly at the end of their patrols, and the kill move requires you to hold a button and complete a simple QTE, leading to a surprising number of failures (though maybe that has something to do with using mouse & keyboard to play what is a painfully obvious console port). If you're killed, you get to attempt to sneak-walk behind the whole group again, one at a time. Fortunately, the enemies come in small groups, but even a small group is too large when each kill is so laborious, and the stealth options so minimal.ALSO: You can't use the mouse to confirm in menus, but you can (must) use Q, E, 1, and 3 to navigate them. The villain's identity, motives, and MO don't make sense when taken together, but the main character has no trouble reaching the right conclusion after you point out [thing] three times. Extras are the same six character models repeated over and over. There is one (1) enemy type. You can walk through walls, but not ghost walls, which apparently have unfinished business. I don't know if it's even possible to fail the escort puzzles; the hardest part was remembering to talk to the character being escorted after every step. You defeat the villain using abilities that are unexplained and have been established exactly once prior to the final showdown. I don't like this game. Ghosts are a bummer.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Absolutely no spoilers in this review.*Edited review now that I have finished the game. It took me about 7.5 hours(played it offline and steam doesn't track offline play) to complete this game and that is including time spent searching for collectibles and finding probably about 85-90% of them. So the complaints that the game is short are pretty valid. Had I skipped the collectibles I probably would have completed it in around 6 hours. That said, I loved every second of this game. The game probably doesn't have a lot of replay value either unless you want to go back through to finish the collectible stories or help any ghosts you passed up on your original playthough (there are only 3-4 of them though I think unfortunately.)So I played this game until 3 am and could barely drag myself away from the keyboard to go to sleep. I am absolutely enthralled by this game and I love it. If the rest of the game is as good as the first 4 hours I've played of it then it will easily be contender for my GOTY.The voice acting is awesome. A lot of the random civilians share the same voice actors but thats a minor thing. I recognize most of the random civilian voice actors from other big budget games. They are all great voice actors. So it seems the devs went with quality over quantity.The visuals are great. I feel like most unreal engine games have models that look like they are made of clay, but this game does not. The ghostly effects are really cool. The way the demons move is absolutely terrifying. Animations are great all around with the possible exception of some lip syncing here and there on the minor characters.The gameplay is fantastic.♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the demons and being forced to run and hide until they lose your scent is pretty terrifying. Finding collectibles is awesome because once you find all of a set you unlock an audio short story with a piece of art and the stories are really REALLY good so far. Your ghost powers are pretty freaking awesome and the game rewards exploration with collectibles littered all over the levels. Helping other ghosts solve questions regarding their deaths and helping them move on is a great feeling. These little side mission stories are very well written and acted. Finding clues is somewhat similar to but much more enjoyable than it was in LA Noire. Once you find all the clues you do a little solving... puzzle I guess. You get three attempts to solve the puzzle. I don't know what happens if you fail all three attempts yet. But they are generally pretty self explanatory for the most part. It asks a question on the screen and you answer it by selecting the proper clue(s), sometimes in a certain order too. The game actually makes me feel like a ghostly detective. And the story itself is amazing so far. The 63/100 metascore completely baffles me because this game is great and easily one of the best gaming experiences of the year so far.I loved the ending. It wraps everything up in a smart way. I immensely enjoyed this game. If you have any interest in ghost stories or detective mysteries then you will love this game.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Not a perfect game by any means, but well worth a sale pickup for the story, atmosphere and visuals.This wasn't a game at the top of my wishlist, but I have been eyeing it since it came out, and when I found it on sale at the HB store for $15 I jumped at the opportunity.  I wasn't disappointed - personally I really enjoyed the game.  The story is engaging, the acting is very good, the visuals and mood of the game are great.  I think a lot of people hating on it are either bandwagon-jumpers who haven't played it, or were just expecting a different kind of game.  A lot of complaints seem to revolve around a lack of action - you just sort of walk around and click where it tells you to.  And in reality there's not too much more to the gameplay, so if you want more then you probably won't like it.  I went in treating it as more of an interactive story - a glossed-up point-and-click adventure, if you will, and I wasn't let down.  The game does have legitimate problems, but for me none of them were deal-breakers, and were outweighed by the pros:Cons:- suffered from performance issues and fairly frequent frame rate drops, which got worse as the game went on- no ability to remap keys- the mouse didn't work for all the menu items- no chance to go back and finish collecting items once you've entered the final level, meaning you'd have to play through the game again in order to try and get everything.  As much as I like the game, I'm not interested in playing it all again just to finish up a few achievements- the demons were really more of an annoyance than anything - they should have played more of a roll or just been pulled altogether- a lot of the investigations were far too simple to solve, while a small few were unreasonably obscurePros:- Great voice acting- Great camera work- Great atmosphere- Great story- NOT too short - I put 12-13 hours into the game by taking my time, doing the side missions, collecting artifacts, and generally immersing myself into the really good story.  I'd rather play a really enjoyable 8-12 hour game than spend 2 or 3 times that on something I end up barely able to finish because I've gotten so sick of it (L.A. Noire springs to mind).  Besides, at 12 hours I spent barely over a buck per hour on it - that's pretty good value in my book.So overall it's probably not worth full price, but easily worth $15-$25, as long as you enjoy story-driven adventure games.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Spoiler Alert: The main character dies. The good news is that it happens right at the start of the game. Then the game gets going. However, unlike some God of War clone this isn't a revenge fueled bloodbath of carnage and destruction. There isn't an ocean of "enjoy to destroy" cannon fodder to kill/loot on the way to the final boss. This is a supernatural redemption story in the vein of Ghost or Always with a dash of The Frighteners thrown in for a bit of fun.The bulk of the game will be exploring mutliple crime scenes as you piece together not only the reason for your own murder, but the deaths of many fellow spirits that you encounter along your main quest. In some regards I am reminded of the forensic analyst role from Heavy Rain. Once you have gathered enough clues in the crime scenes you can attempt to discern the next location that your journey takes you. The good news is that, unlike Heavy Rain, this game does not rely on timing based quicktime events to tell the story.However, the only real combat in the game does rely on a tried and true quicktime mechanic. This involves sneaking up behind the occasional demon and performing a stealth kill sequence to banish it. This involves a random quicktime sequence where you a flashed a direction to press along with an appropriate button/key. Not that deep.TL;DR version: If you are a casual gamer that isn't looking to mindlessly button mash your way through a plotless demon horde this is a nice change of pace. If you want some thing procedural like the Kings Quest, Monkey Island or Quantic Dream created games (Indigo Prophecy, Heavy Rain, Beyond) then you'll enjoy the storytelling. It would really fit in nicely with that friend that owns all the Telltale Games titles. Just don't expect a lot of white knuckle fragging.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I really wanted to like Murdered: Soul Suspect.  The pun in the name alone gives it a couple of points straight off and I found the story enjoyable, with a well constructed supernatural mystery.  While the plot doesn’t break any new ground, it does make good use of its setting and archetypical characters.  But the game side of things really holds the experience back.  The puzzles are rather boring and quite easy, with most of the challenge being little more than a pixel hunt.  But what really ruined the experience for me were the tedious stealth sections that become longer and more frequent as the game goes on, without any variation to how they play out; they really interrupted an otherwise enjoyable story.Honestly, I wish this was a TV show or movie as it unfortunately doesn’t make for a terribly good video game.

												Although I do like this game, I would not recommend anyone to pay full price for it. I purchased it from Humble Bundle when it was part of a $1 bundle and that's honestly about how much it is worth.The gameplay is okay. While the storyline is interesting, general mechanics of moving your character around can be quite a pain. You only play in third person and the camera moves way too fast; apparently mouse sensitivity only seems to affect cursor movements on selecting clues. The demons, though 2spoopy5me at times, seem like an unnecessary add-in to the game. Also, your LMB/RMB and any keyboard function will randomly stop working. The game also only auto saves, so if you end up having any issues like that, go ahead and prepare yourself for any progress you may lose when you have to restart the game.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Murdered Soul Suspect 

			Views: 109		

			Murdered Soul Suspect proclaims to be an deactivate game while being a ghost with a rich story. Available on Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/233290/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if...		

	Murdered: Soul Suspect is a console port detective game with a horroratmosphere that plays more like an interactive movie than a game.  Right off the bat, I was unimpressed by the whopping 30 frames per second that this game runs at, followed shortly by the delayed lineup of subtitles to speech.  	The story was cheesy and doesn't fit with the objective of the game;  starting out by stating that your ultimate goal is to reunite with a lost love,but then not mentioning that relationship for the bulk of the game.  As for the gamebeing a detective game, I would disagree with that and state that it is morelike a hidden object game that requires you search out 'clues' in a predeterminedlocation.  There is no deduction needed; all the clues are in one place, and the game holds your hand by leading you to the next clue and askingrediculously obvious questions.  	The ghosts, while contributing to the atmosphere, did absolutely nothingto add to the game.  For the most part, they were all from the same time period,and were supposed to add a spooky element, but as you are also playing as a ghost, and they disappear when you get close, they were more of a waste of timethan anything else.	I enjoy watching movies, but I buy games in order to, oh I don't know, play a game!  This game played like a cinematic movie, with about 20-25%of the game actual gameplay, and the rest being cinematic movies or dialogue.  Being made to move all across the mapp to get to the next action point does notcount as gameplay;  it is wasting time.	If you are interested in the story of this game, I would recommend goingto YouTube and watching the cinematics strung together rather than buy this game.It treats you, the player, as if you are an idiot that can't figure out anythingfor yourself.  Graphically the game gets by, as well as the level design.  The story is acceptable, but what little gameplay there is designed for thosethat can't deduce anything for themselves.  As a game, I cannot recommend this, if it can even be called a game.For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basic summary of what I cover in my video. Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story-driven third-person investigative adventure game with some stealth elements. You take the role of Ronan O'Connor, a former bad boy turned good guy. Everything begins seconds after you've just been thrown from a fourth story window by the game's primary antagonist. The fall almost kills you and the subsequent bullets to the chest finish the job, meaning you play through the entire game as a ghost. Murdered: Soul Suspect plays out like a puzzle game along the lines of L.A. Noire. As a detective Ronan must uncover clues and evidence to track down the Bell Killer. As a ghost in limbo, Ronan has a number of abilities at his disposal. Although he cannot walk through external doors unless they are opened by someone else, once inside a building Ronan can walk through walls and other obstacles. He can fall great distances and not get hurt and he is able to possess people to read their thoughts, influence their actions and peek at their notes or at their computer screens. He can even possess other creatures such as cats to get to hard to reach areas. In addition to the primary plotline being very interesting, the game generally has a very well-designed backdrop, numerous side quests, and superfluous opportunities to discover more about the characters and places featured in the game.Another part of Murdered that works pretty well is the look of the game. When Ronan walks through the streets of Salem, he sees a mixture of how it is now interspersed with what it looked like during the witch trials of the 17th century. The modern Salem is in full color, but the old Salem is in blue and white, and the contrast is striking. The character models and cut scenes are also rendered well. Really, the production values for Murdered are about as good as you’re going to see in a game. The audio multiplies the eerie feeling as well, with some haunting background music. The music, combined with the sound effects works marvellously.I really liked the look, the atmosphere, and the story behind Murdered: Soul Suspect.Although at times the pace of the game can seem a little slow, I have found that Murdered: Soul Suspect to be an enjoyable detective experience – even if it is somewhat simplified detective work.If you’re a fan of mysteries, Murdered: Soul Suspect would be a worthy purchase. Overall 8/10.

Posted: October 6, 2014
												Right....first things first, this isnt a title you should get for full price but at least it was only half of that when it came out so I can respct that....but still think its not worth the price unless its on sale. This game has alot of mixed reviews but none great ones, this is because it falls very short on some expectations gameplay-wise because its freaking boring and empty. What isnt boring and empty is the story....I could go so far as to compare this as a story driven game. It can be very much enjoyble if you are not bothered by the "run everywhere and pick everything up" <basicly all the gameplay in a nutshell for this game. Of course there are some "detective" work though its basicly click on the words or events which are related (somehow) or that describe this scene by clicking words like "Panic", "Begging" or "Happy". Its impossible to fail the game, you could get caught by demons, click on all wrong "detective" events and it will just keep giving you chances to try again unles you do it. For my overall opinion I guess I can call this a relaxing game with basic puzzle-solving elements that you can stare at and let your mind go blank, its not a bad game even though its no challange and one time I nearly got stuck possessing a woman walking outside of a gas station. I enjoyed the story and there is a hell of alot of stuff collectables you can pick up and read. Thought its always worth finding all the collectables to unlock a "ghost story" audio, they can be a little cliche but damn they are entertaining to listen in. Oh and one last thing, sometimes its hard finding stuff to click on like clues, the detection on some of these are really small but they are always in the tiny area you search in....though just a heads up for the last thing you do near the end of the game where you only have 3 seconds to find something to click on... clue: "hand" Literally impossible with the 3 seconds you have to click on this tiny♥♥♥♥♥thing, I had to google it after clicking everywhere. >.<

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												The best way to describe this game would be to say it's a mix of Ghost Trick and Silent Hill with a little Ace Attorney in there.  I enjoyed my time with the game, mostly to see how the story unfolds. The gameplay is nothing too special and mostly linear unless you are going for collectables (there are a lot). The writing is good for the most part but the delivery can be a bit strange sometimes. It took me just under six and a half hours to beat the game and I would recommend if you enjoy the games mentioned earlier. I also recommend going in without knowing too much about the game, which is why I don't want to write too much here.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												4/10  Murdered: Soul of Garbage CollectorI rated the gameplay with 5 and the story with 5. This game got 1/5 for gameplay 3/5 for story.-The game basically holds your hand through the whole game. There is no punishment for getting anything wrong, and some clues are really stupid. I figured out the run button long ago and the game tried to teach me that after a while.-Gameplay sucks, basically you run around and collect garbage. That is what you do, the only thing that made it even get that score was the story which isn't that great.-Characters are all have the same faces with the same thoughts. Salem had too many people with the same faces that if the killer was one of them, we wouldn't find him.-Demons are just in the way, they didn't make the gameplay any better. It made it worse since the design for the Ghost things to hid in was far away from you, or covered by a wall, or all of them in the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ room which the demons don't even go in. Ravens that supposed to help you are either far away or the range of their screams doesn't reach the demon that you wana kill. And quick time event is not my idea of a fun game. Wish they didn't created the so called demons because they always delayed me from continuing the storyline. Boring @ss obstacles on the ground, forcing you to go around them because they are demon pits or something.-All the cats have the same color which is black in Salem.-Some places you think it should be possible to teleport to but you can't even though you did it during a story mode.-Some escorting missions are stupid and  HOW the hell would July sneak into the church without the police even noticing her?- there is a Ghost train, so how the hell does an object have a ghost? Why doesn't animals get ghost too, since objects with no soul can have ghosts.  Throw the logic on the ground when you play the game.- You can't recollect the other stuff once you reach a check point in the game. I tried to see the story about the (Need Gas) but with the game desgin you MUST reply the whole thing once you enter the Judgment house. Another example of  terrible game design (wish they had the chapter saving to return to the point you need to finish any achievement you missed during your first play through) instead you have autosave.+ The only thing I liked about this game was the graveyard thief story and nothing else.I pre-ordered this game and just got to play it. Wait for a sale to buy it, and don't waste more than 10$ on it.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												If you like the Blackwell series (and I would heartily reccomend the Blackwell games, I bought them on GOG not Steam), you will likely enjoy this odd beast. I got it in the half price sale and consider it worth the 12 some quid, but I wouldn't reccomend buying it at full price since it's a fairly short game and like most adventure games, low on replayability.This is a good game with some terrible game mechanic design decisions.Pros:Decent storyEnjoyable charactersInteresting ideas explored throughout - enough to overshadow the cons, for my money.Cons:Clatty interface, probably made worse by poor porting to keyboard and mouse. If you use a pad on your PC, you may have no issues.Some really annoying QTE's bracketed with unskippable cutscenes - especially the finale which should have been exciting and ended up being an exercise in impotent rage management.Unskippable end credits that run for 15 mins  - laughably bad decision.

												A very nice take on the point and click adventure games. It has what make those a games great. A great story, with plenty of supernatural, and creepy atmosphere to pull you into it. The acting is fenomenal, you do want to know what happend to this cop, and what will be the end. Sadly like most adventure games, suffers from the same weeknesses, and I am talking about the gameplay, just like other games of this kind, like The Walking Dead, great story but not much gameplay. The same thing happens here, I think that the game would have seen more success as an episodic game. Even with these problems, and it depenps if you consider this issues a weekness, you will enjoy the game. The story is more than capable to drive you  into it. If you still have doubts, wait for a price drop, but don't miss the chance to play it. Too bad  the studio behind the game, Airtight Games is no longer around. Hopefully there will be some sort of sequel, one can hope, after all, hope dies last.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many "clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together. The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well, making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics.Very little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons, spiteful cops, or paranoia plaguing the area, thus leaving much more to be desired in character development."Extra" characters aren't even kept within the game for very long, making it feel as though there are only four real characters, and many filler characters.I "did" enjoy the game and do recommend it for those who enjoy dark, investigative, or easy-paced games. Sadly this has little to no replayability and would wait for it to go on sale for $15 or under given it's short story and neglect to several details I mentioned earlier.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												An amazing game if you know what your paying for..It's not a 3rd person adventure game like Assassin's Creed or Sleeping DogsIf you go into the game realizing that it's a new take on the old point and click adventure games where you solve puzzles and experience a narrative, then your much more likely to enjoy yourself.That being said, Murdered: Soul Suspect, does a few things really well.- Great Characters, they're very well done and you'll find yourself really caring about what happens to them.- Voice work is top notch- Extra items / Side Cases come with their own ghost stories that will have you scouring the area to make sure you collect all of them.- Setting is dark and creepy yet it feels alive thanks to all the townspeople spread throughout salemAs with any game though there are negatives of course- The demonic / exorcism dynamic of combat feels more like an afterthought meant to draw in more gamers than a mechanic that was developed to really add depth to the gameplay.- While the voicework itself is excellent.. the characters lip syncing is not as great.  Not terrible, but it's something you'll definitely pick up on from time to time.- Even though there are plenty of citizens walking about and interacting with the enviroment; there is a lot of dialogue that's used on multiple people.  Also once you decide to read their thoughts and the voiceover starts; you have to wait for it to finish before  you can listen to the next or disposses them.If you see it on sale definitely pick it up.  I managed to find this on Gamer's Gate for 13.99

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												When I first heard the announcement of Murdered: Soul Suspect, I thought this looked like an amazing idea for a video game. Then, I when it was released and officially reviewed by personalities on the internet, it was met with mixed opinion, the lesser of which delayed me from giving it a chance. During the Steam sale, I picked it up for a considerable discount, and decided for the price I paid that it would be worth it. I am happy to say, that, it's good enough to play through. Though, I doubt the replay value is remotely existant, for a couple of reasons:CONS:1) Awkward voice acting: At times when the character is supposed to have a cigarette in his mouth, the animation doesn't, so he ends up sounding like he's chewing on his tongue. This is awkward. But somewhat hilarious.2) Awkward animation: For the same reason as #1, as well as as that when dialogue is being conveyed through other characters (e.g.: other souls), they flail their arms in a strange manner as they talk, obviously on a loop of animation that doesn't always fit with the dialogue. As for Ronan, he himself likes to move way too much in conversation. He moves his hips, he shuffles his feet, and he keeps shaking his head. He's either disappointed and frustrated with everybody, or he just can't get past the fact that he has no perception of touch when being dead.3) Cliche: Personally, I've seen the "gruff guy working together with spunky young girl" scenario too many times. It works for the characters, I suppose, but, Joy, the girl, mostly just comes across as very unreasonable. As for Ronan, in this "partnership", for a guy that used to be into some pretty dangerous♥♥♥♥♥♥ he comes across as a bit of a pushover. He helps her out and she up and leaves. She makes an ungrateful remark, and he smirks, shakes his head, and shuffles his feet. Yep. Then he goes after her, and they end up working together again. Repeat (it seems thus far, but I haven't completed the game yet, so who knows? There could be a curve ball in there somewhere, like... *gasp!* She comes to actually like him?! :O )4) Confusing: When I say confusing, I mean only one thing; seeing buildings, and watching live people walk through them, but you can't. Why can't you? Because you're a ghost, and this is a "ghost building" that you can't pass through. What?5) Easiness: Whenever you go to assist another spirit in their issues, sometimes, the clues are literally right in front of them. If the other spirit just took two steps to the left, they would find out what they needed to know. "I wonder where my body is? I lived with the old couple and now I'm dead and don't remember what happened, how I died, or anything except that they had something to do with it... Hmm... Ah well. The trail has gone cold."6) Clues:  Finding all the clues for the main case can be a bit tedious, especially when you just want to go through the window after the girl and follow the trail! I know where she went, I want to go after her, dammit! xD As well, you're roped into a small confined space to find the clues within, and many things jump out, while others are more intangible. It's not very interesting, most of the time, and makes me just want to move on, a la "go through the window after the girl". PROS: 1) Good animation: Very fluid, and I haven't hit any strange framerate issues or animation glitches... yet.2) Game Mechanics: The overall controls and movement is great, as well as the interaction and detective work that you have to utilise to advance the story. It's solid. Though detective work becomes a bit tedious.3) Character design: It's very interesting. Ronan is probably the best looking dead guy I've seen lately.4) Ronan reminds me of John Marston from Red Dead Redemption. Yeah.5) You get to possess and play as a CAT. Meow.I'd say, if you're in the mood to play a very simple, interesting detective game, with little replay value (IMO), and see it on sale, go for it. If you're expecting something like LA Noire, and really enjoyed that game, you might not enjoy this as much. If you're just curious and want to try it out, chances are you'll end up shelfing it. Now, let's see how the ending plays out....AFTER-END EDITS:Alright, so I just finished playing the game. I got a good majority of the achievements, and can honestly say that I have no intentions of going back to gather the remaining ones I missed. But for a good reason!Repetition. Honestly, this game wasn't half bad, and after getting through from beginning to end, I'd say it's something I actually quite enjoyed. That said, however, I will be uninstalling it now. Why? Allow me to repeat myself:Repetition.It's an interesting game with detailed locations, great source material, and a somewhat intriguing story. But, I just can't get past the fact that there is so much, well... repetition. Let me break it down:1) Go to a location2) Start investigation (of said area) and look for clues (some obvious, some not so obvious)3) Come to a conclusion3a) Help another spirit in the area come to terms with something more or less obvious4) Avoid demons.5) Move on. It got to the point where i felt like I just wanted to ignore finding all of the details, hidden items, and extra historical case file "things" laying around, because I did it so many times, I felt like I was playing a scavenger hunt game, rather than a detective-style game. Which is more or less what this is: a scavenger hunt, with a pretty package, and some interesting mechanics thrown in, based on the Salem Witch Trials, which, on a normal day, I find fascinating.And the demons... oh, the demons... Don't expect action, here. And the "crows" that are around that you can stir up to attract the demons so as to take them out? Well, I never used them. You just have to wait for the demon to turn around, run up behind, and take them out (which is 1 of 2 things he figured out on his own out of thin air, just like "teleporting"), or just run past them. It's that simple. Having played games like "Still Life" and "Still Life 2", I'd say, if you're looking for a great mystery game, go play those! Those are gritty, dark, interesting, and genuinely investable for your emotions, at times. Murdered: Soul Suspect? Well, it's good. But I certainly won't be playing it again. Not to say it's not worth playing through at least once, because, honestly, if it's within your price range, or on sale, go ahead and pick it up. It'll keep you busy for a while and give you something to look back on and go "Huh. That was definitely something else". And then move on from.Uninstalled.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												THIS GAME IS BROKEN - I really like the game. The atmosphere is great and some of the mechanics are very clever but it simply does not work. On one side quest I left the "area" before completing the investigation and now it does not function. From researching the problem, the only fix is to START ALL OVER AGAIN. Due to this being a fairly pathetic console port, there is no option to save, so any glitch gets you starting from a checkpoint at the beginning of an area at best. True problems and you are done. The thing that really did it for me was a glitch in the main story line at the police station. I could not finish a scene because (after researching what I may be doing wrong) I discovered that an event was not triggering properly to let me continue. So I restarted at last checkpoint but the event still did not trigger. The only solution? START THE GAME OVER AGAIN.Sorry guys. This game had great potential and even solid execution in many ways bit if the game does not work FIX IT!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I have mixed feelings about Murdered: Soul Suspect. I enjoyed the game with it's very unique style, and the story full of twists and turns, so I do recommend it, but there are a few issues that prevent this from being as good as it could have been.Some of the puzzles require you to choose "most relevant" clues, so you might pick 3 from 10, but it often feels like guesswork. Not guesswork into your character or the story, but guesswork into the developers minds. This can lead to frustration, but doesn't prevent progress.If you miss a clue earlier in the game, even though you can return to that location, the clue isn't always there. A lot of people get stuck on the 15/16 issue with Apartment 4A, for example, and that was the one clue preventing me from a perfect score. The final area does give you a warning message, but once you enter it, you cannot return to a previous save to hunt down any remaining clues. As soon as you enter the area, you are either choosing to give up on side quests, or planning to replay the entire game again. Those issues aside, it's a great experience and worth playing if you can pick it up on sale.

If you still have doubts, wait for a price drop, but don't miss the chance to play it. Too bad  the studio behind the game, Airtight Games is no longer around. Hopefully there will be some sort of sequel, one can hope, after all, hope dies last.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												First things first: the game is really short. You can get 100% without any guides in about 10 hours, even less if you just rush the main story. Yet the game (or should I say "the movie"?) is also fun and well made. Not an AAA-title, but it's definitely a game I sincerely enjoyed.I liked the dark setting, the overall style and visuals and all the little details here and there. Also the detective story is not bad. The first half of the game is the best because you don't really understand what is going on. After that the rough outline of the story becomes more and more clear which made it a bit less interesting for me. This game may also be for you if you like to just wander and see all what there is to see in the world (though it's definitely not Skyrim).Also it is an easy game. You can't fail even if you try really hard! The gameplay is linear as a stick, the investigations can be brute forced (although they are not difficult anyway) and there no story choices to make at all, even cosmetic ones. Action sequences (the demons) become a chore rather quick. Overall it was not a problem since I played not for challenge but rather for relaxation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I have mixed feelings about Murdered: Soul Suspect. I enjoyed the game with it's very unique style, and the story full of twists and turns, so I do recommend it, but there are a few issues that prevent this from being as good as it could have been.Some of the puzzles require you to choose "most relevant" clues, so you might pick 3 from 10, but it often feels like guesswork. Not guesswork into your character or the story, but guesswork into the developers minds. This can lead to frustration, but doesn't prevent progress.If you miss a clue earlier in the game, even though you can return to that location, the clue isn't always there. A lot of people get stuck on the 15/16 issue with Apartment 4A, for example, and that was the one clue preventing me from a perfect score. The final area does give you a warning message, but once you enter it, you cannot return to a previous save to hunt down any remaining clues. As soon as you enter the area, you are either choosing to give up on side quests, or planning to replay the entire game again. Those issues aside, it's a great experience and worth playing if you can pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Although there are many issues with this game, I really do recomend it. It's not great, but it is worth playing.The main problem of the game is that it feels really underdeveloped.The story is short, I think you can finish it in around 5 hours if you rush through the game and skip all the collectibles.There are some pretty useless mechanics included, like, for example, reading people thoughts. At first I was quite excited that I can possess pretty much any NPC and read its mind, but I quickly discovered that most of the thoughts are repeating itself and they are absolutely useless.There are enemies in this game. One kind of enemy to be exact. Demons are annoying addition that doesn't introduce anything to the game except from dull idea of banishing them. You just walk behind a demon, hold R to start banishing and then press mouse button + direction key that pops up on screen. It's excatly as exciting as it seems. Not at all. No thrill, no fear, not even a startle from some jumpscare. They appear, you banish and move on. They could remove them completely from the game as they pose no threat at all and only thing that they manage to achieve is to annoy you.Controls are pretty bad. Especially menu controls. You can use mouse only to point the option you want, to select it you have to use your keyboard.Many technical problems, bugs. Sometimes gamebreaking.The game is faaar to easy.What I enjoyed about the game is the story itself. However short it is, it was really entertaining for me. I love the atmosphere of Salem. Conducting the investigation even though it could be more complex. That's what basically makes the game worth playing for me: the story and the world presented in it. I do recomend the game, however not for its full price. If you see it on some good sale go for it, but else just wait for the price to go down.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Enjoyable story-driven murder mystery. Not really exceptional in any way, but the story and mechanics are interesting. You play a detective who becomes a ghost and thus can walk through walls and do other ghostly stuff while investigating a series of murders. While item collection is heavily featured, it doesn't seem simply shoehorned in to increase the game's length. Each item you collect contributes in some way to the story background/context. The only part that got repetitive and predictable was the demon mechanic: I felt it only interrupted your progress while you dealt with them essentially the same way in every level. Recommended for its enjoyable story and original mechanics.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is engaging and enjoyable.  The atmosphere and graphics are great.  You explore Salem and 'ghost Salem' as a ghost and as a detective, solving your case and many side cases along the way.  Ghost Salem physically exists for ghosts, as a barrier which prevents you from accessing areas of Salem too easily and as a mode of access to collectables in areas you wouldn't have access to in normal Salem e.g. ghost stairs.There is a lot to engage with: collectables (too many, in my opinion), stories to unlock, ghosts hanging around (they say the best things in the graveyard).  It does get repetative and there isn't a challange.  The game is easy to beat but there's still a small amount of action such as dealing with demons.  I find the game satisfactory for entertaining, easy gameplay but I wouldn't pay $30 for it.  Maybe if it was more challanging, everything down to the puzzles are simple.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												To be honest, I feel that this game got a lot more flack than was deserved. Is it perfect? No, but I think the criticisms were a bit extreme. Mind you, most of the criticisms I read were during the time that it was initially released and some of it had to do with bugs.I'm guessing that by the time I bought the game (4 months after release) all those bugs were fixed because I didn't really have any of the issues that they were talking about. There were times, however, I noticed that the narration would cut out. This happened in maybe 3-5 different cutscenes were there was just no sound at all - the only way I knew what was supposed to have been said during the scene was because I always have subtitles on.I think what hurt the game more than anything else was the story. It was okay, but I feel that it could have been better - more developed maybe. Also I feel like the characters were poorly written.I say this because I felt no emotion towards any of them whatsover. The wife was annoying, and there were too many random collectibles of her memories with him - I'm guessing like finding pages of her diary or something scattered around. I felt myself annoyed with all of these and couldn't care less about her or their relationship.The friendship or, partnership I guess, between Ronan and Joy felt really shallow. Since Joy is the character Ronan interacts with the most throughout the game, I was hoping for more development in their friendship.  Also the way Joy treated Ronan after he saves her from The Bell Killer is ridiculous. I'm not expecting her to want to help him right away but it was a bit much imho I couldn't even find myself caring about Ronan himself. None of the characters in the game were developed enough for me to root for them or care about them in anyway. Also I felt it was strange that all the events in the entire game takes place in one night. Why on earth was that one couple getting married in the middle of the night / wee hours of the morning? The demons in the game were laughable. It felt like it was just thrown in at the last minute to give the game some kind of combat in it. They should have either given the combat more diversity or taken the demons out completely, in my opinion. I didn't play the game with combat in mind so I wouldn't have cared if there was no combat in this game. There are perfectly good Adventure Mystery games with absolutely no combat in it (the majority of Sherlock Holmes titles for example).With all that negative out of the way now for the positives: I appreciate the game trying to do something different. I'm a big fan of Adventure Mystery type games and one that approaches it from the perspective of a ghost is innovative and interesting. I enjoyed walking through walls and possessing adorable felines, as well as the people around town.It would have been great if they expanded a bit more on this - more animals to possess, control over individuals in town like how Abigail was able to control humans to do her killings  , as well as being able to poltergeist more items.To sum up my review, I would recommend people to give the game a go. It's enjoyable and fun and I definitely don't think it deserved 59 on metacritic. I would rate it more of a 6/10. It's worth a play through to get to play and experience something different. The mystery is also relatively engaging.I just wouldn't get this game at full price - wait for a sale. I was able to scoop it up during one for 4.99.
