number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story driven game in it's entirety.  The initial events and investigations that followed kept me interested enough to keep playing to the end.  In that regard, Murdered succeeds and is why I'm giving it a thumbs up recommendation.  However, if I was able to vote with both thumbs, it would be one up and one down... I was on the fence about this one.   Why?On the positive side, the story of a modern murder mystery slowly unraveling as the victim himself uncovers the truth is satisfying.  It starts very strong and doesn't end the way you might expect, so that was refreshing.  But there comes a point when as a player you piece together the basic gist of what is happening but Ronan takes a while longer to 'get it'.  This is about mid-point in the game and it was quite frustrating because Ronan is supposed to be an investigator but due to his inability to make the connections before the player does, the game seems to drag until Ronan catches up.  The ending does leave a lot of 'huh?' questions in your mind and does feel a little anti-climactic.  I think this is mostly due to discovering several things all at once in once scene, then end credits.  There is no pacing to the final shocking revelations, and therefore no real chance to feel closure, empathy, relief, satisfaction... none of it.  It's there but it happens too fast.  So fast that Ronan doesn't even react to a world-shattering personal discovery.The characters are memorable.  Pairing the main character Ronan with a mostly reticent, feisty, but intelligent teen Joy adds a lot of chemistry.  Joy is well written and performed.  For me she was the star.  Ronan was a rough and tumble kind of guy before meeting his soulmate, and the mellow, tolerant side of him is done well but that's the only side we get to see.  I was severely disappointed by the lack of strong emotion or raw aggression that could have bled through on many occassions but doesn't.  Sadly Ronan comes off as deadpan.The environment is very well done, with a quiet moody setting where the grim nature of it's history can be seen through your dead eyes.On the negative side, this is a game.  Or more precisely, it tries to be a game.  Almost every single game aspect  just gets in the way, slows things down, and makes you wish the substance it hides was more fleshed out.  The presence of demons and the need to evade and/or exorcise them is haphazardly thrown into the mix.  They look cool and scare the crap out of you when they start chasing you, but these notably gameplay moments seem so disjointed from the story.  It's like the developers said 'OK let's just throw some game in right here'. There is a heavy collecting element to this game if you want your story fleshed out.  From Ronan's background, to his relationship with his lost wife, to history of the setpieces... it's all locked away in the text granted to you when you find something which is not always related.  I'd say maybe half of these were worth reading for good background info.  The rest were all useless to the story and the game.  Of special note are the area specific ghost stories you can unlock.  Most of them are interesting and I really wish they had been incorporated into the story somehow.The investigation and possession elements were great concepts that were presented so incredibly poorly.  When you attempt to solve an investigation the premise is that you take clues and piece them together to come to a conclusion.  Among those pieces are clues that don't help.  If you get one clue wrong, it exits the minigame and you start again.  So all you have to do is keep trying each one until you get it right, and there aren't that many to choose from anyways.  It feels really pointless.  You can inhabit the body of people and read or influence their thoughts, but the thoughts are so plain and boring and the chances to influence people are few and far between.  More wasted potential.My recommendation is to enjoy the game for the story and just follow the carrot.  The gameplay is easy enough to just get through so you can keep the main story moving along.  Collecting and killing demons and exploration are entirely not necessary (unless you want achievements in which case you will be forced to grind through everything).  The game length felt good for a story driven game; not so short that I felt ripped off but not too long that I felt it was watered down or needless.I'd also recommend getting this at $15 or less, which I feel is a fair price point.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many "clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together. The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well, making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics.Very little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons, spiteful cops, or paranoia plaguing the area, thus leaving much more to be desired in character development."Extra" characters aren't even kept within the game for very long, making it feel as though there are only four real characters, and many filler characters.I "did" enjoy the game and do recommend it for those who enjoy dark, investigative, or easy-paced games. Sadly this has little to no replayability and would wait for it to go on sale for $15 or under given it's short story and neglect to several details I mentioned earlier.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												Set in the notorious New England town of Salem, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a ghost story themed murder mystery investigation game. I recommend this game to all who value story, atmosphere and interesting characters and setting, as well as collectibles over fast-paced fighting or trial and error gameplay. The best part of the game is slowly unlocking the riddle surrounding your own murder and many others, as well as piecing together the stories of lost souls you encounter along the way. Generally speaking, the puzzles are very easy (by comparison with something like Monkey Island) and the QTE combat is so trivial it might as well not exist. If you can get it on sale it is a nice experience with loads of good cutscenes, some nice dialogue and a well written story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												I can see how this game might disappoint others, as there is so much more it could do as a survival horror and as a detective game, but for what it is, I think this is a brilliant game, and there are enough items and secrets to find to give it replay value. I guess because of the different path options of another certain "poltergeist simulator" if you like i.e. Beyond Two Souls it is often a shame when I play games like this now and there aren't multiple endings (even Silent Hill 2 had different endings on replays), but I guess we are a little spoilt, and this isn't trying to be a David Chase or a Deus Ex game. The idea itself was so novel and appealing I knew I had to grab this eventually, it reminded me of the basic premise of the old PS2 game Shadow of Memories in which you travel back in time to solve your own murder. In this moody, supernatural almost LA Noire style of setting I knew I couldn't resist. It wasn't until I played it I realised it's all set in Salem, so given that the backstory and local folklore have a large presence in this game, this was one hell of a bonus for me given my interest in the witch hunts and magic. The music and atmosphere didn't disappoint. The backstory and tragic history is incorporated into it very well, and the way in which this game combined supernatural elements with crime scene investigation was really inventive and original.  As said, there are things you can miss as well, but this is mostly side missions. I guess few games if any have really matched LA Noire in this department. The graphics look great, can't fault the voice acting either. In terms of the horror elements, as a puzzle game it's challenging enough, but seeing the same ghouls everywhere gets very repetitive very quickly, and it just becomes a chore of running, hiding and timing. It's different enough but just has no variety, still I can see how hard it is to do something really novel and inventive with the ghost-themed survival horror format. Especially if you are a ghost yourself. Overall great game worth getting, worth experiencing and worth playing again, just don't be too disappointed by the length and lack of variety in gameplay....Salem does allow for some exploration, though.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												Although there are many issues with this game, I really do recomend it. It's not great, but it is worth playing.The main problem of the game is that it feels really underdeveloped.The story is short, I think you can finish it in around 5 hours if you rush through the game and skip all the collectibles.There are some pretty useless mechanics included, like, for example, reading people thoughts. At first I was quite excited that I can possess pretty much any NPC and read its mind, but I quickly discovered that most of the thoughts are repeating itself and they are absolutely useless.There are enemies in this game. One kind of enemy to be exact. Demons are annoying addition that doesn't introduce anything to the game except from dull idea of banishing them. You just walk behind a demon, hold R to start banishing and then press mouse button + direction key that pops up on screen. It's excatly as exciting as it seems. Not at all. No thrill, no fear, not even a startle from some jumpscare. They appear, you banish and move on. They could remove them completely from the game as they pose no threat at all and only thing that they manage to achieve is to annoy you.Controls are pretty bad. Especially menu controls. You can use mouse only to point the option you want, to select it you have to use your keyboard.Many technical problems, bugs. Sometimes gamebreaking.The game is faaar to easy.What I enjoyed about the game is the story itself. However short it is, it was really entertaining for me. I love the atmosphere of Salem. Conducting the investigation even though it could be more complex. That's what basically makes the game worth playing for me: the story and the world presented in it. I do recomend the game, however not for its full price. If you see it on some good sale go for it, but else just wait for the price to go down.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Short version:+ Amazing detective story + Background stories of characters to uncover+ Possess cats and never ending cigarette+ No need to use doors, just walk through walls- Obviously made for consoles-- Boring and linear gameplay-- No action, apart from demons= 6.5/10Long version:First of all, this game has a Metascore of 59/100 and I can kind of understand why. This is not about the story or the characters, but mainly because of the gameplay.WARNING: minor spoilers (not really spoilers, but just in case, you know). Marked them.Story: The story is simply ah-ma-zing. In my opinion, it’s a great murder mystery in which you have to solve your own death (and prevent others from dying too). The whole ghost-idea is greatly elaborated in the story and makes the whole thing quite original: you’re not the usual cop who has to solve the usual murder mystery. The game has some great (and by that I mean unexpected and mind-blowing) plot twists. And, honestly, I didn’t expect the actual murderer to be the murderer, if you know what I mean.Characters: I LOVE how the characters’ stories become clear throughout the game. Most of the characters’ stories are quite vague when you start the game, but as you progress and collect artifacts, you learn more about each one of them. It made me want to keep playing, not only to know who my killer was, but also to know more about other people’s lives and deaths (and Ronan’s tattoos, for example). The side quests are nice additions to the story; they aren’t very long, but quite interesting, too. The main characters aren't really stereotypes, in my opinion. For example, the fact that Ronan was a gangster himself while he was young, doesn’t make him the stereotype cop (not really sure if spoiler, but marked just in case). It makes the game much more interesting than your usual detective story. The side characters, on the other hand, are much more flat and typical.Gameplay: Not great. Even boring, after a while. You walk around in Salem, investigate surroundings to find clues, possess people (and cats!), hide from and defeat demons, poltergeist stuff, and, well, that’s about it. It’s the same thing over and over again, for the maximum of 15 hours of gameplay the game has to offer (one playthrough). No real puzzles, just looking around and finding things. No real action, I believe there’s a maximum of 20 demons to defeat throughout the game. The combat is boring: you have to sneak up to them and kill them with nothing but your bare hands. You have no defense apart from some hiding spots. The demons are in my opinion unnecessary and only a burden to the game. The game’s pretty linear, too. You have no choice but to follow the storyline. Between cutscenes, you can walk around freely in Salem and the areas you’ve already visited throughout the story.Also, it’s obvious this is a game made for consoles, not for pc. I mean, “Press START”? You’re joking, right? You’re unable to change the controls, so if you’re playing with an AZERTY-keyboard, you’ll have to change the language settings of your pc. I really recommend playing this with a controller, if you have one: it suits the overall gameplay much better.Other: Great graphics. The creepy music fits the atmosphere and story perfectly. Good voice acting. Achievements are relatively easy to obtain, apart from some artifacts. Also, DO NOT ENTER THE MUSEUM IN THE END OF THE GAME before you’ve collected all artifacts! You won’t be able to return, or play the whole game from the start to collect the missing ones.Conclusion: I was doubting whether I would go for recommended or not, since the gameplay is such a disappointment. I did go for recommended, because I haven’t seen such a great and original detective story in all my life.I wouldn’t recommend buying this game if it’s not on sale: €30 ($37.5?) is way too pricey in my opinion. Like detectives, murder mysteries and story-driven games? I guess you can give this a shot. Want action, adventure and shooting? Not the right game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Let's get one thing out of the way: "Murdered: Soul Suspect" is not your normal action game. Actually, it is actually not an action game at all; it is more a story-driven adventure focused on exploration and (very logic) puzzle-solving that centers around clue finding and logic implications among them; the plot is thick, with lots of twists and turns all along the way which will nail you to your chair until you're done. There's only one caveat: it's rather short -- I managed to complete it in under 10 hours.There are also "combat" sequences against demons (ghosts that turned evil after forsaking what they were meant to "fix" in the living world before leaving it) that are more annoying than anything else as they involve hide-and-seek mechanics; I think that there is a lot of room for improvement in that area but I am not complaining too much.There is one more thing that I dislike though: the whole collectable item craze that the game is so soaked with. Some are in obvious places, others in less-obvious ones, while others are really unfindable unless you comb the town of Salem systematically -- and it's rather hard to do it without a map of the place. Through the collection of clues and items, you either go forward with the main story or unlock sidequests or insights about the protagonists and the town itself.When it comes to presentation, graphics are really good (locked at 30 FPS but there's no sensation of lag at all), the audio acting is well done and the music hits the spot without being particularly memorable.I recommend this game if you're into ghost stories (or well-written stories in general) and like to enjoy a slower-paced game that requires a minimum of thinking.My vote for the game: 7/10 (with a gameplay vote of 5.5/10 and one for the story of 8.5/10)

												Just finished the game and I really enjoyed it. While it doesn't take long to play it through (I needed 8 hours and I took my time) it was fun while it lasted. I am not sure about the replay value, though. The game heavily relies on its thick atmosphere and the story twists to drive you along and I imagine it will be less fun the second time around. If you don't care for pages after pages of story or lots of cut scenes or do expect a certain amount of fighting in your games you should skip this one, though. There are a few "fight" scenes but you have to solve them through misdirection and stealth. No open combat. Still, if you do enoy a good story and an atmospheric game you should give this one a try. I recommend playing it at night or in a darkened room - both for the atmosphere and to see all the details on the screen. You should also take the time and gather as many clues as possible, especially for the small side quests. The stories are delightfully spooky.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Once you get past the fact that this is a port and has no configurable controls (stuck to wasd), its a very enjoyable game. I played it with the xbox controller in the end. The story is interesting, though maybe let down a little at the end. The collectables add little bits of information and stories on their own which I enjoyed finding. Playing as a ghost, you are able to walk through most walls and furniture, possess people and read their thoughts (the latter not as good as it sounds, basically generic two liners for each person, not all different), find clues and piece it all together. The bit I enjoyed most was helping other ghosts discover what had happened to them, collecting the clues and setting them at peace. I wish there'd been a lot more of that. I enjoyed every minute of it and will undoubtedly play again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												An amazing game if you know what your paying for..It's not a 3rd person adventure game like Assassin's Creed or Sleeping DogsIf you go into the game realizing that it's a new take on the old point and click adventure games where you solve puzzles and experience a narrative, then your much more likely to enjoy yourself.That being said, Murdered: Soul Suspect, does a few things really well.- Great Characters, they're very well done and you'll find yourself really caring about what happens to them.- Voice work is top notch- Extra items / Side Cases come with their own ghost stories that will have you scouring the area to make sure you collect all of them.- Setting is dark and creepy yet it feels alive thanks to all the townspeople spread throughout salemAs with any game though there are negatives of course- The demonic / exorcism dynamic of combat feels more like an afterthought meant to draw in more gamers than a mechanic that was developed to really add depth to the gameplay.- While the voicework itself is excellent.. the characters lip syncing is not as great.  Not terrible, but it's something you'll definitely pick up on from time to time.- Even though there are plenty of citizens walking about and interacting with the enviroment; there is a lot of dialogue that's used on multiple people.  Also once you decide to read their thoughts and the voiceover starts; you have to wait for it to finish before  you can listen to the next or disposses them.If you see it on sale definitely pick it up.  I managed to find this on Gamer's Gate for 13.99

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I just finished this game an hour ago.  I'm not sure why people feels the need to write a review without finishing the game, if I had judged the game after an hour of playing it I would have turned it down too, but after an hour you're not attached to anything, if you're looking for instant gratification in a detective game, you should have never even installed it.At first the fact that its a console port nearly turned me off to it but I trudged on and found that its not all that bad.  I would recommend the game for those who likes the detective style game.PROS------------------------------* Well made storyline* Wealth of history about Salem during the Salem Witch Trials* Ronin and Joy are pretty memorable characters* Pretty original gameplay elements, such as modern infrastructure infusing with past infrastructure.* Great sudden turn of events often* Fair amount of collectibles to learn about side missions and such* Cinematics and voice acting are very well put togetherCONS------------------------------* Console port, you can't rebind keys which leads to mistakes sometimes, especially during QT events* Quick time events are annoying when you're trying to do them with a keyboard/mouse* Some glitches, but nothing game breaking* Not well optimized for PC, often stutters a little

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Just wow.This game is such an amazing and unusual experience. A grim detective story with such a vivid characters, voice acting and visual style. This is a great game, which contsits a half of exploration and a half of interactive movie. Exploration, even if limited, is done in really interesting plain - you're a ghost, and thus you can walk through walls, collect and read ghostly notes and hints, learn about places and their stories. You will investigate some simple problems by collecting evidence, looking and listening. The 'movie' part is done nice. The plot is pretty interesting, although so simple. Sometimes I was wondering, when my character will figure out the killer. I mean, I partly looked through it before the game called the killer. However even by figuring out what was happening I've never seen who exactly was the one to blame. And there was yet another unexpected twist. So even if plot is slightly predictable, It's written dam-good. Definitely a movie I liked to play.I loved cats in this game. Just like cats should be in games. Fast, black, agile, a little glitchy. What I didn't like about them was how people react them. Like zero F-s were given that night.I loved that monitor reference in police station. You'll know when you see it. Square Enix, oh you.Now to the downsides:1. This is a game best played with a gamepad. I mean it. It wasn't made to be on PC, it was made to be cross-platform. So even if it supports keyboard+mouse, use a controller, if you have one.2. There is no free roam after you've reached the last checkpoint. The main menu will offer you to continue, but this is merely a last checkpoint, no way to collect something you've left for later.3. Not sure about the reason, but sometimes I've experienced minor graphic glitches while ui showed/hided collected piece of evidence. Might be just my laptop.4. Repetative faces of pedestrians. There's something like two or three models for each gender. Nuff said.5. Really strange placement of hiding spots. Some places have plenty of them, but never needed. The others feature but a few spots, but you will need more if you need them. And some are too far to jump between them.6. Font. Handwriting fonts in games never work as easy-to-read fonts. And this game has tons of handwritten text. Although I managed to read without problems, some might have them.But in the end, I really enjoyed this game. It's certainly a great experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Writing this review immediately after finishing the game.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third person adventure, with quite a few aspects of the horror genre. The game is rather short (Roughly five hours), and the combat in the game is simply sneaking up behind the enemies and pressing a combination of buttons. Although the combat was a bit repetitive, the story itself was rather interesting for me. You play as a recently murdered detective named Ronan, who is has been left behind as a ghost in the mortal world, because he has unfinished business, which won't allow him to join his wife; who has already moved on. In order for Ronan to move on he has to find out the mystery behind his killer. As he is a ghost, he can only tamper with very few things in the mortal world, so with the help of a young girl named Joy, they work together to unravel the mystery between the Bell Killer murders, as well as the identity of the killer.7.5/10

												A very short game that came in a humble bundle. Basically L.A. Noire with ghosts. Virtually no combat except for irritating stealth portions. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Story 8.5/10 - If you have the patience to wade through the tedium, there's an interesting story here.Story execution 6/10 - Voice acting was good, usually.  The cutscenes were choppy and low quality.  The dialogue would bounce between statements in a way that made you feel like... like they were prerecorded then cut and pasted together.Atmosphere 8/10 - I consider myself pretty judgmental when it comes to this sort of thing, cause I feel like people have to resort to cheap thrills to make something interesting and horror-oriented.  Although there are a few such cheap tricks, the majority of the game creates an atmosphere that is genuinely interesting, scary, and unique.Unique Mechanics 7/10 - The puzzle aspect is nice, but not impressive.  It would be awesome, except that after a few minutes it starts to feel like a game of "Where's Waldo", in which you just look for little details that feel very pre-defined.Gameplay 4/10 - The game feels sluggish and awkward.  Getting your character to face a clue can occassionally be problematic.  Much of the game felt like overcoming the tedium of moving your character through the environment in order to find hidden objects.Level design 3/10 - The maps feel very chaotic and disorganized.  While the general layout may be right (Here's a church, up front there's a chappel, in back there're some other rooms), the execution of the specifics feels pretty awkward and staged.  It's made worse by the "ghost obstacles" that artificially block your path basically everywhere.Graphics 6.5/10 - The main character has the best art of anything in the game.  The overall feel fits the atmosphere, but neither the graphics nor the art are particularly gripping.Bugginess 3/10 - Had the game crash 5+ times in 10 hours of gameplay.  Once it required me to force-powerdown my computer, since even the task manager couldn't come up.Overall 6.5/10 - The twisty, creepy story makes up for an otherwise poor game.  I bought it in the humble bundle, and don't regret the purchase.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I picked this up on a sale for 1,99€ and it was worth the money.It's a point and click detective game with a supernatural story.It's not much to the detective part in the game, you mostly answer questions by clicking on clues you have found.The game have some kind of system where if you guess something wrong you lose a "badge" and you have three badges for each mystery but it will not effect anything in the game as far as I could tell.It feels like it was meant for a achievement but they never put it in or that the detective part was supposed to be more complex but got scratched later on.The game have a nice old detective movie feeling to it and the story keeps you interesting.The story is about a detective that have to solve his on murder as a ghost to move on. The two main characters are good written and works well together. It's a nice spooky feeling throughout the game even tho it's not a horror game.In addition to the main story you can solve a handful of side cases for lost spirits around the world to give them peace and in addition to that there is a lot of collectables scattered around.The collectables tells you about the town, the murderer, your character and ghost stories. The ghost stories is a really nice addition, I appreciated them a lot.It took me around eleven hours to finish and I did most of the side stuff, I missed some collectables.If you see this game on a sale I would recommand you to pick it up but not for the current pricetag (29,99€).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Was a gift from a good friend of mine (Humble Bundle)A mix of adventure, detective mystery solving game.  Seriously, just don't hover near the spoilers if you haven't played the game yet Pros :  - Interesting storyline - The town looks great with the mix of  a past (ghost) and present theme  - Voice Acting - Plot twist!  - A game that  lets you play as a cat   - Being a ghost is somehow fun - Unique playstyle Cons :  - The story is too linear.  Putting routes on stories and additional mini quest is fine  - Demons  Stealth in a detective mystery game sounds good but really, screeching demons who chase you but they leave you once you move in a specific spot. Also, sometimes annoying...  - Save slots would be fine. You have to replay the game once you finish/restart to the last checkpoint (A bit of a hassle when it comes to achievement farming) - Point and click. Investigations are kind of easy since they already tell you where the clues are. You can just spam E in the map and you'll probably find the clue   - NPCs - just remove some of the  mind reading  or just  keep them silent . It's confusing  when you're looking for clues   - Locked to 30 FPS....  - Cutscenes...  A skip button would be nice if you die or restart from another checkpoint  - Too short (Finished within 9.6 hours - including breaks)Needs a lot more improvement still. Would buy a sequel if there is one Better buy it on sale.Rating : 7/10

												This game reminds me of Deadly Premonition.It's objectively 6/10 at best, but at the same time it has lots of charm, interesting characters, spooky atmosphere and engaging plot.You can tell that devs tried to "do something different". Game exhibits few interesting quirks, that are unfortunately not played to their full potential (reading people's thoughts, possesion, poltergeist activity). I wouldn't pay full price for this one, but you should probably give it a try once it goes on sale - especially if you are fed up with AAA titles with AC combat.

												Good adventure, detective-murder-mystery-solving game with a gimmick - you're trying to find out who your killer is, Despite all the low scores from major publications, I think this is a great game. It doesn't overwhelm you with too many mechanics and most of the time what you have to do is pretty straightforward (some might see this a con but it works for me). Looks pretty and sounds alright (the demons do some pretty wicked shrieks). Throughout the game there are also collectibles that, when found, grant you flashbacks to various spooky story from Salem's past - I found these to be a really nice way of immersing you even more into the game's world.Also, you get to play as a cat with a dedicated "Meow" button, so go buy this game right now.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												This is really a different type of game unlike any I have played before.  Basically you go around collecting items (alot of optional items) to get stories to read and unlock.  Often times you have to find clues and piece them together so the evidence tells a story helping you in your search for the serial killer.  While the game looks pretty decent graphically, there are times where things just fell off.  For example the killer could have just murdered someone in the town yet some of the peoples mood in the town does not reflect that.  There are times when some townspeople say the same exact thing by the same voice actor or actress.  One time near the end of the game I read this old ladies mind and had the voice of a teenage girl.  There are somel moments in the game where you have to be stealthy to avoid demons and you do have the option of killing them .   As the game progressed I was more interested in how the story would develop and there was a nice plot twist towards the end.   Its a fairly short game which was the main reason I played this game after reading alot of less than positive reviews.  I'll give the game 5/10  and recommend buying it if you can get it really cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Get it when it is cheap - it is short and has no replay value beyond collecting things, and you cannot revisit earlier areas after reaching the finale. Overall, it is a pretty decent unfinished business ghost story. It comes equipped with the ex-con cop, lovable scamp sidekick, some plot twists, and posessing cats and people to get to locations your short-range ghost teleport can't reach. The setting was interesting to me, and there were some small jokes in a few levels such as ghost hunters in the cemetary, and a ghost right in front of the camera smiling and waving - that nobody can see.The levels are fairly well designed, although some clues require more accuracy in placement with how close to other clues they are. The demons were interesting at first but quickly became just an annoyance once you near the end of the game. Most areas are once and done, although you do revisit one of the opening areas as part of the plot and can return to areas up until the finale.This is mostly an adventure game - the only notable action sequences are exorcising demons, a single section where you have to deal with a ghost train ( which was pretty neat ), and the finale, and even then they are more or less quick time events. The rest of the game is spent navigating the hub You are unable to change the controls if you use the mouse and keyboard. The game itself doesn't have too many poor performance spots aside from some area transitions and, at least in my case, antialiasing smoke/fog during the opening sequence.The collectables were mostly pointless - the story parts, such as the water tank, rifles, saws, gas tanks, etc. were brief ghost stories - generic, but not poorly written.Overall, I feel the main issue is how short the game is - the entire plot encompasses a single night and will only really take three or four hours at most, and feels like a large chunk of that time was exorcising demons and getting to the next area. If you remove the travel time and scavenger hunt, it was rather short and would probably fit inside two hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I was put off this game initially due to negative reports about its length, and so the base price of £20 was enough to give me pause. However, when it appeared on sale for £5 I decided to give it a chance and I am very glad I did. The star of this game is its story, where you play as the ghost of Ronan O'Connor, a detective in modern day Salem. For a large part it feels like a point and click adventure game where the emphasis is on finding the pieces and putting them together rather than on any sort of direct action. Gameplay revolves around investigations that are heavily reminiscent of L.A. Noire (another game I really enjoyed) except you can walk through walls and interrogating people is mostly replaced with possessing them to influence their mind. Perhaps owing to the length of the story (it only took me around 8hrs to complete the main quest, all side quests and most collectibles) both the story and gameplay never outstayed their welcome and remained entertaining to the very end. The main negative in this game is the repetitive forced stealth segments where you are forced to sneak up on demonic spirits before a simple quick time event is entered in place of combat. I felt even after the first of these that it was an unnecessary mechanic designed as a buffer between me and the enjoyable parts of the game. I would commonly find myself sweeping an area of these "enemies" before returning to start the section proper. Thankfully, they don't take too long and aren't difficult, but this just emphasises how needless they are.I would definitely recommend this as a sale pickup if you are even remotely curious.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												There's a noticeable lack of good detective games out there: LA Noire, Sherlock Holmes series, a bit of Batman - and that's it. And there're even fewer concepts as interesting and original from the gaming perspective as this one. However, you must clearly understand what you're getting yourself into: this game definitely is a walking simulator, with the only gameplay being two-button fatalities against demons (which are not all that hard) and the actual detective routine, which consists of loooking for clues, analyzing them and being led to even more clues as a result.Also, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a dream game for any munchkin: there's an abundance of different collectibles in every area of the game and, to the developers' credit, all of those actually contain some story. Those stories (as well as the main one) are obviously and heavily influenced by Stephen King's styled "creepiness", and are well told and fairly unpredictable. In addition, voice acting is surprisingly decent for a not-AAA project.---Summarizing, Murdered: Soul Suspect entertained me for three whole evenings, which is definitely worth those $15 it's asking for right now. The gameplay simply doesn't have enough time to become repetative, and the story is being told with good pace and plenty of intrigue, concluding itself right when it should. Great voice acting gives the finishing touch to the game. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Don’t purchase this game if you expect a lot of gameplay. It’s a narrative gaming experience which involves looking around for clues and solving a few simple puzzles. Overall I had fun and when I wanted a break from action-packed games I played Murdered Soul Suspect. Let’s see the pros and cons.Pros:* The game engine: the game was developed using Unreal Engine 3, one of best engines there is. The game never crashed and I was able to play it with maxed settings and 60fps.* Visual: even though the textures aren’t exactly top notch, the motion (especially the particles) and the lightening are great.* Original concept: a detective solving his own murder, passing through walls and talking to other ghosts and mediums. That’s gotta be enticing.Cons:* The “mind reading” feature: I was expecting that every NPC would have unique thoughts and a lot of embarrassing things would be exposed to the players. That’s not what happens. By using the “mind read” in several different NPCs you might end up hearing the exact same thoughts. It appears they are randomly generated and distributed amongst the NPCs. That was definitely a disappointment for me. What’s the point of mind reading if they don’t appear to be real people, but rather randomly generated walking robots that spurs platitudes?* The linearity: it is not possible to leave an area and return to the investigation later. I reckon this is a game based on narrative, but other developers managed to create narrative games without recurring to such strict storytelling (for instance, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter).* Looks like the developers tried too hard to make the game “PG-13”. The NPCs don’t do anything interesting. You never see them doing anything out of the ordinary (unless you find a ghost. Apparently everyone who is naughty ends up dead too). It’s like the whole town of Salem is composed of boy scouts.Other than that the game is fun. I hope to see a sequel that will address the abovementioned flaws. There’s a lot of potential for a series.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												As the game begins we find Ronan exploding out of a shattered 4th story window after a confrontation with a shadowy figure.  He awakens to find himself temporarily disembodied but that state soon becomes permanent upon the arrival of the Bell Witch Killer.  Shot 7 times with his own gun, Ronan must now solve the mystery of his own murder and in the process uncover dark secrets that have haunted Salem for centuries.Quite a build up eh?It is and it's worthy of it.  The story is intriguing with twists, turns and dead ends to thrill any devotee of the mystery genre.  Add in a tastefully done horror component supported by an eerie backdrop of a dark and gloomy Salem complete with lost souls, haunted houses, and frightful demons.The game is gorgeous even on my creaky old gaming laptop ( circa 2008 ) and the controls simple.  You're led on a path similar to the Call of Duty campaign modes on the hunt for clues to your own murder.  On the way you'll find ample opportunity to complete side quests but be warned if like me you seek to earn all of the Steam achievements you must be methodical in your approach.  For me it took 2 playthroughs as there is no quicksave nor any way to go back once you've completed the final chapter of the game. It's a casual game but it can be maddening at times.  For one, you have no onscreen map nor any way to mark your progress toward achievements.  Meaning you'll spend a lot of time running in circles to find the way forward and backtracking for that one elusive clue.Then there's the demons.  I understand that a game in the horror genre has to have some kind of threat but they're all over the place.  It breaks the flow of the narrative and it's jarring to go from a casual detective story to a flurry of button mashing every 10 minutes.  Still, even with the more "gamey" aspects, it's still more ghost story than game which explains some of its mechanical shortcomings.  My first playthrough was simply for the sake of taking it all in.  The second was purely for my own desire to see everything and in the process earn every Steam achievement.All tolled I've spent a bit over 30 hours and enjoyed every minute of it.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Its still as amazing as ever! I had originally gotten this on my Xbox360 and it was a ton of fun. I saw it on sale during the Halloween 2015 sale and picked it up pretty cheep, considering the original price. I love ghost stories, horror, and killing demons (Diablo). This game has ghosts and demons (which you can choose to avoid or execute, depending on where you are), I found I actually had to execute them to continue at some spots further in.The game begins with Ronan falling through a window and narrating a bit, you also get to learn more about Ronan's (life/ backstory). Considering the fact that he's the main hero and the playable character thats a good thing and its also important.Gameplay is what really got really got me hooked. The town of Salem has areas for doing detective work and its freeroam in the Hub section and the areas (To an extent, its not Final Fantasy or anything, but you do get to explore). The character is always seen in the third person point of view (camera is behind the character).Interactive- You can go around and talk to certain people or listen in on their conversations. You can "investigate" and search for clues- which you'd then use to solve a case or continue on in the story. Collectables are always fun, but can be a pain to collect as they are actually hiding and not always in a typical spot. Cutscenes are interactive! You can usually choose what you want Ronan to say or ask next. Nothing major, but heck its something.Powers, well you get to do a lot of stuff later, but when you just start off you can already possess people and cats (no, seriously). You can also mind read or try to manipulate their thoughts. Story? Spoilers! You die first thing and become a ghost- woot! You're also a detective of the Salem police department. You also have to try to solve your own murder and many others. The game is great and recomendable, but I do have one problem. I had chugging/ lag while on my Xbox and was hoping that'd be fixed on the pc version. That was not the case, and I still have the same annoying chugging/ lag. Its not always while going to a different section of the Hub town, but it does happen a lot in the Hub area. It also happens in other spots, but it rarely happens in places like the graveyard or appartments. So, thats a bit of a bummer, but its still a great game.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												You're a cop, you just got killed and you have to investigate your own murder and the case of the serial killer 'The Bell', who's going around killing young women in barbaric ways and slaughtering anyone who gets in his way. You'd think being dead would put something of a cramp on your investigative abilities, but no, it seems all the best cops are the dead ones. Maybe it's because it's late at night, but everybody except you seems to be doing about as much police activity as can be accomplished by standing around rubbing their noses.You run into a teenage medium called Joy who's looking for her missing mom, and she comes in really handy for opening drawers, crossing glowing holes into hell that try and suck Ronan down, and so that Ronan's musing is cut by about 20%. The rest of the time she's a regular whiny teenager you have to play daddy wolf to and pretend you give a pooper about her mom. The game revolves around investigating crime scenes - yours and other people's - talking to the many ghosts in Salem, uncovering lost memories, being the cause of poltergeist activity and posessing people to read their minds.Occasionally to try and make you feel like there's more to the game than prodding at a crime-scene and musing over a cigarette, Demons spawn. Since they just float around on a set path looking for something to kill, and you creep up from behind to kill them, it feels very tacked on and a really crappy attempt at adding any challenge to the game.All in all, the game feels a lot like an interactive horror movie, but it's a GOOD movie, and it feels like worthwhile interaction. Voice acting and character animation of faces is great. Is it worth full-price? That's a personal thing, seeing as it's quite a short game. But if you can get it at a discount, it's definitely a worthwhile way to spend some game-time.Get it if you like: Detective games, Violent murder, Interaction, Creepiness, A good movie, Collecting stuff.Don't get it if you like: Action, Challenge, Long games.7/10

												I was really surprised with this little gem. It wasn't the most amazing game I'd ever play but it was unique for its genre. Square Enix does a good job of finding games that aren't like every other game you find. The story was good, I liked the characters, the collectables are good. Just remember that if your going for 100% guide then don't forget to get to use a collecable walkthrough for the museum level as you can't redo that level. I almost went for all the collectables but decided against it at the end. I like the mystery elements mixed with the ghost side. The combat system was a bit dull but at least it doesn't affect the game as a whole. The mystery could have been better but the ambience of the whole thing was still good. All in all, a good game for the 4 bucks I spent on it.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I can't recommend this. I don't mean to diminish the efforts of those who worked on this game. I want to acknowledge it, clearly a good bit of work was put into this game, but in the end if someone was to ask me "Should I spend my money and time on this game?" I would have to say no.GraphicsReally great. The models and textures are finely detailed. The environments are beautiful and cluttered, as they should be. You can really have a lot of freedom when your character doesn't care about most collision. Only one texture stood out to me as bad: the police badges. It was sort of distracting when it was right in the camera sometimes. The engine runs beautifully as well, I was able to turn everything to its absolute maximum and run with only a few hitches, even with the anti-aliasing at x16 and HBAO at high definition. I don't think I've had any other game run so well with similar graphical settings.What really confused me was the pre-rendered cutscenes, they were everywhere! This game probably would have been a couple gigabytes smaller without all the unnecessary pre-renders. I don't know if it was for consoles or something, but they never did anything in the cutscenes that they didn't also do in live render. The most baffling cutscenes were the dialogue trees where characters would just sit in their idle animations waiting for me to select something, then pop into a pre-render. They were actually rendered at worse settings then encoded with Bink Video, resulting in a pixelly mess that just made me confused and annoyed.Sound designVery good with some few nitpicks. Stumbling into the little spirit traps on the ground makes an annoyingly loud orchestral sting, which isn't really necessary when Ronan's gasping in terror and the screen is doing everything it can to make me feel attacked. There was a weird bug where sometimes cutscenes wouldn't have audio until I restarted. Overall however, the ambient music was subtle yet evocative.StoryWell-paced and keeps you interested. Unfortunately it's kind of short. It's not that it needed to be any longer, I felt it wasn't rushed at all. The main characters are well written and voice-acted and the random citizens are well voice-acted, but the stories you unlock for collecting all the things are not so good. It was sort of a letdown after running all over the place, only to be rewarded with the actors sighing and pausing and "ohh what a terrible experience" when somehow they all sound like the same person being told how to be scared rather than feeling it.GameplayThis is a large part of why I can't recommend this. It's a murder mystery where you run around collecting clues at various scenes and putting them together to come to conclusions, but it wasn't done all that well, really. I felt quite often that a clue I had to pick didn't really make any sense, because I HAD to pick three or I apparently couldn't come to a conclusion. Sometimes I knew what the game wanted, but was able to pick out several other clues that could lead me to the same conclusion, that I could see people picking and being annoyed that they got it wrong. Sometimes the conclusion didn't make any sense. Are you sure she's being taken to that gallows in particular? Salem, Masseschussetts has no other gallows sitting around? All the other murder scenes were improvised and scattered everywhere, it didn't have to be right there and it didn't have to be a hanging anyway.There's no real consequence to being wrong except that you don't get "three out of three badges". Frankly, I wish there was just no consequence at all. The game doesn't need to tell me that I have to solve the murder, I know I have to solve the murder because I'm invested in the character and I care about the story. The annoyance of the game telling me I'm not perfect at its flawed system really dragged me out of the investigations. The only real consequence happens at the very end of the game in a terrible timed sequence that isn't really timed anyway because it pauses while you make your selection.CombatOkay, but ultimately pointless. Demons float around on limited paths and you have to execute them from behind. They can't see you through walls, but you can see them through anything. If they see you, they'll start sucking out your essence which works through walls, even walls that you can't normally walk through. It doesn't even matter if you get really far away from them, you'll die. However, sometimes I could break the drain for seemingly no reason by running through a bunch of walls or going down stairs. What you're supposed to do is hide, but that system sucks because the demons just go straight to the spot you're in, despite "not being able to see you". If you don't move to another one, they'll push you out and then your camera will probably get stuck in them, so you can't hide again. If you are able to, they'll immediately go back to searching for you even though they just saw what you did.That ended up being kind of a mess, but that's the whole logic of the combat in this game. It makes zero sense. They can't see you when you're behind a wall, hiding, or just more than ten feet from them, but they can ALWAYS see you if they're draining you, but not if you hide, even if you were just about to die and they're two feet from you. Other demons won't notice you killing their "friends". Ronan instantly knows how to kill them even though he can't do things as basic as teleportation (which he also instantly learns when he decides to 'figure it out') and it doesn't seem remarkable that he's able to kill them with ease, even though everyone else is scared of them. So basically, it was slapped into the game to pad the length and fill out the environments.AnimationGet a facial animator! Please for the love of God get a facial animator, Squenix! Every game that you make is played by terrible over-body-animated mannequins! I wish I was exaggerating! The models are great, but the fact that they rarely move their eyes, eyebrows, nose, cheeks or even lips to do anything that isn't lipsyncing is so frustrating. A few scenes had me watching the characters' backs while they talked, which was really immersive. The good acting, writing, sound design and rendering, all of it worked together, just to be ripped apart when I saw their faces.The endingLiterally every resolution in the ending happens offscreen. Deadlines, budget cuts. I don't know. Joy gets her own self out of the noose and bindings somehow, despite that these are devices made to require someone else's help. Rex is fine but we never see him get up or say a word about literally being possessed. He's not accused of anything and nobody thinks that this is strange. The two officers that were forced to murder-suicide are never mentioned, not that they should have known he was there, and also it was only the two of them and no backup for the freakin' Bell Killer, who's been known to have superhuman strength and abilities. Joy meets her mother, but we never see more than the back of her leg and hand after she's the centerpiece of the plot. Baxter is ignored. Ronan gets his peace but we don't even get to see Julia again. There is no mention of the resolution to the Bell Killer case. The ending is all of thirty seconds long, but they're more than happy to force you to sit through the credits for five minutes.In the end it's just a letdown of an experience, even if it is pretty.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Playing Murdered: Soul Suspect is akin to watching a tugboat wreck into a freight train.  It shouldn't be happening, it's the most ludicrous scenario you could possibly imagine but somehow you just have to watch the tragedy.  This game is FAR from perfect and a once n' doner.  IMO it's absolutely not worth the 29.99 price tag and I find it hard to believe it was going for over $50 for quite sometime.  I got much more value from budget games like Curse: Eye of Isis or Hard Reset than I did from this disasterpiece, yet Soul Suspect is enjoyable and I couldn't seem to put it down for the 8 and a half hours it took me to reach my goal.  I think the game performed so poorly with professional reviewers because it's simply not what you expect.  At heart, the game is like an old school point and click, detective adventure with some demonic combat and fetch quests thrown in.  In the game you play as Ronan O'Connor; a sleuth murdered at the hands of the Bell Killer...a sort of Jack the Ripper type serial killer stalking the infamous town of Salem.  The plot of the game is interesting if not somewhat predictable, mish-mashing together a bit of ideas from film (Seven, Silence of the Lambs) with the hard-boiled whodunnit atmosphere of LA Noire.  Some of the plot twists you can see from a mile away, but there's some that were at least somewhat of a surprise.  The story is told at a brisk place with cut scenes between present and past (the Salem Witch Trials) with the voice acting being strong enough to keep you involved and invested.  Ronan is voiced well enough, but sometimes the writing is a little untentionally cheesy.   Thankfully, in the context of a hard-boiled, noir style mystery it works and causes a chuckle or two without being too too flat.  Gameplay/atmosphere wise you run around the town of Salem which is setup as a mini-sandbox.  If Airtight Games had more time and money to put into the project, one could only wonder just how amazing this game could have been.  You can't enter alot of the buildings, leaving you to run around between finding various collectibles, taking on a scant few side quests and finally going to one of the city's main locations for the main action.  The graphical detail isn't overly impressive, but it's solid with decent characer models, appropriately dingy gothic design and some cool locales to explore.  Animation is stiff, the framerate is sometimes choppy and sometimes the items you need to collect will glitch in and out of existence making it a royal s.o.b. to pick them up.  The voice-acting as stated earlier was well-done although the ambient effects (besides the sinister demons you take on in stealth combat) aren't anything particularly special.  The gameplay slides between sleuthing, stealth action, fetching and exploration.  You'll come across numerous crime scenes and points of interests where your main goal is to search, examine and interrogate for clues.  Everything plays out like a stripped-down, beginner's version of L.A. Noire.  Sometimes your ghostly abilities will come into play such as possession to get inside people's heads, teleportation to get where you need to go, passing through walls, etc.  Initially, the gameplay is fun but as the game progresses you can see how basic it is.  You shouldn't need a walkthrough at all for this sucker because everything is laid out just how you need.  Once you've collected enough clues you can solve the crime scene by selecting the appropriate hints and picking the order of their importance.  It's a shame that your'e a ghost with such cool abilities but they feel second nature.  You will not be punished, nor will anything change even if you screw things up.  The game is linear to a fault.  Yet, these sequences are enjoyable enough in an old school point n' click style that it's fun.  If you can think past how the game always seems to cramp and rope you into doing what it wants you to, you'll be interested in how solving each puzzle advances the story.  To break things up you'll get the chance to possess a cat and use it to explore hard to reach areas.  The other main shake of the gameplay is stealth combat where you take on floating demons that look like monstrosities culled from Clive Barker's Undying.  They are actually pretty creepy in the way that they scream and hunt you down if they spot Ronan.  The only way to kill them is to engage them from behind, entering a quicktime button combo that will take 'em out.  Once alerted they can be tough to escape as your only means of protection is to hide in spiritual residue left behind from poltergeists.  You can jump from one residue host to another, leading to a cat n' mouse game where you try to get the upper hand on the beasties.  It's a fun addition to the gameplay variety but like most things in Soul Suspect it's awkward and feels undercooked.  By far one of the most enjoyable parts of the game were the sidequests, where you help dwelling spirits find out the manner in which they died.  These murders have somewhat of an emotional, human element to them (as stated by a few reviewers) that makes you want to help the poor schleps get some eternal rest.  Each quest is set up as a mini-mystery where you canvas a crime scene and put the clues together.  The only problem is that there's about 5 of them total.  If more were added it would have been a great thing.  Once again this represents just how much of a missed-opportunity Soul Suspect is across the board.  For those after Steam Achievements there's a ton of stuff to collect, but some of it's level specific, so if you miss it...too bad.  You have to start the game over again from square one and give it another shot.  Maybe some of you will but I sure won't.  I got 73% on a first try and I nodded afterwards saying to myself, "Good enough, good enough."  It would have been cool if you could start the game over as a new game plus.  I started it over briefly and it seemed to reset everything.  From a technical standpoint things aren't perfect either.  The game ran fairly smooth most of the time but several drops in framerate got me killed by demons about 2 or 3 times, I had about 4 game freeze crashes and I also got the end of cemetery level glitch.  None of these are game breaking, so you can get through them without losing too much progress.  To break it down:Pros:-Salem is a killer game setting.  -Involving storyline with great atmosphere-Fun mix of sleuthing, adventure, stealth combat and pick a path gameplay-Side quests and collectibles are a plus-Strong voice acting-Decent graphics and soundCons:-Pseudo sandbox gameplay is too linear-Easy puzzles and difficulty-Cool ghost powers but all of 'em are quite restricted-No branching paths for messing up the detective gameplay-Can't carry over collectibles that I saw-Some minor annoying glitches-Undercooked combat-Once you beat it, there's really no reason to go backThough I have alot of qualms about what Soul Suspect coulda been, what's there is worth playing through once.  Somehow for all of its flaws, there's a charming veneer lurking behind the game's black tooth smile.  The story in and of itself makes it worth a playthrough.  Whether you'll want to pick it up a second time is going to be an iffy, p2p decision.  I'd say this game is worth no more than $15 if you're going to pick it up.  I got it on a holiday sale for a few bucks and it more than exceeded my expectations in terms of value.  I'm pretty sure I paid $5 and could have seen paying as much as $15 for it.  But for $30?  No way Jose!    Final score:  7/10

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												Quick Summary: Murdered Soul Suspect is a mystery game more than an action game, so if you’re looking for a shooter or platformer, you won’t find much of that here. I haven’t really played many mystery games so the closest that I can compare this game to is the “investigation” portions of the Batman Arkham series, where you’re in a room with crime scenes trying to piece together what happened. The game has a ton of collectibles, both quest related, and for background on the story, making the experience immersive and decently long if you actually stop to read everything.You play a police detective named Ronan, killed during an investigation into the “Bell Killer,” a serial killer terrorizing the town of Salem. Yes, it’s the Salem with the Witch trials from hundreds of years ago, and the history of the town will play into your investigation. You’re not alone on your quest though, since a local “medium” who can see ghosts such as yourself, has her own investigation to follow and it happens to coincide with yours. Good thing too, since being a murder victim means you can’t interact with most of the living world.As a ghost, Ronan has access to certain powers such as the ability to move through solid objects, “possess” random people (you don’t really control them), “reveal” memory remnants, and later on you can teleport short distances.  The game is played in third person perspective with a lot of narration by Ronan, giving it a sort of noir feel (reminds me of Alan Wake, but with no shooting). The town of Salem is pretty small in this game, and despite being a ghost, a lot of areas are off limits to you because of walls and buildings being “consecrated.” There are 2 worlds that you can see at the same time, the real world (that you can walk through objects in) and a ghost world (mostly walls and objects that block your movement). The town is also littered with ghosts other than yourself that you can talk to. Some of them have mini quests (investigations) that you can take part in, but most of them are just there for short conversations, adding to the game’s atmosphere. I actually stopped talking to random ghosts about 1/3 into the game since most of them don’t have anything story related to tell you.As I mentioned before, this is not an action game so you don’t really fight anyone, however there are a number of “demons” roaming the town in story related areas. You can either avoid the demons by stealthily sneaking around, or you can try to banish them by sneaking up behind them and executing a quick time event. You can see the demons through walls, so it’s possible to get around them if you have ninja hiding skills. Frankly, I suggest banishing them all so you can roam freely and pick up all the collectibles in each area. Pros:+A decent, slow paced mystery story with some twists and turns. You’re playing this game for the story more than anything else.+The investigations are kind of fun, searching for clues and piecing together events after you’ve gotten the hang of it.Cons:-If you’re mostly into shooting games, you may find yourself bored. There’re some stealth sections, but the majority of the game is puzzle solving and searching for clues.-The game uses an autosave system that isn’t very well explained.  There are times where it shows the “saving” icon, but if you quit and reload you’ll be missing a bunch of progress/clues.  I recommend completing side quests separate from main story sections (don’t go back and forth between side quest and main quest) and then move on to the story section. The only time I could be sure the game had saved was when I entered a new area in the story.Overall, I’d recommend this game if you’re looking for a moderately easy “thinker” game, and are taking a break from action/shooting. If you’re just going through the main investigations of the story and not bothering with side missions or collectibles, you can probably finish in about 7 hours.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Rating: 7.5/10Short thoughts:Overall, I very much enjoyed playing Murdered: Soul Suspect and would definitely recommend it for those who are looking for a cool story about a ghost detective in the town of Salem looking to crack the case of his own murder. Longer thoughts:The story is based around a murdered detective named Ronan who is a pretty cool and has the outfit to match (and never ending cigarette). Ronan travels around the town of Salem investigating his own murder case as well as those of other townsfolk. Main story was enjoyable, as well as the side mini-stories fueled by the collection of 'evidence' around the town. The ghost aspect was neat, as you could walk through walls, possess people and animals, influence their thoughts and more of that nature. Could have used some variety in the options of interacting with NPCs, but I didn't mind it much. The game has a simple combat system which I found to work out great in the end as it allowed you to continue focusing on the story rather than get distracted and spending hours sneaking by monsters as some other games have you do. In the end, I am very satisfied with how this game played out and do not regret purchasing it one bit. However, I would not recommend purchasing this at full price (~$30), but if it can be found on sale below that, I would definitely suggest picking it up.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Spent 14 hours to finish this game and get almost all of the collectibles, except the Ghost Girl Messages because they were hard to find and I was too lazy to backtrack and find them all. So here's my take on the game.Gameplay:Many people compare this with L.A. Noire but I think the two games are vastly different. This game leans more towards an adventure game, if I have to find another game to compare it with, this game is pretty close in concept to the Blackwell Series (which is awesome, go grab it) in that the game asks you to solve a murder mistery and also help other spirits move on by helping them to know why they died and resolve their situation. In a way, it's almost a 3D version of the Blackwell series, with the emphasis on adventure, finding clues and solving puzzles.Some people complained that the stealth action parts of this game (exorcising demons) are too difficult and annoying. I think it's not that difficult, but if you DO find it hard and it breaks the game for you, there's a simple cheat/patch out there that you can use to completely nullify the stealth action parts and turn it entirely into an adventure game, which might help make this game infinitely better for you.Story:Personally, I think the story is the main strong point of this game. As a lover of classic supernatural adventure games, such as the Gabriel Knight series, this IS the game for me. I also love games that are based on history or cult stories (such as the Assassin's Creed series), and knowing that this game mixed some real history (the Salem witch trials) to the plot just makes it more immersive for me. There is even one character from the Salem witch trials history that appears here, which might surprise some that are in the know of this story.But as with any story out there, like when watching a movie or reading a book, this section is entirely subjective and either you like it or you don't. If you find out that you don't like the premise, then you have no reason to play this game at all, as there is nothing else to find here if you dislike the story. It will quickly get boring for you.Graphics:Played this game on my ASUS laptop with GeForce GT650M 2GB DDR3 graphics and the game runs fine on mostly high settings (see the screenshot I posted of this game for more details) with no stuttering framerates or slowdowns. The graphic quality is awesome and totally realistic, from the facial expressions of the characters to the textures and clothings. Ronan, especially, is rendered with truly amazing detail, I was a bit speechless when I saw his semi-transparent ultra-detailed character model during the opening moments. If you have a decent graphics card, this game can render truly amazing details for your enjoyment.Sound:Voice acting is very good, especially for the lead character Ronan. The music and ambient sounds successfully brings out the haunting and crreepy atmosphere of the story. The sound effect is carefully designed to great effect, especially the shrieks of those demons which can literally get you jumping out of your seat if you're playing with headphones on during the middle of the night.Weakness:There is no in-game map. But the town of Salem is not that large and pretty soon you will be able to get your bearings around town by memory alone. The only difficult route to remember was probably the one that leads to the church, because you need to take a specific route to get there. If you're worried about getting all the collectibles, there are a lot of guides and videos out there that can help you, so you don't have to worry about that at all.Verdict:7.0 - A must buy for mystery/murder/detective adventure game lovers out there, especially those who loved the Gabriel Knight or the Blackwell series.TIP: Don't buy it with the full price. This game often goes on sale, so better wait for it to go on sale and grab it. I got it for just $3.99 during the most recent Square Enix sale.TIP #2: Play with a game controller, not with a keyboard and mouse. It will make a whole lot of difference and can make or break the game for some people.
