												Playing Murdered: Soul Suspect is akin to watching a tugboat wreck into a freight train.  It shouldn't be happening, it's the most ludicrous scenario you could possibly imagine but somehow you just have to watch the tragedy.  This game is FAR from perfect and a once n' doner.  IMO it's absolutely not worth the 29.99 price tag and I find it hard to believe it was going for over $50 for quite sometime.  I got much more value from budget games like Curse: Eye of Isis or Hard Reset than I did from this disasterpiece, yet Soul Suspect is enjoyable and I couldn't seem to put it down for the 8 and a half hours it took me to reach my goal.  I think the game performed so poorly with professional reviewers because it's simply not what you expect.  At heart, the game is like an old school point and click, detective adventure with some demonic combat and fetch quests thrown in.  In the game you play as Ronan O'Connor; a sleuth murdered at the hands of the Bell Killer...a sort of Jack the Ripper type serial killer stalking the infamous town of Salem.  The plot of the game is interesting if not somewhat predictable, mish-mashing together a bit of ideas from film (Seven, Silence of the Lambs) with the hard-boiled whodunnit atmosphere of LA Noire.  Some of the plot twists you can see from a mile away, but there's some that were at least somewhat of a surprise.  The story is told at a brisk place with cut scenes between present and past (the Salem Witch Trials) with the voice acting being strong enough to keep you involved and invested.  Ronan is voiced well enough, but sometimes the writing is a little untentionally cheesy.   Thankfully, in the context of a hard-boiled, noir style mystery it works and causes a chuckle or two without being too too flat.  Gameplay/atmosphere wise you run around the town of Salem which is setup as a mini-sandbox.  If Airtight Games had more time and money to put into the project, one could only wonder just how amazing this game could have been.  You can't enter alot of the buildings, leaving you to run around between finding various collectibles, taking on a scant few side quests and finally going to one of the city's main locations for the main action.  The graphical detail isn't overly impressive, but it's solid with decent characer models, appropriately dingy gothic design and some cool locales to explore.  Animation is stiff, the framerate is sometimes choppy and sometimes the items you need to collect will glitch in and out of existence making it a royal s.o.b. to pick them up.  The voice-acting as stated earlier was well-done although the ambient effects (besides the sinister demons you take on in stealth combat) aren't anything particularly special.  The gameplay slides between sleuthing, stealth action, fetching and exploration.  You'll come across numerous crime scenes and points of interests where your main goal is to search, examine and interrogate for clues.  Everything plays out like a stripped-down, beginner's version of L.A. Noire.  Sometimes your ghostly abilities will come into play such as possession to get inside people's heads, teleportation to get where you need to go, passing through walls, etc.  Initially, the gameplay is fun but as the game progresses you can see how basic it is.  You shouldn't need a walkthrough at all for this sucker because everything is laid out just how you need.  Once you've collected enough clues you can solve the crime scene by selecting the appropriate hints and picking the order of their importance.  It's a shame that your'e a ghost with such cool abilities but they feel second nature.  You will not be punished, nor will anything change even if you screw things up.  The game is linear to a fault.  Yet, these sequences are enjoyable enough in an old school point n' click style that it's fun.  If you can think past how the game always seems to cramp and rope you into doing what it wants you to, you'll be interested in how solving each puzzle advances the story.  To break things up you'll get the chance to possess a cat and use it to explore hard to reach areas.  The other main shake of the gameplay is stealth combat where you take on floating demons that look like monstrosities culled from Clive Barker's Undying.  They are actually pretty creepy in the way that they scream and hunt you down if they spot Ronan.  The only way to kill them is to engage them from behind, entering a quicktime button combo that will take 'em out.  Once alerted they can be tough to escape as your only means of protection is to hide in spiritual residue left behind from poltergeists.  You can jump from one residue host to another, leading to a cat n' mouse game where you try to get the upper hand on the beasties.  It's a fun addition to the gameplay variety but like most things in Soul Suspect it's awkward and feels undercooked.  By far one of the most enjoyable parts of the game were the sidequests, where you help dwelling spirits find out the manner in which they died.  These murders have somewhat of an emotional, human element to them (as stated by a few reviewers) that makes you want to help the poor schleps get some eternal rest.  Each quest is set up as a mini-mystery where you canvas a crime scene and put the clues together.  The only problem is that there's about 5 of them total.  If more were added it would have been a great thing.  Once again this represents just how much of a missed-opportunity Soul Suspect is across the board.  For those after Steam Achievements there's a ton of stuff to collect, but some of it's level specific, so if you miss it...too bad.  You have to start the game over again from square one and give it another shot.  Maybe some of you will but I sure won't.  I got 73% on a first try and I nodded afterwards saying to myself, "Good enough, good enough."  It would have been cool if you could start the game over as a new game plus.  I started it over briefly and it seemed to reset everything.  From a technical standpoint things aren't perfect either.  The game ran fairly smooth most of the time but several drops in framerate got me killed by demons about 2 or 3 times, I had about 4 game freeze crashes and I also got the end of cemetery level glitch.  None of these are game breaking, so you can get through them without losing too much progress.  To break it down:Pros:-Salem is a killer game setting.  -Involving storyline with great atmosphere-Fun mix of sleuthing, adventure, stealth combat and pick a path gameplay-Side quests and collectibles are a plus-Strong voice acting-Decent graphics and soundCons:-Pseudo sandbox gameplay is too linear-Easy puzzles and difficulty-Cool ghost powers but all of 'em are quite restricted-No branching paths for messing up the detective gameplay-Can't carry over collectibles that I saw-Some minor annoying glitches-Undercooked combat-Once you beat it, there's really no reason to go backThough I have alot of qualms about what Soul Suspect coulda been, what's there is worth playing through once.  Somehow for all of its flaws, there's a charming veneer lurking behind the game's black tooth smile.  The story in and of itself makes it worth a playthrough.  Whether you'll want to pick it up a second time is going to be an iffy, p2p decision.  I'd say this game is worth no more than $15 if you're going to pick it up.  I got it on a holiday sale for a few bucks and it more than exceeded my expectations in terms of value.  I'm pretty sure I paid $5 and could have seen paying as much as $15 for it.  But for $30?  No way Jose!    Final score:  7/10

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												Quick Summary: Murdered Soul Suspect is a mystery game more than an action game, so if you’re looking for a shooter or platformer, you won’t find much of that here. I haven’t really played many mystery games so the closest that I can compare this game to is the “investigation” portions of the Batman Arkham series, where you’re in a room with crime scenes trying to piece together what happened. The game has a ton of collectibles, both quest related, and for background on the story, making the experience immersive and decently long if you actually stop to read everything.You play a police detective named Ronan, killed during an investigation into the “Bell Killer,” a serial killer terrorizing the town of Salem. Yes, it’s the Salem with the Witch trials from hundreds of years ago, and the history of the town will play into your investigation. You’re not alone on your quest though, since a local “medium” who can see ghosts such as yourself, has her own investigation to follow and it happens to coincide with yours. Good thing too, since being a murder victim means you can’t interact with most of the living world.As a ghost, Ronan has access to certain powers such as the ability to move through solid objects, “possess” random people (you don’t really control them), “reveal” memory remnants, and later on you can teleport short distances.  The game is played in third person perspective with a lot of narration by Ronan, giving it a sort of noir feel (reminds me of Alan Wake, but with no shooting). The town of Salem is pretty small in this game, and despite being a ghost, a lot of areas are off limits to you because of walls and buildings being “consecrated.” There are 2 worlds that you can see at the same time, the real world (that you can walk through objects in) and a ghost world (mostly walls and objects that block your movement). The town is also littered with ghosts other than yourself that you can talk to. Some of them have mini quests (investigations) that you can take part in, but most of them are just there for short conversations, adding to the game’s atmosphere. I actually stopped talking to random ghosts about 1/3 into the game since most of them don’t have anything story related to tell you.As I mentioned before, this is not an action game so you don’t really fight anyone, however there are a number of “demons” roaming the town in story related areas. You can either avoid the demons by stealthily sneaking around, or you can try to banish them by sneaking up behind them and executing a quick time event. You can see the demons through walls, so it’s possible to get around them if you have ninja hiding skills. Frankly, I suggest banishing them all so you can roam freely and pick up all the collectibles in each area. Pros:+A decent, slow paced mystery story with some twists and turns. You’re playing this game for the story more than anything else.+The investigations are kind of fun, searching for clues and piecing together events after you’ve gotten the hang of it.Cons:-If you’re mostly into shooting games, you may find yourself bored. There’re some stealth sections, but the majority of the game is puzzle solving and searching for clues.-The game uses an autosave system that isn’t very well explained.  There are times where it shows the “saving” icon, but if you quit and reload you’ll be missing a bunch of progress/clues.  I recommend completing side quests separate from main story sections (don’t go back and forth between side quest and main quest) and then move on to the story section. The only time I could be sure the game had saved was when I entered a new area in the story.Overall, I’d recommend this game if you’re looking for a moderately easy “thinker” game, and are taking a break from action/shooting. If you’re just going through the main investigations of the story and not bothering with side missions or collectibles, you can probably finish in about 7 hours.

												Murdered Soul SuspectAfter finishing it , i would recommend it , if you like adventure games and if you can get it cheap (this part is getting frequent lately on my judgement of a game) . For 20 i did feel i got my money's worth although it could have been better.I would say maybe in a sequel but i don’t think there will be one :)

												I thoroughly enjoyed Murdered, I felt that the story was gripping, and the characters intriguing, and get this: a likeable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a main character! In other words, he is your archetypical d-bag with a sense of justice, but he is very intriguing, you’ll find out more about that as you play the game, since I don’t want to spoil anything, even minor details….I will say that the “combat” is the weakest part of the game, but thankfully those are generally few and far in between, all it is, is a twist on cover based stealth system that is quite frankly very annoying and frustrating to say the least.But by far the strongest point of the game is the investigation scenes, during which, you find clues and develop several inferences, thankfully the game doesn’t really hold your hand much in the way the Sherlock Holmes game does.To keep this short, I do recommend the game, it isn’t perfect and certainly isn’t worth the asking price of 40-50 bucks, as the length leaves something to be desired.... I do encourage you to pick the game up if you happen to see it on sale for <$20Happy Gaming :D

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Plus Points:* Great initial atmosphere with an interesting plot* Cat possession is very fun* Salem looks good through a ghosts eyes* Demons look great but rarely interesting encounters* Some inventive puzzle solving* Decent conclusionMinus Points:* Sandbox world quickly feels very linier and confined* Side missions are item hunts within a few feet* Bonus story item hunts are boring and unrewarding* Creepy tone lessens as things progress* Demons are mindless padding, just to lengthen the campaign* Mind reading and possession aren't useful or interesting* Detective work is underwhelming* Short 7-8 Hours with little replay valueLike a supernatural LA Noire with a shorter and more confined world. Since progressing the story is all important the game's not particularly difficult or expansive.Recommended for: Stealth/Crime buffs with a liking for story over mechanics.Conclusion: 7/10. Not as bad as many would have you believe and worth your time for a few quid then move on.

Noire, as this is a completely different game.The story is not so bad (not very good either), but generally it feels like the devs had bigger plans for the gameplay but the outcome was the same as usual ;)The biggest cons: demons feel a bit out of place gameplay-wise, mind reading is totally useless and all investigations could be concluded by brute force guessing.The biggest pro: you can possess a cat :)All in all: if you want to buy this game, then go ahead but I strongly suggest that you wait for a sale, as normal price is too high.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												I had my worries of the game especially considering how multiple gaming review sites just loved to tear it a new one. I found however a particular repeating element and pattern that struck me the wrong way in most of them. The major complaints often revolve around repetition and easy difficulty structure. The learning curve is rather flat while taking the time to solve mysteries and crimes is often called child's play at that. I hate to use this term but it just feels so rather Meta in the face of the pace the game seems to give off. Salem just looks so ghostly inviting and everywhere has the potential for you to take the time and admire the lives of the still living. At the same time it just doesn't feel like a burden to get to the next part of the story and become all the more curious of the world around you. Even the collectables have merit in the stories they tell. It just seems that a great number of people expected a rather explosive and mind bending experience. Murdered: Soul Suspect is like a brisk walk through the undead and spiritual park. It's a pleasant walk. It has a great way of not stifling the flow it has set up and the characters you come to find along the way give a curious nuance to the atmosphere. Would I say the game is flawless or addictive? No, I do not believe it is an extreme grabber that you can't let go of. It's more like that book you've been wanting to read for awhile and you just finally got down to reading it. Take your time, appreciate the attention to details, and you'll feel all the more rewarded for the investment. If you're more set on something more fast paced and hectic then perhaps another title may be up your alley.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Well, a lot of what you've heard about this game is true. There is a lot of clunk to its port (the menu has no mouse support and doesn't even use arrow keys). The "combat" amounts to a random key press alongside a random mouse button click. And the mystery isn't that complex. So why am I recommending it, you ask? Because it never lost my attention. Between the atmosphere, the unlockable ghost stories, and the main case (albeit not Sir Arthur Conan Doyle stuff) it was just a lot of fun to play. I even got into the random key sequences of excuting demons (and was a bit suprised that in the beginning my nerves would betray me and I'd fail at times). It was Airtight's swan song, and you can almost feel it in there what with the brevity and all, but it is a nice tune for those seeking an atmospheric haunted noire vibe. Definitely not for everyone, but much better than the critics have given it credit for, that's for sure.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												This is a great game for those who like stories. It is very cinematic and its storytelling involves the player in Ronan's story. It's more a mystery story than a horror one (even though it has some elements). I'm going to start reviewing from the negative stuff to the positive:- Not being able to change the controls in PC is a joke. This will prevent left-handed people from playing and makes the only difficult spot more difficult by choosing ridiculous key controls - That said, the game is not difficult at all (it's almost an interactive movie), though in certain spots the difficulty spikes due to the controls- There's plenty of reading if you want to know the whole stories that make the side quests, but there's a bug in the game: if you want to read the stories of the items on the menu, press Enter, not the mouse- There's plenty of stuff to do and to collect in the city and you have almost complete freedom to move around. Still I'd have liked the option of finishing the side quests before ending the game.- The game design works great to make you feel like a ghost. I soon realised that even though I was dead I still tended to try to walk through doors instead of walls"- The experience is great.Oh, and as someone said, you can posses cats. And meow.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												I was very interested in a game where you play as a ghost detective solving your own murder, which made me jump on a preorder. I don't regret my decision, but it wasn't really what I expected.It's a third person Unreal Engine game, which you've probably played a million times before. What's special about this game is that it's more about solving murders and gathering clues than hiding behind cover and shooting at aliens. Also, you're a freaking ghost. You can phase through walls, possess NPCs to read their thoughts or influence them, talk to other ghosts and stuff like that. You're a little limited in what you can do, but it's still a novel twist.For the most part you're just walking around, picking up collectibles and looking at clues. Fair enough. I don't need complicated gameplay systems to enjoy my games. But what about puzzles? Detective work other than "look at X"? Challenges?The game doesn't have much of that, and this is where it suffers. It tries to mix things up here and there with some ghost powers and some demons you have to get rid of, but it's not much. I'm guessing a lot was cut during development, to the point where the gameplay feels underdeveloped, or like this game would work better as a point-and-click adventure game or something more like an interactive movie. My thirst for collectibles (of which there are a lot in this game) and the well-paced story was what kept me going through most of the game.You're not the first to be murdered by this Bell Killer guy, so you're sent on a chase that takes you to different locations to uncover more connections. The game has a pretty big arsenal of cutscenes that are generally well-produced. It was easy to get invested and want to see more. I lost this admiration a bit at the end when things got super cliched, but I know that for the majority of the game I was really enjoying the way the game was headed and happily followed where it wanted me to go. You really need this when the gameplay itself doesn't provide much challenge. The main story is fleshed out with collectibles that relate to the town of Salem (this game is set in Salem, speaking of cliches) and to the relationship between you and other characters including your recently deceased wife (very cute!).The well-produced story and the novel twist on third-person exploration made this game worth playing for me. The part where it's supposed to be a detective game falls flat when the gameplay systems have been either underdeveloped or just assumes that the player is a child, so keep this in mind. Still, the good outweighed the bad for me, so don't be too scared by the lackluster reception.

Posted: February 28, 2015
												By all accounts, this game should have never been made in 2014.  The market for AAA games demand experiences much different than this one.  This is a niche game, and throwing so many resources at it is a terrible, terrible business decision.The game has almost no combat, and is driven by dialogue, information gathering, and narrative.That said, I am writing this after just completing it, with a huge grin on my face.  The story in this game is STELLAR.  It evokes the slower pacing and murder mystery elements of games like the Blackwell franchise and LA Noire.  It's also compounded with supernatural elements and a heavy influence from the Salem Witch Trials.At it's heart, it's a murder mystery (your own, in fact.)  But once it starts unfolding, there is an incredible narrative to be experienced, one I highly recommend, if you don't mind slow pacing in video games.I can't recommend this to everyone, but if you love a good mystery, and prefer dialogue to gunplay, then I cannot recommend this game enough.  Like I said, it's a niche game, and if you fall into that niche, then please, please, play this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												It has been awhile since I’ve played an adventure game. An honest to god adventure game, where you play the character to pass a few simple puzzles to unlock the next part of the story. And Murdered: Soul Suspect developed by Airtight Games scratches that itch. Albeit it does have its flaws.Lets get the basics out of the way, you play a cop by the name of Ronan and in the first seconds of the game you get to see your character die. But unlike a lot of games this isn’t the end, because you become a ghost. Who in order to move on has to find out who murdered him. That’s the basic plot of the game, and the main story line. And so you will spend roughly 8-12 hours going through all of Salem’s locations hunting down the clues to discover your murder. Along the way you’ll befriend some people and learn some very unsettling secrets about the town.While the story isn’t the most complicated or even the best it still is written and presented well enough to be enjoyable. Along with the side quest and collectibles that fill in the background details about the town and the various characters it kept me enthralled for the nine hours that I played it, but then some peoples mileage may vary. The one complaint I will have is that the developers didn’t put more background in, or even more interesting stuff. As in very early in the game you help a young girl discover what happened to her and why she was dead, you barely ever come close to that type of detail again. And that is sad because of this the background environment in terms of engagement is inconsistent, because at one end you find a piece of the map full of history and maybe a doctor who was performing experiments on his patients then at the other end you have a boring area that you have to navigate constantly to get to other locations in the game.  Seriously it gets tedious having to run the same gauntlet over and over again, with nothing changed just the same old Salem with the same old random NPC’s.As for the gameplay mechanics, you will have learned almost everything within the first hour of how to play this game, except for a couple of “powers” you learn later on. You’re a ghost, you can pass through physical real world barriers, except for ghost barriers and all the houses in Salem are blessed or something so you can’t get into them without there being an opening of some kind. You can manipulate real world things like tv’s, phones, and printers, but except for missions these abilities don’t rouse a response out of the people in Salem. You can possess people to hear there thoughts, which there are not many of them. You can influence them to advance the case and you can view the world through there eyes to once again advance the case. Pretty nifty thing, but only actually used in the missions and have very littler bearing on the game.And that is pretty much the sum total of the game in mechanics other than the bad guys. Which are demons and floor demons as I will call them.Just like most adventure games of the past the bad guys pose little to no challenge and are merely there to present a hurdle to bypass. For being called demons if its 1V1 I’m going to win all the time. You hide in shades wait for them to turn there backs and then rip them apart. Also you can use ravens to distract them, but ravens ain’t used a lot. As for floor demons just side step them. Graphics wise, the game is pretty good, not the prettiest in terms of background environment and the character models look a bit dated, they remind me of XCOM the Bureau, or even LA Norie, but that’s not a bad thing as those games had good graphics as well. And as with anything graphics are not everything as the recent trend in PC gaming can attest to.  So you may be asking why I seemed to be praising this game in the beginning but point out a lot of flaws in it. Well because in truth there are very few actual adventure games made by triple A developers anymore so anything coming out in this genre that isn’t a bug ridden mess, it will be enjoyed by those of us who like adventure games. Where you play a guy or women trying to unfold a story, either by solving puzzles or piecing the story together . Where you don’t have to gun down an armies worth of bad guys to move from one area to the next. Where the bad guys have to be planned around as you really have no actual defense against them. Where you know you can’t lose but hate the fact that you screw up sometimes. So for an adventure game, Murdered Soul Suspect is a fine addition, its has a fairly strong main storyline and some pretty interesting side storylines and background storylines, but as I said before could use a few more to liven the area up even more. (Maybe some DLC?)For a game it is pretty average to mediocre though, with most gameplay mechanics discovered and mastered in the first hour it leaves little advancement in that area. The NPC’s are uninteresting, the graphics compared to top of the line are dated, gameplay is pretty linear, and replayability, well to be honest there is none. I’ve played ten hours and the game will probably sit there unless I have an itch to find those 5 pieces of background info/collectibles. So final verdict? If you are a fan of adventure games and smooth easy gameplay, then Soul Suspect is the perfect game for you. But if you are new to adventure games, or expecting something different then I wouldn’t suggest this game. And even if you are a fan of the genre this will slot into, wait till it drops to under $20 for it to be worth the money.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												This is a ghost story, About a abused misunderstood criminal, who meets his soul mate and turns a new leaf on life by becoming a detective with the help of his brother-in-law, He places the story of his life in tattoos that cover his body. His wife dies and he becomes reckless, and winds up geting killed. Now hes a ghost, searching for his killer. Theres alot to do in this game, through fairly easy. you have your main story, about 7 additional ghost stories to uncover, history on salem, and many other artifacts, something like 200 Items to search for. As a ghost you get abilities as the game progresses. The game really does not punish for wrong choices except you lose your gold badge status if you mess up. Steam has achievements to earn. There are demons and demon traps so you need to be carefull where you step, or if your running from demons not to step into traps. You can kill demons by getting behind them. or you can try to avoid them. I perfer just to kill them and get them out of the way. The game is not set up so you fail, it relies on the story telling and requires you to scour areas with a fine tooth comb to unlock all the stuff thats needs to be found. Just running through the main story makes for a short game, But trying to collect everything makes a very long game. So the choice is yours. The graphics are very good, I have not found any glitches or bugs in my two play throughs, the controls are responsive. I'd recommend this game for anyone who just wants a casual interesting story to sit back and relax and play. With that in mind the critics scores on this game is unjust. It's not a 10, but more like a 7.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect was easily the biggest surprise of 2015 for me, and I think the last game that really blew away my expectations to the same extent was the psychologically assaulting trek through the sands of Spec Ops: The Line. Now of course that comparison gives Soul Suspect a lot more credit than it deserves, it’s a far from perfect game and certainly won’t be looked back on as a game design milestone. But while I expected a more or less point and click hidden object game with fancy 3D graphics and bizarrely contrived QTE’s, what I got was a decent story entwined in a fascinating and well fleshed out word with fantastic mechanics to handle action sequences.Honestly, yes. If I had to boil this game down into a single genre I would have to go with a point and click adventure. The main backbone of the game is walking from crime scene to crime scene and pressing X when you spot a clue. There is certainly nothing revolutionary about the mechanic but the content of the clues- and to a much larger extent the collectibles- brings to light a remarkably well imagined world. Now I’m not well versed in the history of Salem and the details of the witch trials, but I think the writers put in a good amount of creative effort bringing an engaging fictional story into a very real place and time. Typically the little factoids littered around the game world only appeal to completionist minded individuals like myself, however I found myself on a multitude of occasions scouring the town for that last entry to figure out the end of a story.The visuals of the game are adequate, nothing that I didn’t expect after looking at 2 or 3 screenshots. I was able to run the game mostly maxed out on my 680 and the framerate was stable and consistent.Here is the thing that made the game for me: the “final boss”. Don’t worry I will not spoil a thing, and it was actually the absence of something which made it utterly refreshing and a huge relief. Aside from a handful of action-y stealth segments with demons, the game is slow and narrative driven. As I felt the story come closer and closer to a close I got this feeling of dread. You see I know how AAA games go nowadays, every fiber of my being was expecting this dreadful quick time event unfair boss fight that has no continuity with the entire rest of the game. I was even tempted to not finish the game myself and watch the ending online because I didn’t want to walk away from such a great experience with a terrible taste in my mouth. Yet the developers NAILED it. No it’s not a spectacle and no it’s not brutally difficult, but it was satisfying and conclusive to the narrative. The amount of relief I felt at the ending was overwhelming.I’ve harped a lot on a very little point of the game, but it was a big reason this game left me with such a positive view of it. Murdered: Soul Suspect is not perfect but it’s a breath of fresh air for narrative centric games and it kept me engaged and entertained the whole way through.

Murdered: Soul Suspect Review - NihoesI know what you're thinking. Is the game a detective game? Is it like L.A Noir? These two questions are the most common asked ones, and it's a little bit like L.A Noir, but that is only because you can take choices on what to ask other dead persons. Since you're gonna meet others like you, each one of them, have their own story. You can travel into living persons mind and read them, or you can "posses" them. Not making them do things for you, but you can make them think thoughts that you kinda implant in their head, You can't make them do things for you, as like you "posses" a police officer, and then control him, nope not gonna happend.The game not only got the whole detective genre going on, but also a good old thriller.If you like mystery, thriller, action, then this is game for you. You're Ronan, a former gang member who gets tattoos for each and every 'great' memory in his life that he wants to remeber for his very own personal reason.Visit my profile to see screenshots of the game.-Nihoes

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												For those who don't want to read a wall of text; I give the game a 6.5/10The Short review:Pros+Main story pans out rather well+Collectible ghost stories are great+Unique concept+Intriguing secondary characters (pretty much everyone but Ronan)+Diverse game world+Despite the limited/focused gameplay, it did not get repetitive+No bugs/perfect performance, especially at launchCons-Very short (7hrs to 100%)-Limited side missions-Small game world by modern standards-Ronan, and the investigation system, can be really..really stupid-The facial expressions for pretty much every character in the game sucks**-Limited number of character models, despite how few ghosts you can interact with-Probably would have been received better if it was at a cheaper price**My long review was actually way too long, but the rather awkward facial expressions throughout the game are the most important part of the review that I had to cut outThe (Really) Long review:STORY 6.5/10 - Chances are, you already realize the Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure game based very heavily around a story, and that story quite often falls flat on its face in terms of portraying the sense of whodunit type mystery you would get from anything Sherlock Holmes, or from similar games such as LA Noire. The main story starts off kind of rocky, but as it pans out, and you learn to ignore the hand-holding that occurs during the investigations and some of the sillier plot points (where the game screams THIS IS IMPORTANT), it actually becomes quite intriguing. I found myself actually ruling people out as the Bell Killer, with my mind firmly set on one person from very early on in the game. To my pleasant surprise, I only partially anticipated the ending, and it wasn't something from way out in left field as you would find in an M Night Shyamalan movie. It worked (eventually).What didn't work in this game, are many of the aforementioned investigations that hold your hand throughout, often making it obscenely clear exactly what happened without ever even looking at any of the evidence at the scene. In most cases, you needed to guide Ronan to each piece of evidence (generally around 10 items), at which point he would make a remark that is often idiotic (and very often the complete opposite of what the item clearly gave me the impression of) about how it may pertain to the case, and after you have collected sufficient evidence, you would choose the items Ronan deemed important in closing the case. Since chances are you already know what happened, you would then need to find the two or three items that Ronan needed before you could move on to the more enjoyable parts of the game. This burden is frequently increased by Ronan's tendency to ignore VERY important evidence, that could immediately close the case, to focus on items that don't really help his investigation..at all. In general, what could have perhaps been the main draw for many people in this game, ended up feeling trivial and even, at times, tacked on as an after-thought. This became especially apparent when comparing the investigative stories to what was probably my favorite part of the game.Perhaps the most redeeming quality of the game in terms of story, is sadly the part of the game that most people are likely to overlook. Each area of the game has a set of collectibles that you can gather to get a better understanding the lore surrounding that part of Salem, as portrayed through a spooky ghost story. Between these and the investigations, it definitely appears that the ghost stories took a backseat in terms of time spent working on them in the production process, as they consist of a single voice actor describing a very short ghost story, while you look at a spooky picture related to the story. It sounds lame, sure, a cinematic would have made more sense, but at the same time I think it allows you to focus more on the story itself. The ability to successfully portray a spooky story with what seems to be as little effort as possible makes me wonder why this wasn't more of a horror-based adventure game, than a detective-y investigation-y game. Perhaps the most depressing part of the story is the fact that it is so short, clocking in at only 7hrs from start to finish, getting 100% of the achievements at the same time. I would have liked to see more side missions (I'd say investigations, but there wasn't really any of  that going on), and a generally longer story than the game had to offer.CHARACTERS 7.5/10 - Ronan is basically a walking cliché for a bad guy gone good guy cop who does more than just toe the line between cop and criminal when he works cases. You can pretty much ignore his character entirely for a good portion of the game as his comments tend to only point out the other flaws in the game. Joy, the teenage medium, even comes off as a rather cliché young pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but her character does evolve rather well. When it comes to characters, the game really shines with the secondary characters, such as Baxter, and some of the Bell Killer's victims that you meet along your journey, who have all interacted with the killer in one way or another, and you get to see how that experience has changed them - for better or worse. The same split between really good and really boring characters can be seen in the all-to-few number of side investigations that you can find scattered across Salem, where someone may have a problem that you offer to investigate, and inevitably fix. In the cases where the characters are lame, it is often because of the same thing the investigation part of the game suffers from, the answer being too blatantly obvious to not think that character is an idiot for not seeing it. In other cases, it is clear that the character is in a literal limbo, and they need your help getting out of it. GAMEPLAY 8/10 - First off, the game as a whole  works beautifully, both as a game being played on launch week, and a game in general, as I found no bugs of any kind while playing through the game. Chances are, part of the reason the game runs so great is because it is just so simplistic. The combat in the game is about as basic as you can get, and would most likely have become very redundant had there been more combat sequences in the game. I had only just started to get sick of dealing with demons by the time I reach the last half hour or so of gameplay. It is very clear that the focus is on story and investigating the crimes of the Bell Killer (see the story section for why that is a letdown).The world around Ronan becomes increasingly impressive, and creepy, as the frequency of ghosts increases, but in general I got a very Twilight-zone-empty-town feel from Salem, and the ghosts flat out reminded me of the Haunted Mansion ride at Disney World. Ultimately, the living people that populated Salem ended up feeling even more empty than their ghostly counterparts, which I think actually gave me an even creepier vibe from the game, although I don't think that was totally intentional.While making the world feel a bit more lively is kind of optional, since a gloomier look does make sense to me as you are playing a ghost, I think Salem definitely should have been larger than it was. By the time you reach the credits, you will have only explored just over a half dozen different parts of Salem, and the streets of (a rather small) Salem itself. Sure, the areas are diverse, consisting of everything from a Church, to a Police Station, and a Mental Hospital, but none of the areas are very large, further adding to the small-world feel of the game. On the other hand, with how tedious the combat had become by the end of the game, and how pointless the investigations were (they weren't quite tedious, but certainly would have been soon enough), I think focusing more on other aspects of the game first would have been more important than expanding the world around Ronan.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect developers have implemented completely new type of investigation games. 'What is it about?', you may ask, so the answer is below:You are local of Salem, Massachusetts, the place which is mostly associated with XVII-century's history about witches, that people were hunting at and then, after catching them, they were burned at the stake. In game, there is mystical climat exposing supernatural skills of Ronan O'Connor, the main character, who had been killed at the beginning of the game and then he transformed to a ghost, who had to face demons, solve a mystery of his death and find out, who had killed him. Ronan, while getting the 'new himself', gets new skills, which allow him to move through the walls, be invisible to people, read in people's minds and even control them! During investigation he meets some demons hunting for souls, so he needs to eliminate them, or move around the place to get safer way. The game reminds me of L.A. Noire, because you need to solve problems by getting some details and then connecting them into one, making sense trace. If you complete it successfully, you'll see what happened before.Graphic effects are nice, the gameplay is happening during the twilight, so colours are darky, but they keep you even closer, because of usage them in thrilling details around. The Unreal Engine 3 is helping the game to get high details of buildings, models and characters, as well as good animations. The last thing I want to mention about is sound - thrilling music showing overwhelming atmosphere of Salem and live comments of O'Connor's adventures, which lead us to equating with Ronan even more.Murdered: Soul Suspect and its story completely touched my heartstrings and that's one of the reasons, why my note is very high! Great compilation of story, graphics and sound is forcing me to put 10/10. Hope you enjoy!

 Murdered: Soul Suspect  Very cool game with nice storyline, interesting characters and with a lot of collectibles. We play the detective Ronan O'Connor, who was murdered and our goal is to find out who is the serial killer and the game takes place in the town of Salem. Cool title for people who like to finish the game on 100%.

content:
Posted: February 21
												I stumbled upon this game as I was checking out the Square Enix webpage because I am a huge fan of Life is Strange and wanted to see what other titles they had that may be just as interesting. I read the information on Murdered Soul Suspect and figured I'd give it a go. I am so glad that I did. This game kept me wanting to come back to it more and more. I grew fond of Ronan and wanted to see this to the end. His ghost to medium relationship with Joy kept me amused throughout the game and their conversations back and forth lifted the darkness from the game itself. The history also was interesting as it is obvious the creators researched the Salem Witch Trials as well as other newsworthy incidents in Salem, Mass. It was well thought out on how to incorporate these details into the game without it coming across as a boring history lesson. I would have loved to have seen more helping of other ghosts around town (I think there were 4 or so?). The side quest portion I really enjoyed while continuing through the main story itself. It was fun running around Salem tracking down all the collectables. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in the Salem Witch Trials, the paranormal, and who enjoys detective work. An enjoyable game!

content:
Posted: February 24
												Good premise and atmosphere, but some of the gameplay is mediocre.It's basically an interactive story point-and-click game but with a mainstream 3rd person view, some basic stealth and QTE mechanics, and a larger budget to make it more appealing to the masses. This combination of niche and mainstream works well enough, if you have modest expectations. The story is quite enjoyable, but a bit short. Voice acting is decent, and the music fits the mood well. Graphics are fairly modest on a technical level, but some environments still manage to look beautiful, and the effects look slick. While I was expecting some rough edges with gameplay, the core mystery solving mechanics also have some flaws - the answer was sometimes too obvious or seemed inconsistent or illogical. As a console port there are some issues - flawed mouse sensitivity, clunky PC controls you cannot re-bind and a prohibitive autosave system. All these issues are annoying, but they don't ruin the game completely. Possessing cats and solving crimes as a ghost was pretty cool at times.This game reminds me a bit of Alan Wake and LA Noire. While not as good as either of those games, it was better than I thought it would be after seeing the professional reviews. Its sad the developer went bust one month after making this game.If you have modest expectations and some patience, its an enjoyable interactive-story game.Recommended, at sale price.tip: add “-nostartupmovies” to the game's steam launch settings.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect, the supernatural detective thriller from Square Enix and Airtight Games. Murdered takes place in Salem, Mass and stars the newly deceased Ronan O'Connor, who sets out to learn the identity of his killer.It's an adventure game, basically, right down to the often frustrating hunt for clues. This makes up a good chunk of the gameplay and tasks you with finding a certain number of bits of info by exploring a tightly defined location, examining everything. Moving the story forwards requires you to find and identify the most relevant clues. It's not the most graceful representation of the detective's art, but it is a more compelling take on the genre than the rummage sale of irrelevant detritus that typified LA Noire.So the game is absolutely amazing The visuals, the gameplay, are all spectacular and it's refreshing. they have completely redefined storytelling in gaming with this masterpiece.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												A got premise doesn't make a good game.Pro:+ A very interesting concept behind the game (solve your own murder, be a ghost that can walk through everything else)Con:TL;DR: everything else-VSYNC limist the game to horrific 30 fps. disablign VSYNC leads to a lot of screen tearing (GTX 970)-Random performance issues on some maps-Video sequence graphics have worse graphics than actual ingame graphics... wtf-Extremely linear game-Horrible controls (e.g. you always have to look at stuff in a VERY exact angle while the normals XBOX controller controlls are much to sensitive, so you randomly happen to skip past this point...)-inaccuracy in opject / enemy targeting worsens the above issue-> if you LOVE having to redo a stage because of random targeting issues... or simply bugged targting... this is agame for you!-Only autosave, no normal save- Gathering achievement stuff feels unrewarding since the unlocked "story" for each part is sually less than 4 sentences and that's it...- You can "Poltergeist"-stuff to distract people... but unless it's story relevant they don't give a flying f()ck whether that coffee machien nearly explodes... but if you need to disctract them for a story mission they suddely notice a fan beign switched on 3 rooms away....-THE GAME IS EXTREMELY SHORT. I think I spent as much time as I spent playing in order to avoid the stupidly placed save points.... and redoing the same stuff again.... the game already is repetitive enough..-NPC dialogues are limited to very few lines which you'll get annoyed to hear over and over if you use the "possess" feature-Very few sidequests- F()cking overwhelmign amounts of product placement (Essentially every God damn computer in the police station is running Deus Ex Human Evolution... Once would have been a nice Easter Egg, so many are just annoying. Well, maybe the devs wanted to show that their company at least made one good game...)Summary:The idea behind the game is GREAT. It's a good damn shame that essentially everything else went wrong. This game was a pain to play through... To bad I also hate leaving games unfinished... Let me tell you: It's simpyl not worth it...Sidenote:Why does this game have a horror tag? Because it features ghosts? Finding out you already ate the last cookie is a bigger horror...

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This game, just this game.I have so much praise for it that I don't even know where to begin, but I'll try to sound it off.-The gameplay is a breath of fresh-air because it's this unique blend of third-person action game with occasional stealth elements and exploration based adventure game with some crime scene investigation and mild puzzle-solving thrown for good measure. I have trouble really classifying it because I've never played anything quite like it, and it really managed to form it's own gameplay identity instead of being a clone of something else or fitting neatly into a pre-defined gameplay genre.-The graphics are also really pretty relative to how easy on the hardware it it. I was able to max it out (with AA turned off) at 1080p on a 750ti and it was rare that it dropped under FPS.-The story is brilliant and actually managed to have a couple twists that I really didn't see coming because of the way it played with my expectations near constantly and intentionally set itself up for common tropes only to subvert or play with them.-The art design is great and does this thing where it creates interesting eviroments by blending the real-world with ghostly left-overs of the past.-It was interesting how it turned no-clip into a game mechanic.-The bonus stuff like the side-missions and ghost stories were cool.I guess there is some cons, though:-The stealth sections can get tedious because the Demons tend to be a little to smart and aggressive, I often found myself trapped because they got stuck in the alert state and wouldn't go back to the posts no matter how well I stayed hidden.-Some poor optimization, I know I said it runs well but it does tend to suffer from really inconsistant framerates, it can be at 55FPS one minute and 100FPS the next and the Vsync is useless because it looks it to 30FPS instead of to your screens refresh rate.-Some of the items are to well hidden, I missed out on two of the Ghost Stories because I just could not find the last items for either, and one location even locked me out of room that the levels last item was presumably in.-No kind of map, even though the "hub" area is pretty huge and maze-like.-Short, I spent just over 10 hours on it and that was a playthrough with a lot of messing about and finding A LOT of the bonus items. I imagine it would be under 5 hours if you ignored the side-missions. -Price, I think $30 is pushing it. I paid $4 during a sale and I'd say it's not worth more than $15, so wait for it to go on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Is this a perfect game? No, not by a long shot, but then again, are there any perfect games which aspire to the complexity of narrative and gameplay as Murdered: Soul Suspect? As a narrative exercise, Murdered is very enjoyable. The stories of the various ghosts you encounter are always interesting and sometimes quite haunting. Ronan, the dead detective whom you play, may seem one dimensional at the beginning, but he is 'fleshed out', so to speak as you play, to at least TWO dimensions. But to mitigate this issue are some really interesting characters and stories, i.e. the aforementioned ghosts you meet. Some are quite affecting.The game is, for the most part, solidly built and I experienced no bugs or glitches while playing the game. Glimpses of Airtight Game's puzzle pedigry show through in several sections, though there is never an explicit focus on that kind of gameplay. Yet nor is there a focus on action. This a much more quiet and reflective gameplay experience, which I wonder is not an explanation of the game's poor reviews thus far. Certainly, it is not a blockbuster, but it feels more like an independent, more closely focused affair which I think many will enjoy if they are open to it.In many ways, I kept thinking about similar games I played in the 90s. Perhaps it was the interface itself or the mood or the package as a whole. The game is a throwback, so yes it does have obvious shortcomings. The living world which it hints at is very quickly revealed to be smoke and mirrors, but as already explained, I was fine with that. I liked the characters and the ideas and the game played smoothly. I do not regret slapping down the cash for this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												"You have the right to remain silent. Any cop you throw out a window will hunt you down and kick your♥♥♥♥♥"I really enjoyed this game, a dark supernatural murder mystery. I'm not sure exactly what the critics got upset about though looking at the Metascore, but it's not as bad as they have made it out to be.As others have mentioned it is very LA Noire-ish but it's more forgiving if you make a mistake during your investigation. The story is interesting, voice acting is good, and the atmosphere/music is very similar to an early Silent Hill. The game has you spend most of your time investigating your death and tracking down your killer. Along the way you can also collect items that tell you ghost stories, interact with living and dead, and help others that have also passed move on. This isn't a hard boiled action game like Max Payne, however you will run across demons during your travels that can be exercised. It is short yes, but for what it is I think it was probably the right length.   I didn't experience any major bugs or issues, and it is possible to 100% it on the one play through.A heads up though, the interactive map has some major mistakes in item locations, other users however have kindly corrected these with their own markers. So if you choose to use the map check out the Global Flags. So to wrap it up, if you are after ghost stories, dark settings and something a little different, check this one out.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												So no idea why it's online reviews were so bad. I've been looking forward to this game for a long time and I wasn't disappointed at all. Think of it as LA Noireish with ghosts. It's got the whole detective thing going for it which I like a lot and wish was found more often. Pros: -Compelling story, made me sit down and play though it in one sitting, amazing.-Gameplay, if you like to walk around and discover everything then this is the game for you. It never gets dull, slow or too fast. Demons are there to change up gameplay and overall I enjoyed being a exorcist.-Graphics, beautiful game, love the art, everything looks great.-I found a few Just Cause 2 posters in the game.-Even though it's supernatural it doesn't feel fake/childish.-Writing, for the most part, was done very well.-Made me want to help the lost souls and feel rewarded for doing so.-Examples about people who throw their life away.-Good ending.Cons:-Short, only about 5 hours if you stick to the story and probably close to 6-7 if you want to 100% the game.-Character development, sometimes it felt like characters weren't developed enough for me but I like to know full blown backgrounds, I wouldn't say it was bad though.-Occasional frame drops.Overall: Solid game, would definitely recommend. Good luck in the afterlife!! Morals:Don't do drugs.Don't kill yourself.Don't hold grudges.Do something with your life.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I will agree with some of the reviews, that this is more like a movie, than a game. And this game gets negative reviews because people are expecting a game, not a movie. But if it was soemthing like "Wolf Among Us" ("The Walking Dead" is a bit off, sicne it's not a detective story), noone would have complained, I think. And if there were more choices, that influence the game, if collectibles did not only tell you some background, but also influenced the ending somehow, if saving ghosts influenced the story... There are a lot of ifs, that could have been covered if this was an episodic game and if it did not feel like pieces were cut off of it. And if it actually had a map IN the game, not on a web-page.But if you forget about all these, it's not a bad story. Yes, if the background told by the collectibles were more integrated in the main story, characters could become more... Real. Less flat. But overall, I actually enjoyed it. It has good dynamic: not too fast (since it's not an action game), but not too slow (as some detective quests can be), it has motivation, it has mistery.I think I'll give it 7/10. Maybe 7.5/10, since it kinda reminded me of Dreamfall (although Dreamfall had more gameplay). I wonder if Airtight Games can make something in similar fasion, while covering some negative points. Or they can simply try an approach closer to Telltale Games, I guess.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is more of a point-and-click adventure game but with actual WASD movements. There isn't really any combat besides exorcising demons rarely from time to time (there aren't many throughout the game). You mostly look around spam clicking for clues and progressing through the story. A mentally challenged 2 year old monkey can beat this game. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though. If you want to just turn your brain off and enjoy an interesting story then this will be great! Think of it as an interactive movie.This game is rather short and linear even the "hidden" collectibles aren't very well hidden and tend to be right next to each other. But if you enjoy a good story and interesting characters it's a good game to play through once.

												The gameplay is repetitive -- just walk around and find some stuff and sometimes kill some demons. The game itself is buggy. I was able to play the same cinematics twice. Also, the war room mission title keeps popping up on the right hand side when I start the game and then says that it's completed no matter at which point of the game I'm at. 												I tend to give a game a lot of points if the idea of it is good and it looks good. This totally does, it's a cool film noir thing that's written like a paranormal TV show, in a good way. The 'detective' puzzles can be a little...wonky sometimes, abd a lot of them come down to trial and error. But even then it only takes a few minutes to really sort out which clue you need. The "combat" is kind of a sore spot, it's basically a stealth/reaction puzzle thing where you have to sneak up behind a demon, hold R, then press the WASD+mouse1/2 combination it shows you. Luckily the demons are pretty sparse. The focus is really on the atmosphere and the writing, which is actually super good.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												As many of you know this game has issues, issues square enix aren't in a hurry to fix.. mainly related to the game not launching on many PC's. Luckily there are people out there who have fixed this.. and the link at the bottom is a youtube video that also links in its description to the files needed to sort it all out. :)Onto the review... This game was very enjoyable from start to finish. The story is great and the whole idea of playing a dead character solving his own murder is one I haven't seen done before and it was excuted perfectly in this game so welldone to the developers for that as in the wrong hands an idea like this just wouldn't have worked as well I feel.The games graphics and look were great. I ran it maxed out at 1080p on my Radeon 6870 with a quad core Athlon II cpu and 8gb of memory. I didn't experience any framerate issues that others have mentioned in the forums.. tho there was one part of the story that seemed to repeat itself at one point and I'm pretty sure that wasn't meant to happen as it made no sense, but the story continued fine after that little hiccup, not a major issue.Controls on the 360 controller were great, very easy to get into and layed out well. I never tried the keyboard/mouse for this game as I felt no need to, so can't comment on some comments form others about it not suiting keyboard/mouse.. considering the price of even a 3rd party wired 360 controller these days its not a problem worth moaning about and as i said, the 360 controller is fully supported and ideal for this game.The game is quite short compared to most large companies titles these days and can be completed in between probably 7 and 10 hours depending on whether to stick to the main story or want to collect everything and complete the side stories. I clocked a bit more than that as I was playing the game on a day I was ill to pass the time lol, so game was paused for periods of time while i was .. well... attending to being ill lol.I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes games with a good story to unfold.. also its a bit different to the norm thats released these days. I hope Square-Enix and Airtight Games work together again on a similar title as I'd definitely buy it.. and hopefully they will learn from their game launching mistakes with this one.As stated the game launch problems are easily fixed using the files the guy links to on youtube for anyone that needs them.. (link below, view on youtube to see description and files link)I'll give the game 8/10 despite the shorter than usual gameplay and the fact I had to fix its launching problem. The score reflects the game itself and it was great.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Oh man, this game. Right from it's release, I somehow knew this game would really capture my interest. I picked it up at the Humble Store when they were doing a Square Enix Sale for $15. I do not regret paying that much, as this game really caught my attention.As far as gameplay goes, L.A. Noire players will find that it's a lot alike in terms of clues you must find and mysters that have to be solved. Of course, if you fail to connect the clues to the pending question of "who dun it", the game is more forgiving in that regard, as you get as many tries as it takes. Get it on your first try, however, and you get a better rank for that mission.There is "combat" in this game, but this is the one and only thing about this game that really was shallow. The "demons" that all of the ghosts within the plot are afraid of are nothing more than easy prey for the protagonist. What was supposed to be a game of cat and mouse where the demons were the cats, actually felt very flopsided, as every demon encounter I had within Murdered: Soul Suspect felt like mice, and I more than likely felt like the cat in multiple situations. I really felt like the purpose of having demons within the game was really undermined, thus, it fell very flat on it's face.The overall plot to this game is where it really shines. Within each level, it's a consistent game of "who dun it" as I mentioned earlier. Each solved case supposedly brings you one step closer to unmasking a pertty good villain: The Bell Killer, keyword "supposedly". I found that whom I thought it was all this time turned out to be completely and utterly wrong, and the game laughed in my face for having me think it'd be whom the clues all pointed to.As an added bonus, within each level you can find these artifacts that, when you collect them all, tell a ghost story about the specific surrounding that you find yourself in. Because of this, I will happily be replaying Murdered: Soul Suspect so I can listen and bask in the ghostly horror of these stories.Overall, this game was great, although a bit short. At it's current price tag of $50, one might be a tad disappointed. Wait for a sale, however, and you'll truly enjoy the ghostly world that is Murdered: Soul Suspect.

content:
Posted: April 1
												So, by this time I'm done with the game. Having done most but not all side missions. Worth mentioning that I got it via the Square Enix's mystery box for March which was 10$. For those looking for the punch-line of the review on if it's worth your money or not (29,99$), here it is guys and gals: If you like point and click adventure games, sure, go ahead, it's one of the better of it's kind, you don't see tripple A point and clicks that often. If not, I'd wait for a really good sale. Also keep in mind that the replayability value is low, if any.Now, into the depths: *The Plot* : You're a badass detective under the department of the Salem area, an active serial killer is around and you just happen to pick to have your badass moment going-in without back up moment in the wrong place and in the wrong time, getting killed. Surprise, you're now Casper and you get to be a detective in the afterlife trying to solve your own murder while trying not to get killed (again) by demons in the ghost town. The concept in itself is marvelous- who wouldn't want to be a ghost detective? But the execution.. Don't get me wrong, it had it's moments and a few great twists, but for the most time the story felt predictable, the characters felt very shallow and generic and they certainly  did not make me to want to know more about them. I really wanted to buy into the world, but I just could not feel it. Overall, the world building felt weak, if not rushed. It's like reading one of those books that you thought they were okay, but you just wished there was more to them because their description made you expect more. In short : -Average*The Gameplay*: As I mentioned earlier, the gameplay is point and click for 90% of the time. Those interested in L.A Noire/Sherlock games are out of luck, no observation needed what so ever, your only penalties are that you lose 'ranks' each time you make a mistake, that's pretty much it. Outside that, you go from area to area, you point and click at clues, you get clues, you point and click clues into a sequence and tadam, you're the Sherlock Holmes of the Underworld. Is it repetetive? Very. Is it a criticism? Not in this genre. Outside the point and clicking, you'll get to jog around the world for quite a bit from place to place with occasional simplistic puzzles that for the most part -you guessed it, require you to click on something and see magic happen. I gotta point out that the navigation after some point gets tiring and as a result of the world not feeling very lively, the game would have benefitted greatly from a fast travel option at some point. The devs put some interesting 'invisible' walls around the game so that as a ghost, you cant go through everything, you gotta go through the simplistic puzzles, of course and on top of that, those invisible walls and obstacles which make the world look 'cooler', also make it harder and pointlessly longer to traverse. The side missions around the world although they sometimes have an interesting backstory, are not very engaging for the most part. At some point, the invisible walls get very frustrating, especially once you get your teleport power as they get nonsensical. The weakest part of the gameplay is the combat. It's tedious and clunky. I wish I could demonstrate. There are demons, chasing you around, you have no weapons to fight so you have to hide and execute them from the back. The number of times I was spamming the execution button till it responded  but I left it (you gotta hold it) and failed the quick time event (YES, QTES BOIZ) which most likely resulted to my death or running around for 2 minutes as a result is immense. Not only that but the execution animations remain the same every time and its the same, over, and over, and over.. If you're adding combat, even stealthy combat into your game, you gotta be more creative. A huge spike of irritation comes in the last sequence of the game which becomes unforgivingly hard and 'timed'. I got so frustrated at that point that I finished it on another day. But that's literally the last 5 minutes. Overall, the gameplay, aside from the point and clicking is very average, with the combat being a gigantic unpleasant pain for the player.*Graphics* : Unimpressive. Although the main character model looks good, the world itself looks mostly uninspired and bland. The textures are pretty outdated and the effects were generic mostly. The character models outside the main character are mediocore. Your enemies are always the same kind, looking exactly the same like someone performed a kage bushin no jutsu (Yep, a Naruto reference). This unfortunately is the same also for the peope around you such as cops and even some ghosts are just so, so uninspired. Overall: Average (probably) for it's time, below average for what it is now.*Sound, Music, Voice Acting* : The sound of the game is actually good, I found myself enjoying each cutscene after an investigation was over as a result of the robust sound they provided. Its not ground breaking, but it felt more effortful. The music is very repetetive, its definitely not getting any 'extended' remixe's anytime soon, if ever. The voice was okay, the lip syncing was fine but if you were expecting L.A Noire, well, that's not the one.Is it worth your buy? For 29.99 I'd probably only recommend it to die hard point and click fans that wished for big publishrs to release point and click titles. For the rest, just wait for a good sale. The only thing the game has going for it is it's story which is not as interesting as the cover makes it to be. It's a missed opportunity for a game that would have great potential if you added better combat, a more fleshed out world and made people care for the characters.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												The game is actually pretty good. Short, but good. The story is absolutely fantastic - well written, well presented. There are a couple of problems I encountered - keyboard controls felt awkward, so I had to switch to xbox controller, the whole "investigation" thing is pretty linear. But what saved this game for me was the sheer amount of LORE and background for everything happening and what happened. Hell, even the town and some of it's past events are real. But also not only you can "read" newspaper articles or you dead wife's diaries - you can also poke around the city to find some ghostly remains of city's past, reveal some well-narrated backstories and so on.It is pretty linear in it's investigations, but outside them you have your town which is kind of open-worldish, but not really. Nice little touch is the ability to read people's minds - and even though they sometimes repeat - the amount of "thoughts" is pretty big and also reveals some lore.The "ghost" mechanic is great and executed well - the only bad thing I can name is that in tight spaces (there are not a lot of them, but still) you can easily lose your sense of space because of your "ghost noclip" ability. Oh, and demons are kind of annoying, but not too much, and they are pretty rare.The real bad thing is that this game is pretty short. If you ignore all nice details you can possibly complete it in 6 or 5 hours. With all the poking around it will take around 9-10, but not more. Though the story is good, really good. The whole story made me not regret buying it.8/10

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												While I have said I wouldn't recomend it I do have some positive points as well as negative ones.I will admit the concept is quite a fun one, a dead cop investigating his own death however I feel this game suffers from Remember Me syndrome. A good, interesting concept with bags of potential that has a half arsed delivery. It also feels like a dumbed down L.A Noire, that maybe a bit harsh actualy but anyway it still holds your hand through the investigations that are implemented a lot like L.A Noire. The twist is ok and frankly I was quite a head of the investigation before that point anyway and the rest of the game was basicaly confirming my theories. The controls are also very odd. Exorcising demons, which I swear is never explained how the main character and only him can do it however I may have just missed that or didn't pay attention, involves holding the R then pressing either W,A,S,D and the left mouse button. Now I'm sorry but this is just too much, a 3 button QTE is just too much, it's a QTE not a think for a bit to make sure I have the right button because if you don't your going to have to run fast. These demons are quick and kill quick too, they also freak me out a lot but that might be just me. The mouse is also super sensitive and it took me a while to get used to it even on the lowest setting. The cat controls are ridiculous too and seems to be slightly less broken than Radscorpions, which is saying a lot as they are the most glitchy animals in a game, ever. Oh and the game is too short, and the escort parts are silly as the people your escorting won't move till a distraction happens to lead the person away....who is standing still at the time, not actively searching...so those being escorted are never in any real danger, so it's a tad pointless. On the whole, good concept, average delivery and worth £10 on sale, definatly not full price though.Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Fridayhttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I REALLY wanted to like this.  The premise was unique (you're a detective and you need to find out who murdered you).  But this was just not enjoyable.The game is short.  By itself, this isn't a big deal, you don't need to put 40+ hours into a game to get your money's worth.  My playtime was 9 hours.  But I'm guessing 4 of those were spent fighting with the game's poor systems:1) No Map.  Seriously?  What is this 2004?  In a 3rd person exploration game this is unheard of & seems like it was omitted to add unnecessary time & difficulty.  Wandering about town, there is a series of intermediate waypoints that lead you to the next target, but those get broken & send you through areas that aren't available, so unless you're a navigational expert, you're stuck randomly wandering until you luck into the next target.2) Combat.  It's basically added as an afterthought to add time in between the "investigations" (which are generally well done, once you figure out the game's systems).  There's one monster type & it's pattern is easily identifiable.  But the controls are difficult & even if you do everything right you still might get caught & have to redo the area.  The game is using poor controls & frustration to again add extra difficulty & time, instead of giving the enemies useful AI.The graphics are fine, but suffer from overusing a "dark & hazy" theme.  Considering the story takes place entirely at night, this is probably expected.I was engaged enough with the setting & story enough to want to finish it, but definitely won't be replaying to get a 100% finish.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Criminal turned detective stumbles upon a killer and end up dead. Insted of going into the light, he becomes a ghost, resolved to reveal who murdered him. It's an adventure game, most similar to LA Noire. You go around, detect and inspect clues, listen onto the conversations, talk to other ghosts, walk through the walls, think, make hypothesis, solve mysteries, and reveal the story step by step. There's no much action, but there are stealth sequences, where you have to detect demons, and destroy them before they find you. A lot of optional content (side quests, world information, character info and all that) to be found. Nice graphics and sound, a bit weird controls but one can easily get used to them. I like it.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												To start off there is only 4 hours of gameplay here and no replay value. It is basically an interactive movie. It is a murder mystery. For me this game/movie was kind of boring... Not very fun for a video game. I feel sorry for those who paid full price. I guess I got my $12 worth out of this game since it's cheaper than going to the movies to kill 4 hours. This is a Crime, Drama, Murder, Mystery. I'd say I've been bored for 4 hours since I just wanted to finish the story. It wasn't worth it for myself. There was no challenge at all... Just go here investigate this and that help this person do this get here blah blah blah.... Just boring.Killing demons isn't even satisfying and it's also a very small part of the game to add a challenge... It's not challenging at all. Just get behind the demon hold R then you will have to hit W, A, S, or D with left or right click, it's completely random which is cool but i'd rather actually battle the demon with something more interactive. But yeah do that and the demon is dead YAYYYY!!! Or you can just skip killing demons and go to your next location... doesn't matter.This game is only worth $12 or less. For a single-player only game for $50 when it released and only 4 hours of gameplay if you don't care about finding every stupid hidden piece in the world. I just went where I needed to go and picked up what I could along the way. Most single-player 3rd person / 1st person games have around 8 hours average if not a little longer and also have replay value majority of the time.Bought it, played it, completed it, never playing it again, the end.
