content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Really awesome game, painfully short.  Game is pretty easy, really no penalty for wrong answers to investigations.  It's also really linear.  But regardless I found myself really enveloped in the world and lore, I found myself finishing it quickly within 3 settings, totalling 10 hours.  If I could say one are I did not like were the demons (enemies) in the game, the only way to beat them is to use a QTE that lasts no more than 1 second on screen that randomizes each time; if you fail you need to hide for a good 30 seconds to a minute if not more each time.  If more than one demon is chasing you, good luck - just kill yourself and restart at checkpoint because I *never* was able to elude more than one demon at a time.The story is fanstastic, the voice acting is above average bordering on great.  There is an awesome twist right at the end and the culprit, in the realm of the gameworld, is believeable and throughly explained.  However it has very little to no replay value.  I would really like to see a sequel with a more fleshed out overworld and maybe branching paths or consequences to your choices.I give the game a 4 out of 5

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												'Always be careful with overhyped games that even gets attention by common news media!' ... would be an advise I would give to my children.Too bad Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the games, that I would put in that category. But why do I recommend it then? Easy answer: This game isn't a total desaster, but it is not worth its full price.The gaming magazines criticize its length, its combat system (btw there is no combat system ... you more or less only hide from the few enemies) and absolutly no replay value. These three things I can confirm.It is also annoying, that while the main characters are very detailed, everyone else looks way worse and there is nearly nothing to do beside the 'main' quest.But that main quest is the thing, that keeps you nonstop playing till the end. The story with a relativly unused setting is well executed and the gameplay elements are simple enough to give you more of a interactive movie, then an (action) adventure.So if you like (gameplay simple) mystery thriller, go grab this game, when it is on big discount.

												WELL! just finished it (12 hours gameplay... really tryed to enjoy it).... WELL...where to start?first: was waiting for this game 2 months... big expectations.... preordered and waitedsecond: limited edition - there was a small journal (i have a phys. game DVD limited ed.) - nice small book, interesting reading.... no spoilers... just some "background" info... nicethird: the game.... well... the story is great i think, the end surprised me. Nice twist. I guessed another ending :) The story, i mean the IDEA of this game is great/unique. The afterlife and etc. Many ghost NPC - some interesting, some useless. The living NPCs on the streets.. .well... the city was a bit dead .... empty. (many repeatitive toughts and lines, etc...) not enought side quests.The gameplay.... not bad, but not superb...  I think the action passages were..... the fighting part was for 3rd time boring. But the demons were great (mean the design, not their skills or AI)I think 2-3 months more for betatesting to correct flaws and changes in gameplay, this game could have been PERFECT  (9 from 10) but maybe next time!But now... one playthrout and I think I never play it again. There are flaws for me I cant never forget....Dont buy it for full price or you become angry. Trust me.  (10-15 euros, or sale)In past, Ive played fahrenheit (indigo prophecy) and both Alan Wakes (game and expansion)... I think this game is first for me, then Alan Wake, and then fahrenheit. Didnt liked the Alan Wake supernatural part, and fahrenheits either. But this was more believable. I really want to try Beyond 2 souls and heavy rain, but i dont have a ps3 and they never make it for PCs.I can tell Im satisfied... And I think theyve made a room for a sequel maybe...I give it a 7 (i dont care for the reviews) this game is: you love it or hate it... no other way. And I loved it more like hated it.Fans of deep story adventures are welcome... the others... well.... you can try (but dont forget, not the full price) :)7And one more thing - the MC was great. He played it very well(he had a great style and personality). And all others too. Like a theatre.

												While there are some things that I liked about this game and are really interesting, almost none of those take place in the gameplay.  Gathering clues and evidence is neat.  The game's mechanic for putting those clues and evidence together for a solution is terrible.  When it's not the most obvious puzzle ever, it's a complete guess and luck.  The action sequences are not terrible.  They simply aren't fun.  Wait till the enemy turns his back and then walk up and do the QTE.Gameplay aside though, the environment and story are interesting and the conclusion, though a bit hokey, is pretty good too.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												I LOVED this game. But I'll confess to having a bit of a bias due to how firmly this game dug into a favorite subject of mine storywise - laying the dead to rest/bringing peace to the restless dead. The story is dark, intriguing, and I count it among those rare ones where I couldn't figure out where plot twist was going ahead of time.PROS:-Superb storytelling-Excellent quality voice acting-Graphically gorgeous and expressively animated-Tons of exploration-Tons of stuff to collect as a reward for exploring-Interesting story-related things unlocked by finishing collections-Controls overall translated well from controller to keyboard-Intriguing puzzle system.-Very good 'beacon' system to get you from goal to goal along the mainstoryline.Cons:-Barely-there combat system. It fit the feel of the game (I'm serious about this), but anybody looking for more than light stealth sections are going to be disappointed.-No map whatsoever. This can be particularly frustrating when trying to track down collectibles.Verdict: Very, very good, excellent game, just not for everybody.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The entire premise of this game is solid. The story is well done. The characters aren't half bad. The locations themselves are very well designed and it doesn't overstay its welcome (about 8 and a half hours to 100%). That being said take note that some problems exist (at least at the time of writing this "review")1. No key rebinding. At all. Unacceptable. Good thing I used a pad.2. If you miss any collectibles you can't go back and find them after completing the final sequence of the game. This game has over 200 collectibles. It honestly expects you to find them all in one go.3. V-Sync locks the game to 30FPS. Unlocked I didn't notice any tearing myself but YMMV. (Runs at over 100FPS maxed on a 2500k/12GB DDR3/670 @ 1920x1080 if you're curious about performance). 4. There are terrible tacked on demon fights in most chapters of the story. They add noting and just slow the game down. It's just a game of waiting for a demon to turn its back to you so you can come out of hiding and do a quicktime event. Absolutely. Pointless. Outside of that, it's pretty awesome and worth about $20-$30. It's no L.A. Noire but as far as detective games go it's not bad.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												A hidden gem or a rusty stone To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.Is this a good game?I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.Final verdictMurdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Having seen footage of the very first part of the game, I was curious about the story. The characters and detective esque gameplay seemed interesting. So, I purchased the game and have only just finished it. The game is about a detective who has to find the mystery behind his own murder. This game was played with a 360 controller.Lots of text following, so:tldr; amazing cat simulator, 10/10serious tldr; Only buy if you are interested in the story only and not in it as a game. And only then when it is on sale.numbers tldr;Gameplay      [3/10] - not much of itWorld            [2/10] - felt emptyStory             [6.7/10] - not as exciting or interesting as I hoped, but still good. Narrated short side stories were very entertaining, and eerie. Graphics        [6/10] - adequateSound            [5/10] - nothing noteworthy or memorable, but adequateVoice Acting   [6.7/10] - mixed feelings, bland NPCs are bland, main characters are quite okay.You can move freely as a ghost, passing through real world objects such as walls. The design here is quite well done, clipping through objects felt quite natural in this game and definitely was an interesting experience. You grow quite quickly accustomed by it, and by the time you do the novelty of it does wear off as fast (atleast it did for me). Even though you can pass through some objects, ghostly objects and certain walls still limit you. More and more as you progress through the game, making it feel like any other regular game. Gameplay wise, throughout the story you encounter different "crime" scenes and are left to examine it. This involves some looking around, and depending on how many of the clues you want to find and how adept you are at it, it could take 5 to 10 minutes. It does not involve more than walking around the crime scene and pressing X to interact with an object. Sometimes,  the game wants you to be slightly more involved by asking you to, for example, select which of 3 objects matches the sound being played. More often than not, the sound and belonging object combination were quite far fetched in my opinion.  Another type of clue is when you "reveal" a memory of the scene. You get to see a person and need to select out of a bunch of choices what the person was doing or experiencing, again a selection of 3 to be made. When you have collected enough clues, you can "solve" the scene by combining the most relevant clues to mystery at that time (such as: "What was person X doing here?"). For each of these elements, the player has 3 tries to get it right. When the player fails within those 3 tries, I believe it doesn't quite matter and the counter stays at 1. I'm not sure of this, since I've at most only had it happen to me once in the beginning of the game.The player moves from scene to scene through the town of Salem, which is filled with bland NPCs. You have the option to possess them and read their thoughts, which more often than not are only 2 of. Once you listen to a thought, you can't quit it either, and have to wait for the voice to finish talking. Other options the player rarely has when possessing an NPC is to "Influence" their thoughts (pick the most likely clue out of a bunch to try help the person remember something useful) or to "Peek" meaning watch through their perspective to see what they see. These are only ever useful with NPCs at a scene, not random NPCs spread throughout town (whom, by the way, all look similair and mostly have the exact same thoughts). You can sometimes hear them converse with eachother, which is a nice element to the game to give it a bit more depth and make it seem more alive, but it is not far enough to stop the NPCs and the town of Salem feel bland and empty.Other actions the player can use as a ghost is "Reveal" (hold R to reveal a ghostly object), "Remove" (hold R to remove a ghostly object) and "Teleport" (hold LB and release to teleport at an aimed location). In a nutshell, the actions the player has available to him are very limited and do not add much to a gameplay perspective value. To try and make the game more exciting (dare I say challenging?) they have added two enemies to the game: demons and a pool of demon grasping hands. When you walk over the second one it grabs you and you need to press a random direction combined with a button to get out. Once you figure this out it succesfully into like any other wall you can't pass through. Demons patrol certain areas, once they see you they try to suck your soul which means game over. You need to avoid being seen by them, meaning hiding in certain "Ghost residue" or simply behind walls. You can sneak up on them from behind and execute them by, again, pressing a given direction and button. Bland. Annoying. Nothing more than a nuisance.I believe we've arrived at the final gameplay element, which is the cat. Yes, you can take over the cat and move around for some basic platforming action thing. If one could even call it that, as you're basically still just walk around, except sometimes with a jumping or climbing animation. The most interesting thing for me were the short narrated ghost stories, which could be unlocked by collecting a bunch of objects. The problem with this though, was that you had to actively search around to try and find the objects, sometimes 14 of them. And you needed all of them. Got 13 and can't find the last one? Too bad, you get nothing. I would have really liked it if the developers had changed it so that you only needed to find half of them, because a game such as this that only has the story going on for it would do well to cater the only players still playing by giving them these greatly narrated short stories. The characters in the game were alright, there's a bit of character progression going on and you learn the relationships between them. The main character is enjoyable to get to know, and thinks and behaves like a real person. It was good enough to keep me interested. The game can be finished within a day's playtime if you want. I've got about 12 hours on it including afk time and searching for most of the side clues.If you enjoy the story, I recommend just watching a playthrough on YouTube or something and skipping through boring parts. I can only recommend the purchase of this game if you are truly interested in the concept of it and would like to see more (better!) of it by supporting the developers, and even then only on a heavy sale. €40,- for a game as this is severely overpriced, unfortunately.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												Graphics are nice, but the control system is limited and a little forced (obviously intended for a controler). the only 'Action' is when you interact with demons and try to kill them from behind, in which case you have to quickly push a randomly chosen WASD key+mouse button combo while holding down another key to initiate. If they see you first, or you miss the key combo (EG because you're moving when you initate and the key your holding isn't the right one) then the only thing you can do is run away untill their not searching for you anymore and try again. Other than that it's a really simple detective game where you atempt to move your character into just the right spots to be able to interact with clues to get really obvious hints. (you get flashes of information when you find the clue, then you have to watch it all over again anyway once you 'solve' the crime)If you enjoy 'Tell me a story' mode games and can get past the controls it's alright. but get it on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The game has a good story, nice environments and believable characters with solid voice overs. Actually, it could have been one of those interactive movies if not these two things.First of all, it's completely linear. The main story and a few side quests. The only variable is whether you find all the collectibles (they are all related to the lore) or not. More likely, not - looking for every collectible is just too boring and doesn't provide much new information.Secondly, for some reason the creators tried to add more depth to gameplay and introduced demons that you need to hide from or kill stealthily. And it just doesn't work. Too easy for any Thief (Splinter Cell, Hitman, etc) player and too boring on top of that. Thankfully, those moments with demons are really short and sometimes you can simply run through them and then hide.Despide the flaws, I still recommend playing it. Basically, it's like watching a good movie. Perhaps you can even be surprised in the end!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												this game is an absolute disappointmentbut before i start raging i must pause and give a thumbs-up to the interesting plot that this game has. and that's about it what can anyone enjoy the game. maybe some shallow gamers could also enjoy it for the graphics but don't get me even started on those.anyways, there is absolutely no gameplay. the whole "game" consits of boring pixel hunting, after which you are asked absolutely dumb "detective" questions, which often don't even make sense and would make even CSI-miami look like a decent detective movie (which it is not). basically, it has absolutely nothing to do with playing a detective.the hours of boredom spent by pixel hunting for "clues" and collectible artifacts are accompanied by an absolutely ridiculously primitive "stealth action", which consists of walking behind a wall with ghost infravision or whatever and just killing these demons with a press of a button. and the game does not even punish you for getting noticed because you just run away, hide and return later, and try to press the "KILL GHOST BUTTON" again. and if you are incompentend enough and manage to get killed somehow, i don't know, maybe a dog jumped in your face or something, then you respawn 1 milliseond and 1 millimeter before the enemy encounter, because the checkpoints and saves are almost literally made after your character makes a step. (honestly, i have not gotten killed a single time during the game, except for once when i wondered what would actually happen if i got killed on purpose)honestly, just reading these few paragraps written with my terrible english will probably be a time spent better than trying to enjoy the gameplay of this excuse of a modern "press x to win" game. but as i said earlier, the story is cool and the little ghost tales told for collecting items during the abrasive pixel hunting are interesting as well. i would much rather watch a 1 hour long B-movie made from this story than die in agony wandering through the streets of the boredom town to get to the story.this was a terrible experience, and screw the money but i want the time back. the time. give me back my time.PS. before you dismiss the review because i have 0.1 hours of the game played on the record, i played it with steam in the offline mode and it just didn't register my playtime

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm going to begin by voicing my displeasure at the fact that steam has only a two means of reviewing a game. The bright blue thumbs up or red thumbs down is the first thing people see and it is criminal that I'm forced to open my opinion with either a blatant recommendation or condemnation, as it is often never that simple. Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of those games that I feel very ambivalent towards. It gets a thumbs down though for reasons I'll gladly expound upon here but I'll start by saying that If you do want to buy this game, go ahead, but do it at a discount as there isn't enough of it to warrant its full price by a long shot. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural intrigue game where you play as Ronan O'Connor, gangland warrior turned detective and wandering samurai warrior, who is tracking a mysterious serial killer. Ronan is about apprehend the killer in the opening cutscene when the killer decides he's had enough of the law and reenacts the opening scene from Watchmen all over Ronan's face before shooting him seven times in the chest. So Ronan is dead, but you knew that already. Ronan now has to endeavor to do in one night what the entire police force couldn't do in years worth of time and solve the case of the Bell Killer. M:SS reminds me of two very specific games I actually liked, the first of which is Alan Wake. Like Alan Wake, this game is about supernatural dealings with a distinctly traditional American feel. Also like AW, the rules for the supernatural stuff in this game are very well defined.The supernatural lore being dealt with this time is ghosts, exploring all the traditional facets of what you might think ghosts are like, but before you go hog wild there is an exception to each of your abilities. You can pass through walls but not consecrated or ethereal walls, which mark the level boundaries. You can jumble electronics, but not to any meaningful degree. You can possess people but not control their actions. You can teleport, but not over demon holes so you still have to circumvent those on foot. Also like in Alan Wake, there isn't a whole lot to do in between plot points except hunt for collectibles. This leads me into the real issue I had with this game: its design.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game of extra steps. I kept a running list of things the game took more than one step to complete without needing to: Often the game will end a cutscene just to have you press the interact button to continue the same cutscene. When questioning a suspect, you have to press a button for each option you want to explore but the interrogation doesn't end until all options are explored, so it might as well be one long cutscene. You can read the minds of people you possess but each person has exactly two things to say and you have to press the button twice to hear both things when they could just say them both at once. When piecing together the clues of an investigation, if you pick a wrong option you get booted from the screen, having to reenter the screen to continue. When grabbing collectibles, you have to reveal the object first before picking it up. The collectibles are half hidden but the game tells you where they are so there's no need for hiding them. Speaking of collectibles, there are a plethora of them, all of which have very little to no bearing on the actual game. Each area has a unique object that, once all are gathered, will unlock  a spooky campfire story unrelated to what you are doing. There are a series of over arching collectibles including diary pages from Ronan's dead wife (really the only means of character development), handy info blurbs copy-pasted from the Salem tourism comity website, and newspaper clippings reminding you how creepy and invincible the serial killer is.While Alan Wake also felt the need to boldly announce the appearance of an enemy so that there is no way for you to be caught off guard, at least it had engaging combat. Every once in a while the game breaks up the monotony by presenting you with enemies to sneak up behind and quick-time-event to death. Once or twice a level, there will be demons that half-heatedly wander around in an enclosed area. You have to hide in the hiding spot and wait for the monster to turn around so you can slowly walk up behind it and kill it. This ends up being tedious and non-threatening, unit you mess up. If you manage to not properly dispatch your spectral foe, the backlash is absurd. Demons will kill you within a 3-5 second window unless you can scurry back to a hiding spot. However, once detected, the demons can see you in hiding spots; forcing you to shift between them as fast and erratically as possible until they give up. This turns what little combat there is into a game of Red Light, Green Light. These sections make no sense to the lore of the game either as there is no reason given as to why Ronan seems to be the only ghost that can dispatch the demons. No introduction is given to the power nor is it explained that Ronan is the only one capable of it, leading me to wonder why the other ghosts all flee in terror when the demons show up.The second game I'm reminded of is L.A. Noire, because the investigation sections are reminiscent of the ones in that game. You have to walk around the crime scene and collect the clues, using them to piece together the motive of the criminal. There are six to fourteen clues per scene but only three of them at most are ever necessary to continue. It's no secret that detective work is not as flashy or intriguing as it is portrayed in popular culture, but no where is this more obvious than video games. L.A. Noire had a good mix of action and detective work, due (I think) to it's structure. All the clues were relevant because solving the case was the goal of the mission and everything unfolded naturally. Murdered, by contrast, has you investigating glaringly obvious crime scenes which, more often than not, inform you of something you already knew. For example, one crime scene later on in the game has you investigating a room full of people the Bell Killer murdered all at once. At the point of investigation, however, you have already been made aware of what the killer did afterword, so the reason for killing the room full of people is obvious. Then, once you investigate the room, Ronan stands there and tells the the reason the killer did it, even though you already knew. Really the investigating is just being a master of the obvious. It's also impossible to fail to find all of the clues, because the game tells you how many are present in the scene.Murdered, like many games these days, would have probably made a better book or movie. The game play really just consists of different kinds of walking around and looking at things. Despite being a game made by an established developer and publisher, this is something any indie dev could have made, if not made look quite as good. In the end, games are meant to be interactive; that is what the medium excels at. Yet more and more it seems like games are being made with interactivity at the bottom of their priority list. Once during the middle of a cutscene I caught my self replying to text messages. It was then I realized how bored I was with the game; how absolutely unengaged I felt. The story was really not all that bad but being set in Salem, you can bet with reliability that it will have to do with what Salem is famous for. I would rather them have just made a movie out of it and cut out the game play entirely. At least then it would have taken me only 120 minutes to get through.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												I just beat this game and I can safely say that I loved it.(I have tried to avoid spoilers at all costs, but I'd still be wary of them)I have actually been following the development of this game since it's first announcement, and when I saw the bad reviews I was kinda sad that a game like this would do so poorly.Luckily, the reviews didn't put me off enough to not play the game. I did play it and well, it's fantastic. The story is definitely the highlight of this game. Playing through it and see all the events and twists kept me immersed that I nearly forgot about real life. Was a long time ago I had an experience like that.The gameplay, while most reviewers said it was bad, I enjoyed walking around finding things and exploring. I also liked the "stealth" element with hiding around enemies. You don't actually fight, and if you get seen they hunt you down until you die. You have to get behind them and execute them through a QTE (which is pretty easy, but I messed it up a bit because I got stressed like crazy when those things were around)The game is open-ended and Salem acts like a sort-of hub for the game. Doesn't mean that it's not shockful of collectables Also, the game has loads of those. Around 200.All-in-all, I loved this game. It's not the perfect game, but the story is just amazing. The game is relatively short, but in my opinion the story makes up for it. I would recommend you to buy it, but if around 8-10 hours doesn't cut if for you, you should wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												I'd only recommend this game for its story only - in no way is this game worth the full price and it doesn't live up to what a game should be (some good gameplay elements but not used very well).This game is more fitting for a movie than a game since the whole "clue" thing is very much compulsory to proceed in the story line. The investigation aspect is forced on to you on each level and spoon feeds you on what you need to do, meaning that the harder-to-find clues aren't even necessary and have no impact in the game, making it a linear story. Side quests are almost non-existent despite it showing some potential with some of the ghosts you talk to - most of which, there is nothing to persuade them to move on from the living world. It has much potential but it dies down and you realize that everything you thought was cool, becomes repetitive and or unnecessary. Gameplay/Story aside, there are annoying technical issues with this game - only one save file is allowed and the autosave is terribly planned. If you're unlucky, like me, you'd have spent some time and lose all your progress with side quests (did two side quests and quit the game, only to find out that the game didn't save). The game's vsync is garbage, your video driver's vsync produces better results.To sum things up, the game aspects of this game are great but not used well to keep you entertained for long. The only things that could keep you entertained would be the story and that depends per user's preference. The autosave feature sucks, it only saves during main quest and when you enter/exit places. It doesn't save on the town map at all.[Possible spoiler regarding gameplay]The teleport and remove abilities are barely used in this game, making you wonder "whats the point of having this?". In the end, you only use the teleport ability for travel conveniences rather than to get past obstacles like how it was originally introduced to you. Remove ability is pretty much dead in the game, there's no point of having it. I'm quite ok with the monsters but other people may have issues with them. The demons need more variety. There are only 2 types of monsters that get in your way and it's those same 2 from beginning to end. Their availability in the game are very rare and illogical - you don't see them in the open map and only during story related quests. The investigation/clues - some answers are stupid and doesn't fit well in what you are observing, others are so obvious. As mentioned before, the important clues are in your face and you're forced to use them as your evidence. You won't be able to proceed unless you use those set pieces.The AI ... at first, you think it's cool but as you play on and interact with the non-quest related AI, it all becomes repetitive. They all say the same things and they don't react when you use poltergeist... they're there for decoration and nothing more.

												Only played a couple of hours but already clear this is a pretty decent offering if you're into something a little moody and at the same time not macabre. Imagine an clue exploration game with the investigations from LA Noire with a paranormal twist. There's tons to discover, lots of parallel stories and investigations going on, and reasonably unique gameplay mechanics. These don't always work so well, for example prompts don't highlight unless you move around to a certain angle, etc. But overall very decent experience, and worth getting on sale - not full price. The graphics are a little rough, especially character animation, but they set the tone very well nonetheless. I'd say a solid 6/10, which is fine if you can get it for an affordable price.

												This is a really enjoyable game. The gameplay is mostly just finding stuff around the environment, with a few simple stealth combat sequences and puzzles to mix it up. The story is pretty good, although far too short. Voice acting is top-notch, although the game does suffer from 'Welcome to Corneria' syndrome at times.If you hate collectables, this is not the game for you, but unlike many other games, you actually get nice rewards for finding stuff here. The side stories are quite interesting.All in all, this game is clearly low-budget and unpolished, but there are still many endearing and fun features. If you're a fan of immersive environments and detailed lore, don't miss out on this game.

												This game is very similar to LA Noire but instead you are a ghost detective in the present day instead of an LAPD detective in the 40s. The gameplay mainly consists of walking around and examining objects in the environment to help solve cases. If that bores you, don't get this game because there is not even much of a combat system aside from sneak attacking demons once in a while. It is kind of open world in the sense that you are free to walk around town and collect objects to solve side cases, but the lack of any sort of map or minimap makes exploration a hassle. With all that being said, I enjoyed the story and atmosphere of the game, which is surprisingly a bit lighthearted for a game about ghosts. It took me about 7 hours to complete the game and I also took my time to grab most of the collectibles as well.Verdict: Definitely get this on a sale, it is short but sweet. 6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												A hidden gem or a rusty stone To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.Is this a good game?I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.Final verdictMurdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the best detective/interactive fiction games I ever played. The story is quite compelling and dark, since you play a cop who was murdered and has to find out about his killer. Taking place in the legendary small town of Salem, which you can freely traverse, you head from one crime scene to the next. There you have to solve single cases, all of which are interconnected and eventually will lead to reveal the big picture of the main mystery. You will find clues to other side cases everywhere and can interact with a lot of people, dead and alive. The presentation, utilizing the Unreal 3 engine, is very adequate to the story, creating very dark and gritty ambience. Everything is nicely modeled and really good animated and also the sound design is excellent and facilitates the gloomy atmosphere.The only critique that I have is that there is little to no replay value. Once the cases are solved, you will hardly touch this game again.All in all I had a great time playing this game and I do recommend you give it a try. My verdict: 9/10 points -  great game

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												'Always be careful with overhyped games that even gets attention by common news media!' ... would be an advise I would give to my children.Too bad Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of the games, that I would put in that category. But why do I recommend it then? Easy answer: This game isn't a total desaster, but it is not worth its full price.The gaming magazines criticize its length, its combat system (btw there is no combat system ... you more or less only hide from the few enemies) and absolutly no replay value. These three things I can confirm.It is also annoying, that while the main characters are very detailed, everyone else looks way worse and there is nearly nothing to do beside the 'main' quest.But that main quest is the thing, that keeps you nonstop playing till the end. The story with a relativly unused setting is well executed and the gameplay elements are simple enough to give you more of a interactive movie, then an (action) adventure.So if you like (gameplay simple) mystery thriller, go grab this game, when it is on big discount.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												WELL! just finished it (12 hours gameplay... really tryed to enjoy it).... WELL...where to start?first: was waiting for this game 2 months... big expectations.... preordered and waitedsecond: limited edition - there was a small journal (i have a phys. game DVD limited ed.) - nice small book, interesting reading.... no spoilers... just some "background" info... nicethird: the game.... well... the story is great i think, the end surprised me. Nice twist. I guessed another ending :) The story, i mean the IDEA of this game is great/unique. The afterlife and etc. Many ghost NPC - some interesting, some useless. The living NPCs on the streets.. .well... the city was a bit dead .... empty. (many repeatitive toughts and lines, etc...) not enought side quests.The gameplay.... not bad, but not superb...  I think the action passages were..... the fighting part was for 3rd time boring. But the demons were great (mean the design, not their skills or AI)I think 2-3 months more for betatesting to correct flaws and changes in gameplay, this game could have been PERFECT  (9 from 10) but maybe next time!But now... one playthrout and I think I never play it again. There are flaws for me I cant never forget....Dont buy it for full price or you become angry. Trust me.  (10-15 euros, or sale)In past, Ive played fahrenheit (indigo prophecy) and both Alan Wakes (game and expansion)... I think this game is first for me, then Alan Wake, and then fahrenheit. Didnt liked the Alan Wake supernatural part, and fahrenheits either. But this was more believable. I really want to try Beyond 2 souls and heavy rain, but i dont have a ps3 and they never make it for PCs.I can tell Im satisfied... And I think theyve made a room for a sequel maybe...I give it a 7 (i dont care for the reviews) this game is: you love it or hate it... no other way. And I loved it more like hated it.Fans of deep story adventures are welcome... the others... well.... you can try (but dont forget, not the full price) :)7And one more thing - the MC was great. He played it very well(he had a great style and personality). And all others too. Like a theatre.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I just beat this game and I can safely say that I loved it.(I have tried to avoid spoilers at all costs, but I'd still be wary of them)I have actually been following the development of this game since it's first announcement, and when I saw the bad reviews I was kinda sad that a game like this would do so poorly.Luckily, the reviews didn't put me off enough to not play the game. I did play it and well, it's fantastic. The story is definitely the highlight of this game. Playing through it and see all the events and twists kept me immersed that I nearly forgot about real life. Was a long time ago I had an experience like that.The gameplay, while most reviewers said it was bad, I enjoyed walking around finding things and exploring. I also liked the "stealth" element with hiding around enemies. You don't actually fight, and if you get seen they hunt you down until you die. You have to get behind them and execute them through a QTE (which is pretty easy, but I messed it up a bit because I got stressed like crazy when those things were around)The game is open-ended and Salem acts like a sort-of hub for the game. Doesn't mean that it's not shockful of collectables Also, the game has loads of those. Around 200.All-in-all, I loved this game. It's not the perfect game, but the story is just amazing. The game is relatively short, but in my opinion the story makes up for it. I would recommend you to buy it, but if around 8-10 hours doesn't cut if for you, you should wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I'm going to begin by voicing my displeasure at the fact that steam has only a two means of reviewing a game. The bright blue thumbs up or red thumbs down is the first thing people see and it is criminal that I'm forced to open my opinion with either a blatant recommendation or condemnation, as it is often never that simple. Murdered: Soul Suspect is one of those games that I feel very ambivalent towards. It gets a thumbs down though for reasons I'll gladly expound upon here but I'll start by saying that If you do want to buy this game, go ahead, but do it at a discount as there isn't enough of it to warrant its full price by a long shot. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural intrigue game where you play as Ronan O'Connor, gangland warrior turned detective and wandering samurai warrior, who is tracking a mysterious serial killer. Ronan is about apprehend the killer in the opening cutscene when the killer decides he's had enough of the law and reenacts the opening scene from Watchmen all over Ronan's face before shooting him seven times in the chest. So Ronan is dead, but you knew that already. Ronan now has to endeavor to do in one night what the entire police force couldn't do in years worth of time and solve the case of the Bell Killer. M:SS reminds me of two very specific games I actually liked, the first of which is Alan Wake. Like Alan Wake, this game is about supernatural dealings with a distinctly traditional American feel. Also like AW, the rules for the supernatural stuff in this game are very well defined.The supernatural lore being dealt with this time is ghosts, exploring all the traditional facets of what you might think ghosts are like, but before you go hog wild there is an exception to each of your abilities. You can pass through walls but not consecrated or ethereal walls, which mark the level boundaries. You can jumble electronics, but not to any meaningful degree. You can possess people but not control their actions. You can teleport, but not over demon holes so you still have to circumvent those on foot. Also like in Alan Wake, there isn't a whole lot to do in between plot points except hunt for collectibles. This leads me into the real issue I had with this game: its design.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game of extra steps. I kept a running list of things the game took more than one step to complete without needing to: Often the game will end a cutscene just to have you press the interact button to continue the same cutscene. When questioning a suspect, you have to press a button for each option you want to explore but the interrogation doesn't end until all options are explored, so it might as well be one long cutscene. You can read the minds of people you possess but each person has exactly two things to say and you have to press the button twice to hear both things when they could just say them both at once. When piecing together the clues of an investigation, if you pick a wrong option you get booted from the screen, having to reenter the screen to continue. When grabbing collectibles, you have to reveal the object first before picking it up. The collectibles are half hidden but the game tells you where they are so there's no need for hiding them. Speaking of collectibles, there are a plethora of them, all of which have very little to no bearing on the actual game. Each area has a unique object that, once all are gathered, will unlock  a spooky campfire story unrelated to what you are doing. There are a series of over arching collectibles including diary pages from Ronan's dead wife (really the only means of character development), handy info blurbs copy-pasted from the Salem tourism comity website, and newspaper clippings reminding you how creepy and invincible the serial killer is.While Alan Wake also felt the need to boldly announce the appearance of an enemy so that there is no way for you to be caught off guard, at least it had engaging combat. Every once in a while the game breaks up the monotony by presenting you with enemies to sneak up behind and quick-time-event to death. Once or twice a level, there will be demons that half-heatedly wander around in an enclosed area. You have to hide in the hiding spot and wait for the monster to turn around so you can slowly walk up behind it and kill it. This ends up being tedious and non-threatening, unit you mess up. If you manage to not properly dispatch your spectral foe, the backlash is absurd. Demons will kill you within a 3-5 second window unless you can scurry back to a hiding spot. However, once detected, the demons can see you in hiding spots; forcing you to shift between them as fast and erratically as possible until they give up. This turns what little combat there is into a game of Red Light, Green Light. These sections make no sense to the lore of the game either as there is no reason given as to why Ronan seems to be the only ghost that can dispatch the demons. No introduction is given to the power nor is it explained that Ronan is the only one capable of it, leading me to wonder why the other ghosts all flee in terror when the demons show up.The second game I'm reminded of is L.A. Noire, because the investigation sections are reminiscent of the ones in that game. You have to walk around the crime scene and collect the clues, using them to piece together the motive of the criminal. There are six to fourteen clues per scene but only three of them at most are ever necessary to continue. It's no secret that detective work is not as flashy or intriguing as it is portrayed in popular culture, but no where is this more obvious than video games. L.A. Noire had a good mix of action and detective work, due (I think) to it's structure. All the clues were relevant because solving the case was the goal of the mission and everything unfolded naturally. Murdered, by contrast, has you investigating glaringly obvious crime scenes which, more often than not, inform you of something you already knew. For example, one crime scene later on in the game has you investigating a room full of people the Bell Killer murdered all at once. At the point of investigation, however, you have already been made aware of what the killer did afterword, so the reason for killing the room full of people is obvious. Then, once you investigate the room, Ronan stands there and tells the the reason the killer did it, even though you already knew. Really the investigating is just being a master of the obvious. It's also impossible to fail to find all of the clues, because the game tells you how many are present in the scene.Murdered, like many games these days, would have probably made a better book or movie. The game play really just consists of different kinds of walking around and looking at things. Despite being a game made by an established developer and publisher, this is something any indie dev could have made, if not made look quite as good. In the end, games are meant to be interactive; that is what the medium excels at. Yet more and more it seems like games are being made with interactivity at the bottom of their priority list. Once during the middle of a cutscene I caught my self replying to text messages. It was then I realized how bored I was with the game; how absolutely unengaged I felt. The story was really not all that bad but being set in Salem, you can bet with reliability that it will have to do with what Salem is famous for. I would rather them have just made a movie out of it and cut out the game play entirely. At least then it would have taken me only 120 minutes to get through.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												The entire premise of this game is solid. The story is well done. The characters aren't half bad. The locations themselves are very well designed and it doesn't overstay its welcome (about 8 and a half hours to 100%). That being said take note that some problems exist (at least at the time of writing this "review")1. No key rebinding. At all. Unacceptable. Good thing I used a pad.2. If you miss any collectibles you can't go back and find them after completing the final sequence of the game. This game has over 200 collectibles. It honestly expects you to find them all in one go.3. V-Sync locks the game to 30FPS. Unlocked I didn't notice any tearing myself but YMMV. (Runs at over 100FPS maxed on a 2500k/12GB DDR3/670 @ 1920x1080 if you're curious about performance). 4. There are terrible tacked on demon fights in most chapters of the story. They add noting and just slow the game down. It's just a game of waiting for a demon to turn its back to you so you can come out of hiding and do a quicktime event. Absolutely. Pointless. Outside of that, it's pretty awesome and worth about $20-$30. It's no L.A. Noire but as far as detective games go it's not bad.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												While I do recommend the game overall, I have one major gripe with it: the demons. Having to fight them was, for me, a total distraction from the story. In short, they were supremely annoying. IMHO, the game would be much better without them.I have one other, less serious, gripe: the navigation system. At various times there is a pointer displayed that, supposedly, tells how far, and what direction,  it is to the intended destination. It's practically useless; truly annoying.On the positive side, the story is really good. The way the graphics are handled is also pretty clever. Some say it's similar to L.A. Noir. I've never played it so I can't compare. The movement mechanics for keyboard were good. It is a little slow at the beginning while trying to figure out what to do, and how to do it, but it picks up as you get into the story.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is another example, approving that Square Enix releases good solid games, but not AAA level. I waited for it, and although it did not meet all my expectations, it left me satisfied.First of all it a game of a rare genre nowadays - Adventure. Get rid of the demons and demon hands - and this is a pure non-combat quest. The closest example which appeared in my mind is Indigo Prohecy. Sometimes it's really pleasant to drop off your swords, guns, explosives, tanks, etc. and just listen to a good (mystic in this case) story, or since we're talking about the game - become a part of the story.The plot doesn't bring something new (or maybe it's me getting older), but it's interesting and keeps you involved till the end of the game, with a small twist. Thankfully, game is pretty short and does not get you bored - 16 hours in my case, BUT, this is becasue of the greatest minus of the game - it's terrible, random, sadistic check points. I had to exit the game after several hours of playing, and when came back to it about 30 minutes were gone. I had to rush into several side quests again aaand....caught a bug with Ronan falling through textures, reloaded, and repeated those 30 minutes.As far as I understand this is first succesfull project from Airtight Games. If they had more budget, city would be bigger, there would be more side quests, more reasonablo thoughts in the citizens' minds and more interactive objects. So I wish developers all that for their next project so it can become a real AAA game. For now, it's 7,5/10 (not enough for 8, better than just 7)

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												I liked the game, good graphic, nice soundtrack and immersive storyline (so far). I guess the only problem I found with the game was the lack of depth in gameplay (e.g. lack of difficulty settings, engaging combat systems and side quests). However that said, I really dig the story and aesthetic of the game as well as the classic who done it vibe. I reccomend this game for people who are looking for a interactive movie experience with a solid plot and expectionally good voice acting (IMO). I'd give this game 7.8 out of 10, because whilst the fundamentals of the game perform well, the lack of gameplay depth and overall quantity can take the shine off what is a generally wonderful experience.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												This game I feel appeals to people who enjoy story rich games. The gameplay is satisfying but nowhere near as enjoyable as that of LA Noire. Though it draws many comparisons to it I would say a gameplay format such as The Walking Dead would have done this game justice. The low score doesnt reflect the well written and intriguing story which this game relies on, but rather the repetitive and simple gameplay. Going into this game with the right expectations I feel you will definitely enjoy it. The concept is good just needs some difficulty improvements and the next installment in this series, in the hope there will be one, could easily become a popular franchise. Supplying 8 hours of gameplay, with some side missions which are just as enjoyable as the main storyline, I feel this is a game which all should experience assuming you are someone who just enjoys a good story.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I need to point out a bias, and that's that I love games that dare to be different. I have no heavenly idea whether it's the optimism or the bias itself speaking, but I really like this game! I'm sure you know what the game is about, you're an ex-"bad boy" who wanted to change your life, so you became a cop. Now, during an investigation, you got shot by a mysterious man who seems anything BUT normal. You now need to solve this wicked mystery of who that man is, to get your redemption. Don't worry, you won't get to hold a gun, exactly, so it's not your "average COD-clone".My personal opinion of the beginning- and middle parts of the story is that they were good.  The ending was the most disappointing part of the game, however. Extremely cheap and weak way to end the game.. and even if it was "cheap and weak", it left you with a whole lot of questions afterwards. I won't spoil anything But story was overall quite good.The world in itself, that you walk around in, is fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic! It is soooo cozy to walk around in a very Italian-like village during the night! But there's a huge flaw.. hugeeee flaw. The voice of the main character is painfully bad. He tries to do something Batman-like and deepen his voice way too low that it ruins everything. I don't know how to demonstrate this exactly, but when I was playing and heard him talk, my stomach hurt.. that's how bad this situation is!Other characters are somewhat lovable, and their animations & voice acting are all well done. HOWEVER, despite this game being "open-world" the elements that show this are abscent. There are missions you can do when roaming around such as helping a ghost solving their deaths, but I've only found three or four. Pathetic! And the collectibles aren't even worth thinking about. It does get quite scary at times as well, however, for you horror-lovers. I definitely recommend this game, in the end, though!7,5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a typical Square Enix title story-wise, however it falls short on game length, suspense based on its genre and some pretty slow controls. What do I mean by slow controls? I mean that walking is more like shuffling and the run option is nothing more than a fast paced walk. Granted you get a power later on that helps with that problem, but only to a point.The story is well presented but it still feels rushed and boring at times. The only thing that would make the gameplay any longer is by aquiring all the collectibles which I feel has had more time spent on than some more important parts of the game, both finding them and reading/watching them. This game is portrayed as a thriller and it hasn't failed on that part. However it also implies some horror elements that aren't really present, even with the "spooky" spectres.As my activity time shows, I've not spent long on this game. I'd say that the campaign is only around 3-4 hours long and all other time is spent simply getting the collectibles or completing the tiny amount of sidecrimes/cases that you can solve.All in all, this is getting a thumbs down. While the story is good, I can't help but feel that this game was rushed out to help with the new gen consoles rather than be a good game. I also don't think that with the small amount of time spent on thisgame it is worth the £24.99 price tag.

content:
Posted: March 19
												So... I love the idea of the story. Investigate your own murder, help other ghosts along the way. Superb premise. I play games for the story. I personally am not a fan of fight driven games, or games that constantly interrupt the story due to fights and battles inbetween. If the difficulty could be changed to "walk through the fight, so I can go on with my puzzles and story", then that would be ideal for me.As is, however, the controls are so infuriating that I stopped playing it in first chapter. Randomised-button-smashing-after-on-screen-prompt as a "battle" is not my description of fun, particularly when half the time the game doesn't react at all to the button usage even though you KNOW you have hit the right ones. In the right order. (edit: there is a function that lets you make the demons be completely unaware and they won't bother you. That at least let me play the game through to the end...)So, if you are after action, and battle and that tiresome interruption of the story, then yes, that games if for you and I can recommend it, because the graphics are amazing, and the idea behind it is great.Either way, if you are like me, a casual gamer that doesn't have a world of time and plays for exploration, story, puzzles, then no, this one is way too infuriating and I cannot recommend it. (Though, playable with Demon's off, it's bearable and I enjoyed it a tad bit more).Meh... Guess I'll stick to my "simple games" like Myst, Riven, Obduction, etc.

Posted: April 4, 2015
												5/10Best Part: Playing as a cat!Game with a lot of good ideas that got made by people who didnt know how to craft them into a good game-------I have bought this when it was on sale and since i really like these adventure games especially playing as a detective I just could not get into it. I was so bored... soooo bored. I did not expect another LA NOIRE but c'mon.. the best part was the intro video. It does have a very good story with interesting characters but it is so dull when you play it.It is sort of like this. You get into a location where you run around and picking up some totally useless things for revealing some sidestories which are interesting (some of them) but after picking up 5(/10/25) whatever they want (saw/papers/photographs) you go "OMG just give me the achievment and let me go". And the game starts telling you the whole sidestory while looking at some picture or something similiarily cheap.Some weird♥♥♥♥♥♥in the location where you run around belongs to the main story. But the point is same. You runnin around like an idiot and then go "HA! it wants me to push E" then you push E and then continue to run around. Then it asks you some totally dumb question and you got to connect some clues which would be interesting if the game would punish you for a wrong choice... You picked the wrong clue? Nevermind.. Pick another! So you can just click around cause it doesnt matter and answering questions like "Why did she go to church?" with an answer "I think she did go to the church" summs up the dullness of the "detective mechanics".Overall Murdered Soul Suspect looks like a game by someone who knows what makes a good game but doesnt know how to put it into his game. I can imagine somebody can get into this game and actually like it but I was so bored after 2 hours playing it.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												There's a lot of good to be found in this game, but it is ultimately let down by its length, scope, and incredibly frustrating 'combat' mechanics.You play as Ronan, a newly-deceased detective on the trail of the same serial killer that had just taken his life. In his new ghostly form, he possesses powers of teleportation, x-ray vision, and some other supernatural capabilities in addition to his police skills.The game is fully linear in nature with some detours (small side stories), but ultimately railroads players down a single, short path. Taking my time to look around, I ended up clocking just under 10 hours on my playthrough, but your mileage may vary here. In addition to basically being a one-track experience, the game heavily relies on collectibles to flesh out its characters, setting, and lore; a bad design decision as not everyone may be inclined to seek out every little hidden detail. All Steam Achievements are tied into this as well; if you collect all 242 collectibles, you have 100% completion outside of surviving the final 'boss battle'.Nonetheless, if you are a fan of murder mysteries, point 'n click games, and supernatural stuff in general, Murdered might be worth a look during a sale (you want to go for 90% off, like I did). That being said, don't expect a groundbreaking ride; interest in the aforementioned things will justify a cheap price tag on this game, but little more than that.If you have no strong interest in the above genres, steer clear of this game; short on content, zero replayability, horribly implemented and hamfisted combat, some bewildering design decisions, and suffocating linearity (with plenty of walls to stifle your progress) will kill most enjoyment you can get out of this game. Additionally, the developers closed down less than a month after release, which is pretty ironic considering the sense of wanting to get things over with the ending has about it. A shame considering the likable protagonist, but the closest the game comes to outright telling you you shouldn't have bothered.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												I heard good things about this game, and it's an interesting premise, but after three or four sessions I'm losing interest.  The gameplay typically involves wandering a room/area and picking up 16/16 random glowing points, for each you'll get a mostly uninteresting sentence to read "A police report.  Witness says the killer was wearing a hat.".  Then he'll come to a conclusion to move you to the next scene.  The dialogue is also typically very uninteresting.  You can read NPCs thoughts which should be cool, but each NPC has 2 useless dialogues, and they share the same dialogue with the other NPCs.  "It's so cold outside" "I don't feel safe with a killer on the loose" etc.  And everyone else who has unique dialogue is some kind of secret psychotic serial killer.  The demons are getting annoying.  My favorite part was a bit where you can "posess" and become a cat to access an area you otherwise couldn't.  The main character's backstory was interesting, but just poor implementation so far.  I'll probably push through and finish it, but I'm disappointed.

												Bought this one as part of a Humble Bundle.Pros- the story is quite satisfying, the intro is such that I actually said "WOW!" out loud, flashbacks are well done and interesting, backstory is well told- the main characters are quite fleshed out, especially Ronan (see what I did there?)- love the voice acting, it's quite good, even for minor characters- lots of collectables (if that's your thing)- performance is excellent, I did not encounter any bugs or technical problems what so ever, very polished- you get to be a catCons- combat is THE WORST, you basically have to walk up to the enemy (demon) and pass a QTE, if you fail, you can scramble to get out or (more often) stand there feeling helpless, VERY FRUSTRATING and the reason I'm uninstalling before finishing- gameplay (besides combat) is underwhelming, I've expected much tougher and more diverse puzzles- the city feels quite empty and samey, people's thoughts repeat and are otherwise boringTLDR enjoyed the story, left because of the combat which (I feel) shouldn't be in a adventure / puzzle game to begin with.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												When PC gamers complain about console ports, this is what they're talking about. The mouse and keyboard controls are terrible. It's full of quicktime events and unskippable noninteractive sequences. The dialogue between characters is full of weird inflections and unnatural pauses, like the dialogue was stitched together from people who weren't in the same room (which it almost certainly was).The first puzzle is "find 8 objects you can click on in this scene", and the gameplay is completely linear. With so many cutscenes, it's more like watching a terribly edited movie than playing a game.I wish I'd listened to the 59 on metacritic and avoided this stinker. I'm only an hour in, but I really can't take any more of this.

												Incredibly slow placed, visuals are lacking for a game being released now.Repetative and a little dull.Almost feels like you're on rails following a linear path with little to no interaction with anything aside from wandering around the same space for 5 minutes picking up different "clues"I got this free, which would normally make a game better.HA.I played this for a good couple of hours and uninstalled it, slow paced, wont get to the point.The whole concept is cool, solving your own murder, posession, moving through the void...But what this game essentially is, is awkward, awkward badly made and outdated.not to mention horrifically linear. The clues you collect are useless if you have any sense and pick up the obvious one first then you progress without any of the menial.. pick that up.. investigate this (by looking at it) move forward, now you can move to the next area, where you will do it again, and again, and again.There was one, amazing, feature that made some of the montany worth it...YOU COULD POSESS A CAT.for all of 5 minutes then you were straight back into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Don't spend money on this.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a typical Square Enix title story-wise, however it falls short on game length, suspense based on its genre and some pretty slow controls. What do I mean by slow controls? I mean that walking is more like shuffling and the run option is nothing more than a fast paced walk. Granted you get a power later on that helps with that problem, but only to a point.The story is well presented but it still feels rushed and boring at times. The only thing that would make the gameplay any longer is by aquiring all the collectibles which I feel has had more time spent on than some more important parts of the game, both finding them and reading/watching them. This game is portrayed as a thriller and it hasn't failed on that part. However it also implies some horror elements that aren't really present, even with the "spooky" spectres.As my activity time shows, I've not spent long on this game. I'd say that the campaign is only around 3-4 hours long and all other time is spent simply getting the collectibles or completing the tiny amount of sidecrimes/cases that you can solve.All in all, this is getting a thumbs down. While the story is good, I can't help but feel that this game was rushed out to help with the new gen consoles rather than be a good game. I also don't think that with the small amount of time spent on thisgame it is worth the £24.99 price tag.
