												This title looked fantastic when I first read about it and watched the teasers. Then I watched the first few minutes of gameplay, coupled with reviews, and (wrongly) came to the conclusion that is was a hidden object game/single-room puzzler wrapped in a 3rd person Unreal Engine. Not the case at all. While the puzzling is not brain taxing in the slightest, the story is interesting and the setting can be almost beautiful in places. There is no horror to be found, unless you found Peter Jackson's Frighteners scary. Were it designed for grown-ups instead of E for Everyone it could have been so much more.Despite it's flaws, I found it enjoyable and sometimes hard to put down.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												★★★★☆I had great fun with this game, the plot always had me playing to the next point to see what is going to happen. That said this is obviously a plot oriented game, everything you do is to further the plot or to give you more information that informs you in a direct or indirect way to what is happening, going to happen or has happened before. Don't expect any 3rd person shooter action in this game, that is not what it is about, it is about finding your murderer and running away (and sapping) demons. So no shooting, only talking and running XD.Okay now that that is all said and done, just a quick summary, it is a good game, definitely worth the money if you like mysteries. I would give this game a full rating but there were a few annoyances I had while playing. The textures are quite crappy in most cases, especially if the cutscenes would zoom up to the people talking, then you can see just how non "high quality" the textures are, but that’s still fine, I can get use to that. But what bugged me the most was that to play the game I had to launch it 5 times every time -_- because the game would automatically flag itself if is set to be fullscreen, for some bloody reason, so I had to open the game, close it, open it, close it, flag it open and close, open and close, and just hope it will not auto flag itself afterward.Now that said this game still gets a 4/5 from me :) enjoy, and hopefully you won't have the annoyance I did.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												So... this game...Well, I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, so I cannot complain about it as such - it was an interesting experience.HOWEVER, had I bought it as a stand-alone game on Steam, I'd be very dissapointed.Visually impressive (to a degree at least) the game is filled with a bit too many collectable quests (get X of Y to unlock something). The investigations are sensible 50% of the time - the other half just felt I was wrong becuase the scriptwriter went for a really surreal story. Finally, the ending... well, I don't wish to spoil things, but what a cop out. On the gameplay side of things... someone decided that to build tension they need to throw in demons into the mix (either in the form of demonic "pools" on the ground or "sentries" that patrol the area). Suffice it to say it doesn't build tension, but it does slow the pace even more, and is purely annoying. Oh, and speaking of the pace - I really wish the character could make a like a ghost and move faster. Getting anywhere is a pain.PS. The game is also buggy. Because the developer is long gone, don't hold your breath for a fix for any bugs you may encounter.

												A first impression here. It's not bad as some of the review sites out there might want you to believe. It's and adventure game, think LA Noire without the action and driving. It's a slower paced game where you'll have to look around for clues to solve puzzles to move to the next area, so if you're looking for an action FPS or something like that, it probably won't be for you. It's a good looking game with better graphics than watchdogs that I picked up last week, and has alot of graphics settings to play with, runs smooth on ultra/high on my HD 7870, although the frames per second seem to be locked to 30. I'd give it a 7 out of ten, it is kind of pricey though for what it is, but would definitely reccomend it at say $25.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Right then, I just finished the game.Let me start by saying that I like playing detective and love trying to solve puzzles on my own. I don't even mind if the graphics are bad, as long as the gameplay works and the plotline keeps me interested.When the game started I thought it seemed alright. The whole ghost detective trying to solve his own murder wasn't a bad idea and had quite some potential. Woe is me now, having paid 40 euros for something that lasted for 17 hours, and only so long because I kept on exploring the extremely limited environments that seem to be a trademark of Squaresoft's games these days. The player is guided by both arms like a blind and handicapped elderly through the mediocre and predictable story. God forbid anyone who pays good money for the game should have to think for themselves.And it's not just that. The whole game was more like getting from one lengthy cutscene to another. The only times you can screw up or die is when "battling" demons, and by battling I, of course, mean pressing two keys that show up on the screen in the correct order when close to a demon. How exciting.There was really only one thing I enjoyed in this game, and that was the first time I got to possess a cat. The cat's animations were done nicely and it was a fun idea. But really - not worth 40 euros. Another thing that was "ok" was the lead male's voice acting. It was not great, but it didn't get on my nerves either.At some point you gain an ability that made me think I might be able to roam the map more freely, but again I was to be disappointed. Most times I didn't even need this new ability to reach any places that were meant to be reached.I won't be recommending this game for anyone with half a brain.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Question: is Murdered a good game? Not really. Is it bad? Not at all. It's the defitintion of "average".You play as Ronan, a badass detective who wears a black fedora and a stupid vest and still managed to get married, who's following a lead to stop "the Bell" serial killer, who enjoys murdering women in pretty babaric ways. But the protagonist ends up dying in the first minute of the game and becomes a ghost. But not even this undead form can stop him to unravel this mistery and stop this murder once and for all with the help of Joy, a psychic teenagers who's looking for her mom. Also, she's a total ♥♥♥♥♥, almost as boring as the main character.The gameplay takes a lot of inspiration from L.A. Noire: you have to inspect the area to find clues to answer questions about murders or misteries. Except it doesen't do that stupid sound every time you're close to a clue; I can actually say that it's a bit improved in comparison of the Rockstar game. You can pass through certain walls to access secret areas, and trust me, there's a lot of secrets (about 240 in total).So, the detective mechanic are pretty fun, but sadly, the devs though it was a good idea to add some kind of fighting system. Sometimes, random flying demons will appear, announcing themselvs with a ♥♥♥♥ing loud scream that will♥♥♥♥♥♥your ears every single time; how to fight them? Go on their back and click 2 buttons. It's just a time-waster mechanic, and could have easly been removed.The mistery itself in the game is pretty ok, but honestly, I figured out most of it during the middle of the game, while Mr. Spoopi Detective realized only at the end. THOSE MURDEREDS ARE CONNECTED? AND IT'S ABOUT WITCHES? IN THE CITY OF SALEM?! WHAT A COINCIDENCE! ..Yea, is pretty lacking story whise, and most of the characters are pretty obnoxious.Music is almost non existent in this game, so I can't really recommend anything from the soundtrack.Even tho this game is not that great, I can't help but recommend it. But why? Because at least is trying to do something different. Sure, it's borrowing a lot of mechanic and ideas from other games, but at least it's really trying to bring something that is not a classic story "kill the bad guys and win the lady". Sure, you might argue that it's kinda following that path, but it's the way they're getting there that at least is trying to be different.Final Score: 6/10I highly suggest to pick this game up during a sale, or if you have the chance, get it for cheap at humblebundle.com

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Got this game for free when I purchased my video card. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective game set around the site of the former Salem Witch trials where you are a ghost stuck in limbo until the you can resolve everything in regards to your death (namely, identifying the killer). The story is moderately enjoyable, and the ending twist regarding your death genuinely surprised me. Didn't care for the time spent in between crime scenes, as things tended to drag, and the collectables are more of a hassle than anything. Since the story only lasts for 7-8 hours and the game doesn't have much replayability, I can not recommend buying at the $50 price. Look into playing once it hits a major sale on Steam.

number of helpful: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												MURDERED isn't really a game. It's more of an interactive story/movie with movement, It has a very interesting premise, but in my opinion it failed to deliver on that punch which it desperately needed and strived for.For the "gameplay" mechanics, you basically find crime scenes, try to find and examine every object, then have infinite tries to choosing the correct ones that apply to move the story along. Sometimes this involves influencing people by possessing them, but that's only during scripted moments and does nothing useful when you possess the NPCs walking around the world. It's the same when you "poltergeist" an object (turn it on/mess it up for a few seconds). Lifeless NPCs will not react unless it's a scripted moment for the story.There are enemies in the game, demons, and you can walk behind them and try your hand at a randomized QTE where you'll have to press one button from WASD and use the left or right click to destroy the demon. If you fail, which you will due to the poor controls of this, then you'll have to jump into ghost fragments around the level to avoid getting your soul sucked until the demon gives up. This is all of the "action" in the story and it's more of a waste of time than anything. There is no boss fight or no real reason for destroying demons. Their AI is on a predetermined route and they're just an inconvenience for scouring a level for the collectible items.Each area has a different amount of collectibles. These unlock urban legend/ghost stories that are just a picture and a person monologuing. That's really it for the entire game's mechanics outside of possessing a cat and following a predetermined route with no real obstacles/puzzles. There's literally nothing interesting to do in this game beyond solving the main storyline with its pre-determined deductivity.  All in all, I can't recommend this as a game. If you're looking for the great supernatural mystery thriller of our time this is far from that. But if you're looking to chance it for a story that you may (or may not) enjoy and you're willing to overlook about 8 hours of lacking gameplay, this one on the cheap might fit that bill. Treat it more like an average-grade movie than a game.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Murdered Soul Suspect is the last game made by Airtight games, Did the go out with a bang ? In Murdered Soul Suspect you play as Ronan o connor. Salem is haunted by a serial killer named the Bell killer. One day Ronan Finds the trail of the bell killer but gets killed in the process. Ronan returns as a ghost but hes unable to move on until he finds out who killed him. In the proccess he meets Jane who the killer is trying to hunt down. So its youre job to protect her from the killer while trying to find out who killed you. So how is Murdered ? Its actually a great game. The best way i could put it would be a supernatural LA Noire. The game is essiantly you interogating ghosts and people who can see you know as mediums. The game lets you posses people and cats. Mess with electronics and stuff like that. Theres also fighting segments where you have to fight ghost while trying to aproach them from the back. But if they see you you will have to hide because you cant fight them head on. So now for the pros and cons. The game has a great story and a great twist ending. The game is fun and simple. Great puzzles to solve and tons of collectibles to collect. The cons: the game is kinda glitchy and its also really short. Overall Murdered Soul Suspect is a great game and i suggest you buy it because simply put it its a great game and Airtight Games will be missed. I give Murdered Soul Suspect a 8/10

content:
Posted: February 28
												Would have been okay if it came out 10 years ago. Key word being "okay".Average to bad story, bad acting, not as cheesy as it should have been (big missed opportunity there), and lots of 'collect all the♥♥♥♥♥♥ which is usually my jam, but even that feels messy and arbitrary.Speaking of 10 years ago, I would recommend something like Fahrenheit instead, which still blows this out of the water.On the other hand, if you want to play a $50 game that really takes ZERO brain cells to process, both in story and gameplay, this is the game for you my friend!update: Finished the game (which thankfully speeds up in pace at the end, but still doesn't get an upgrade to recommended from me), and saw that the credits feature a Japanese dev team! This actually explains a lot. It really feels like a eastern interpretation of a western crime story - they pick up every cliche and trope, the cheesiest characters, but approach it completely straight faced. No irony, no self awareness. I wish they'd felt more free to inject more of their own personality.Now it sits in no-mans land, the equivalent of a western attempt at an anime or a JRPG.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												So clearly not recommending this game, this Review is being written in 2016 and should be noted as such, if your thinking of buying this game just go for something else.This game is basically a detective story in 3rd person where you hunt for clues to piece together the bell killer murders and find out who the murderer is.The main part of the "game" part of this game, is annoying little demon sections where you have to go up behind a demon and exorcise them, these have really crappy AI and mostly just detract from the story (the main reason to play this kind of game), looking a little too low? these demons won't register, will turn around and notice you, and you will have to hide from them till they get bored and go back to doing their rounds, and this element just feels added for the sake of actual gameplay (even though the story does technically cover it, it's a really loose connection.As for the Actual main story, while part of it is obvious, the true answer is basically a massive cop out, and as this is spoiler free i won't actually be able to say why, but once you have played this game, you will be dissapointed by the ending.Other then this, it's basically a fetch quest where you look for clues and work out which few are actually even relevant (each section requires no more then 4 clues to do any one part, and you can then move on) and it mostly just becomes find the relevant spot and look at it.I finished this game in about 6 Hours (although steam doesn't seemed to have registered my play time properly) and was rather disappointed, i'm glad i bought this through a humble bundle, as i didn't end up paying the $20 price tag, which realistically is asking a bit much for something like this.Without all the filler stuff this could easily be a 2 hour game but you spend most of your time walking around and playing hide and seek with demons.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												MURDERED has a cool concept and plot: You have been murdered and trying to solve your own murder as a ghost. What is not cool, however, is how repetitive and confusing this game can get.The game is a glorified movie with a few cuts of brain-dead gameplay here or there. Your objective will tell you to go to a location. Then you will use to stealth to kill some demons, then you will pickup all the clues to solve a few "questions" which lead you to another location. Rinse and repeat a few times.The crux of the game should be solving hard puzzles, but most puzzles are just wandering around a small room and mashing 'E' on everything to 'reveal' it. Then you have unlimited tries to put the 'clues' together (there is NO penalty for guessing wrong, not even a special perfect ending). Additionally, the demon fighting game play is ridiculously easy. I realized half-way through that you could actually run past every demon without fighting them. In other words, there is no challenge.One final thing I didn't like: No mini-map in-game. It turns out you only could get a mini-map if you PREORDERED the game (for something so core you would think it would just come with the game). If you are a completionist this makes collecting everything a living hell. Every wall in the town looks the same. And some collectibles don't appear unless you go along all the walls and mash a button (in other words, this is near-impossible without a guide).

content:
Posted: March 24
												This is easily the best game i've ever played! Granted, i am a strickly point and click gamer where there is a distinct beginning and end, and crime stories are definitely my favorite, but with that said, i have never played a game so incredibly clean and well-written. There was only one glitch that i ran into, and it didn't keep me from completing the game. It had to do with a side story, and although i usually like to be thorough in the games i play, i let it go and moved on (i had no choice unless i wanted to start over, which i definitely didn't want to do because i was well into the game). The graphics were amazing, the voiceover fantastic, and the story was intriguing and kept me interested to the very end. And to top it off, the ending surprised me. All in all i couldn't have enjoyed a game more (except for the glitch)

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												I've had this game in my library for like 3 years now and I haven't bothered to even install it once. Recently I figured that I would play it because I had nothing else better to do and I had seen a few short gameplay videos. It's a game by Square Enix, one of my favourite publishers and it's got moderately good graphics so I'm able to play it Ultra and in 4K resolution.Firstly the premise seems cool enough, but also pretty simple. You play a detective who's been killed and you have to find out who killed you. No problem there, as I always like a good 'whodunnit' story.The problem is everything else except the story.CONTROLS - The controls are so annoying to use. I had to turn the sensitivity down so low to avoid the camera spinning around like a tornado. You also walk so slowly, and are forced to constantly hold run 100% of the time if you even want to get anywhere within a reasonable timeframe; having to always hold shift also made my pinky get sore fast. All of these things make the game quickly feel very cumbersome to play and my patience really started to wear thin...GAMEPLAY - There's no 'crosshair' but you have to perfectly directly face an object so it is in the middle of your screen in order to interact with it. Due to being a ghost, you can walk through many solid looking objects which is cool until you realise that there is also no kind of map in the game at all. Paths are constantly 'hidden' bethind objects that you have to walk through, and it's very hard to remember where something is. If you missed something way back at the start of the area, you can go back provided you can find your way through the confusing and very narrow/linear path from one area to another. The game is also filled with pointless empty alleyways and dead-ends that I really could not understand at all why the developers didn't bother to make any sort of map. It would have made navigation so much easier. Finding clues and collectables in Murdered: Soul Suspect is a huge part of the game, but sadly it's very hard to spot some mission related clues do to the objects being absolutely tiny, and/or partially hidden.ENEMIES - There aren't really any except for these 'demons' that lurk around some areas of the game, and 'traps' that just force you to find a way around them. Demons are more of an annoyance than a challenge. Simply hide behind a wall or in a 'safe zone' until they come close enough, then when their back is turned press the right combination to kill them. The combinations are a total pain as you have to keep holding the 'R' button AND then press 2 other buttons at the same time which are often very close to the 'R' button. Getting it wrong means wasting a few minutes whilst the Demon chases you or looks for you. They're incredibly easy to kill as you can spot them through walls and there's often plenty of places to hide. Honestly I found them a pointless addition to the game and just something obviously added to try and increase the overall length of a playthrough.STORY - The story is good enough I guess. Some of the side missions seem stupid and some of the murder/death mysteries are quite boring really. I found it kind of hard to care about a few of the NPCs but at the same time I guess a couple of them were interesting enough. The main story seems interesting enough so far and so long as it's about the same length as 'The Wolf Among Us' I will be pretty happy. I still prefer TWAU's gameplay and smoothness to this game's by far.GRAPHICS - Not much bad to say here as graphics are pretty top notch. The game looks really nice in 4K, although I found that some of the floating papers got a bit distracting as I often mistook them for clues that I could interact with. Also the game is capped at 30FPS if you enable Vertical Sync which made it feel really, really choppy for me. A huge part of the game are also pre-rendered cutscenes which are also all capped to 30fps. So if you end up playing in 60+ FPS normally and then move to a cutscene you can end up getting eye fatigure and a general nagging feeling as the game changes framerates constantly. Finally I thought that it was kind of annoying that a lot of the NPCs don't have proper lip movements when they are speaking. This is something that Square Enix usually does really well, but in this game a lot of NPCs just stand there going through their limited behaviour animations with their mouths closed but they are still speaking.ABILITIES - These are actually pretty boring and feel really lackluster. The first ability you get is to be able to possess people in order to read their minds or try and jog a memory that helps uncover part of the story. Murdered: Soul Suspect has a lot of NPCs in some areas, and using the mind-reading ability shows really how little thought was put into the game. ALL NPCs only have TWO possible dialogues that can be uncovered through reading their minds. Specific NPCs have specific and more 'unique' dialogues however NPCs that do nothing except to just 'populate' the game world almost always all have the same "I don't feel safe here" etc. responses. It's really boring. As for the other features like Reveal, this is just used to uncover small side stories and Teleport is only used to get into 'consecrated' areas that would normally be off-limits.There's not much else to talk about but all in all I wouldn't recommend the game. The graphics are good and the story is interesting enough but the game quickly becomes a total pain to play. My fingers get sore, my patience runs thin and even the uniqueness of the game and the lingering mystery to uncover doesn't hold my attention for more than a few short hours at a time. More than anything I can't help but feel that a few changes or extra small additions to the game would have yielded a much smoother experience. Things such as a small map, faster walking and running, and increased amount of dialogue in the game would have added a lot of value.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												This review will be in separate parts when ever I want to complain about the game. But every bit of this review is constructive criticism.First three areas explored in:I am already offended by this game for its lack of social construction. This game's dialogue seems to have bits and pieces of an idea together but are poorly sewn together. If you are a private investigator or an FBI profiler you will be saddened by this game. For the dialogue choices seem to route you to the same answer, but are shallow in complete thought. I get the idea behind this game being the main story line but my problem with this game so far is not your maneuverability, or lack of direction. But more or so to the approach this game takes when it comes to solving the cases. It seems like the person who created this plot forgot that detectives constantly talk to themselves while piecing together a story. Though to be fair it says in the text right there what it wants you to do. But it should be stated by the detective to help people figure out what is going on. The text floating around as you try to piece things together will throw you off guard as soon as a change of course happens within the solving of each small puzzle.While trying to figure out one thing it suddenly switches... but our friend the detective doesn't say much and it quickly moves on to the next thing. So you miss what the text changed to, telling you what you are supposed to look for now, at that very split second given moment and you guess wrong. Worst of all is the clunky UI. You mess something up it freezes you... pauses.... backs out.... brings up several different separate tab screens for each object which suddenly takes away the purpose for searching it, (which is why I say again it would help if the detective was constantly talking to himself in thought to keep the main point in focus.) And quite frankly leaves me bewildered at what happens when you "try again."Maybe the approach to this method should have used better sorting options.... Throwing things around all the time makes me think this detective never carried around so much as a book. Possibly carried around a recording device seeing how disorderly everything being displayed becomes.Just imagine that every time you came up with the idea behind a string of events you got angered, and suddenly threw up all the information you just looked at in frustration... only to come right back to it, to string everything together again, as all the papers fall to the ground and you have this game. I think the creator... if he is or was a detective... must have had little to no patience himself in each case. Possibly due to extra ordinary means like time or money allotted to his investigations. Maybe a sergeant or person's interest was a timely manner. I am still willing to give this a second try but it is so demanding on your eyes, more or so than your brain, that it causes you to lose concentration quite easily.And the demons? My goodness. Talk about an annoying trap puzzle that springs up like a jack in the box that malfunctions a lot. I get the idea behind exorcising ghosts... but uh.... how does our detective friend just suddenly know how to exorcise a ghost exactly? Was our friend the detective a priest? There is no mention of him being one in his own background... But just barely minutes into the game, you have the ability to exorcise a ghost without having to read any books about it. I think this game would have been a lot more interesting with the setup it seemed to hold. In which I think the Detective originally did not know how to exorcise ghosts until later in the game. But I guess the devs thought it would be too annoying to make players fear them so early. Yet it would have been a lot more fun and made more sense if the ability wasn't there until you figured it out.This game seems to be targeted at kids more or so than adults seeing how there are some "way too soft" spots that spring up like a bad smell. You will literally yell at our detective to "JUST GRAB HER F***ING ARM!" When it comes to solving one of the cases. I want to slap the detective for being so.... retentively sympathetic, yet wise cracking at certain times.Also the girl? Best idea ever when it comes to surprising your audience when you finally meet her for the first time. But there was one inconsistency that happened at the cemetery... She complained about not being able to see him... even though she was holding a flashlight... Then a few minutes later she has no trouble seeing them. Could have been the lamp post nearby but uh.... She did shine a flashlight on him.Last three bits:Am I ever more disappointed in a game? This game answered that question. Incredibly short game. I am sad. I am so sad after completing this game.The best puzzle is the ending.I think the issue is that the development team behind this had an astonishingly awesome idea.... but I think budget cuts really let this game down. This game had some real potential but it is so short lived. The ending seems to be pasted together. But at least it did create one hell of a mind ♥♥♥♥. It is just too bad the whole time you believe one thing because of your own abilities... and then there is another. What the hell.Too short. Way too short. My final complaint? Some of the "side missions" are broken.This game should be twitch viewed only.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												A lot of the games that I rate "thumbs down" are just mediocre and still have redeeming qualities. This game, on the other hand, is literally the worst game I've ever played. Took me just over 5 hours to finish it and it overstayed its welcome.The story is actually OK - not great, but a decent B-horror-movie tale. It does have a pretty good red herring followed by a nice twist at the end. However, one aspect of the villain's identity is very clearly telegraphed. The plot is pretty simple - you're a homicide detected who is killed by the serial killer you're hunting. Now relegated to ghost form, you try to track down the killer.The gameplay, however, is abysmally weak. Gameplay has two phases - investigations and stealth. Investigations involve peeking into people's minds and observing supernatural objects. Stealth involves avoiding demons and helping your (live) AI companion sneak into locations by creating distractions. The basic problem with both is that they are essentially hidden object games - all you need to do to progress is to find the correct button to press. The game never gets any more complicated than this. There are a few sections where you have to do things with correct timing, but they're very easy. In reality, you spend the entire game walking around and clicking on things. Occasionally, you will be asked to identify the "relevant" clues out of a crime scene with numerous clues scattered about. If you pick incorrectly, you're just told you were wrong and given the chance to try again. So that means that your "investigations" can be beaten by simply picking clues at random until you get them right. That means this so-called "mystery" game has no actual mystery to it. What's the fun in a detective game where you aren't allowed to be misled? Calling this a mystery game at all is misleading - it's a glorified walking simulator. You couldn't possibly make a mistake. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter has far more actual mystery than this.The game is so brainless and holds your hand so much that at times I felt like I was playing one of the simple educational games you find on Steam, like "The Deer." It's dumbed-down to the point of utter boredom, start to finish.Technically, I guess it's fine, runs fine and looks decent for a last-gen console title. Controls are OK with both M+KB and with controller, which is to be expected when the game has such a limited amount of interaction.The only reason I played this to completion was because I didn't want to feel like I wasted my money. That makes me a sucker. Don't be a sucker like me. Avoid this game.

												Murdered: Soul Suspect was surpsingly enjoyable game, despite it being very game-y (which is somehow odd to see in era of AAA MOVIE-LIKE BLOCKBUSTERGAEMS).Sure, it didnt have the most amazing new mechanics, but I kinda liked it. It has its problems and I can see why some could give it 80 or 70.´"Problems" include things like: linear levels and narrow corridors, the animation is bit clunky and there is random stuff blocking your way without trying to "hide it" at all. Its really obvious that ghostwall (get it, hur?) is up there to block you. NOTE: when you finish the game there is no "go back to get last achievements!" thing. Once you get into "last room", you gotta start all over again if you missed achievements/sidequests.It aint AAA game by todays standards. If this was released early at PS3 or late PS2-era, it would fit right in. Now its slightly feeling like indie studio who is trying to get into deep story with still bit of clunkiness on the gameplay and design part.The story is a bit predictable at points, does have nice plot twist. But overall it was fairly enjoyable.But..you actually feel like playing A GAME.For me this is actually refreshing. It doesnt try to hide it I guess. Its game with story, not "movie story with game mechanics".

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												MSS is pretty much a PNC adventure game masquerading as a modern cinematic AAA game (which I don't find any better, by the way).  While the game has merit for any adventure game fan, know that the story falls apart and I doubt anyone will be satisfied with it.  So with such a major hook of pnc games not really delivering, what are you left with?At its heart, MSS is your typical textbook modern game design, except the main character doesn't carry a gun and you don't run around shooting at pop-up targets.  Instead, you are tasked with investigating your own death, complete with spritely sidekick and canned TWEEST.  This in itself isn't bad as mysteries often need to have at least some sort of turning point and well, being dead kind of demands you have a real-world sidekick to help you out.However, being of modern game design, MSS falls into the trap of checklist design; that is to say, it takes no risks and does pretty much everything by the book.  Exploration?  Check.  Voice actors?  Check.  Cinematics?  Check.  Hidden objects?  Check.  Progessive ability unlocking?  Check, check, check.  None of this bad, really; just saying it brings nothing new to the table.  The worst offender is the checkbox for action - because why would anyone play a game without action in it, right?  Pfft.  From time to time you will be forced to deal with a completely useless and forced section where you sneak around bad guys and try to get rid of 'em (or circumvent them entirely once you're tired of this♥♥♥♥♥♥ because someone in development land has decided that under no circumstance should a game of this type be without an action sequence; problem is, it's stupid and provides nothing to the game other than padding and, of course, a checkbox.  Similarly, you'll be tasked several times to arbitrarily click on multiple clues to proceed through the game and it gets old fast - at least it's thematically sound what with the main character being a detective.  Whatever.Anyways, as far as fans of PNC games goes, this one isn't that bad.  The game has a runtime of approximately 8 hours, maybe 6.5 if you don't bother looking for all the hidden stuff (which is also pointless, but allows you to do some checklisting yourself).  I wouldn't recommend getting this at full price in any shape or form, but if you get a decent deal on it, say... $10 just to cover some of the production value, then why not give it a run-through?  It's kind of like watching the latest sci-fi space opera film just because you don't often see them being made and not because it's actually really good.  MSS is just a decent effort.tl;dr: Adventure game fans may enjoy this game on theme alone, but anyone looking for a meaty game experience will find that this offering is leaner than that girl you used to know whose bones could be counted individually when she had her shirt off.  So this remains a (meh) thumbs-up for adventure game fans, but a thumbs-down for anyone else.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Awesome game. Reminded me of both "Fahrenheit" and the movie "Ghost". I see a lot of idiots misread the genre and poured out their virginity in a form of a negative bs, learn to read, ffs. It's action adventure!There are no puzzles in traditional point-and-click sense. It's mostly about gathering stuff and making some obvious choices.Nice graphics, not top of the line but very nice.Had no issues with controls whatsoever. It is THE MOST standard keyboard layout for modern games (for a right handed people that is).The plot has a few holes in it but otherwise is pretty solid and engaging with a twist at the end.And not a single bug through the whole game. That's a rarity these days.So I just have no idea what those kids with their negative reviews are whining about.The game is good and it's well worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I am a casual female gamer, not great with button mashing. I really love rich story lines, rpg styled play, and puzzles! This game included all of that. If you're casual like me, it's a great point and click that isn't boring. Too often I find the point and clicks are slow paced, but this isn't. Most of the game is really innate. You know what your goals are and what you have to do. I rarely needed to look something up, so that's a plus for the casual gamer. The storyline is reallllly cool, the characters, the voice acting, all of it. My only negative is I didn't clue in to just how open the world was. You can explore a lot and do side quests and I missed a lot of them because I was only following the storyline. Newb mistake for sure, so be sure you do all the fun stuff on the side to get all the achievements. Graphics and controls were great.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												I was actually enjoying this game until I encountered a game-breaking glitch near the end of Chapter 2. What I assume I was supposed to do was use my poltergeist ability on the vacuum to get the priest to walk over the vortex thingy on the floor so I could possess him and safely cross to the other side of the hallway.As it turns out, the priest decided to be a bishop, in the sense that he only moved diagonally. He crossed over and clipped into the wall opposite the vacuum cleaner, and when I possessed him he moved diagonally across the vortex, clipped into another wall, and walked in a courtyard where I could not unpossess him.I tried restarting the checkpoint. I tried letting the priest make a single trip and then using poltergeist on the vacuum a second time before possessing him. I tried starting the game over from the beginning. I tried reinstalling the game. I even tried starting the game from the beginning AFTER reinstalling, but nothing worked.So I checked Google for answers, but couldn't find any solutions. That's when I gave up. Even if there is a solution, I refuse to sit through the same unskippable cutscenes for a fourth time in the hopes that maybe I'll be able to get past the second chapter.If you're thinking of buying this game, don't. There's an old flash game on Newgrounds called "The Dead Case", which is similar yet vastly superior despite being from 2004. Not only is it free, but it actually functions like it's supposed to.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												There's a reason this game gets so many bad reviews.  It's not that it's necessarily a bad product, but it's a bad GAME.  Virtually all of the gameplay elements serve to do nothing but force interactivity; they don't really add anything substantial to the product.  There are little forced "stealth" segments, some elements of old school pixel-hunting games, a very Vampire Bloodlines-feeling "open world" hub section, etc.But, ultimately, I don't think they add anything to the product, and in most cases actually detract from it.  The plot isn't going to win any awards, but it's competent.  The voice actors are all at worst competent, the art direction is fine, and the setting is kind of fun if you like the supernatural stuff.The problem is that this could've been a movie for all the significance of the actual interactive parts have.  That's why I keep referring to it as a product, and not a game.  Because I don't feel like Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game for the same reasons I don't think Gone Home is a game.  Or, rather, because I feel like Murdered is cramming in a bunch of random gameplay elements to make us BELIEVE it's a game... when it's really not.I would never, ever recommend paying anywhere near full price for this product, but if you can get it for a few bucks on a Steam sale or in a Humble Bundle like I did, it's a decent enough way of using five or six hours of your time.

												A gem of a game, not what I expected at all. It has innovative gameplay, an original storyline, and damn detailed side quest gameplay (also if you have a decent rig to play this on...well the graphics and effects are top shelf). In the end if you like crime solving games with a splash of supernatural... this game is well worth it. I highly recomend it indeed.-Side Note (metascore);-For the first time I really question the metascore, critics reviewing this baffle me... the users reviews are a bit more on par and fairer in their assessment... I guess in the end just watch some let's plays and see what your close friends think of it and thats that.

content:
Posted: April 14
												I can't really recommend this one, as its a cutscene point and click adventure that isn't point and click with "action" that isn't action (sneak up behind something and press R).  The main plot is okay, but it would be much more enjoyable if you didn't have to stop and pick up the collectionables along the way.  Some places you can't re-enter, so waiting until the end (pre-finale) won't work.  There is also the not-too-hot save system, which is autosave after picking up a collectable or at a checkpoint in the main plot - side quests don't create an autosave.  There also isn't an exit save.  I'd give this a 5/10, if bought cheap.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Not a bad game... Thought I feel like this could have been a much superior experience with a little more effort... The core concepts definitely work, and the interaction between a living character and a ghost make for interesting gameplay situations... The game's key failing is in its actual interaction during investigations - you essentially look at things, and click on them, with very occasional sections where you select the most likely explanation of a given situation. This is woefully inadequate for a game that is supposedly about solving the mystery of your own death. I'd confidently state that this is pretty much a zero-difficulty game with no significant challenge except that of avoiding the irritating demons.The game has decent voice acting, yet some pretty ropey cutscenes, interesting ideas and systems, but inadequate use of them, a dreadful cut & paste soundtrack, but reasonable sound design. It could have been better, but that said, this game is still worth your time, so long as you don't buy it full price.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect sees you take on the role of Ronan O’Connor, a felon turned detective. Roman is tasked with solving one of the most complex murders that he has come across… His! Yes, that’s right, the game starts as Ronan is killed by someone known only as ‘The Bell Killer’. I’m not going to spoil the story for you lovely people who are interested in buying it, but will stress that the story is enjoyable. Look out for Joy, who gets to become an accomplice of Ronan’s throughout the story. Their relationship is well scripted by the developers and really flourishes throughout the game as they help each other solve a mystery or two. I must say that when i thought i know who the killer is, I was genuinely surprised.Usually being dead in a game is not a state you want to be in. However, Murdered: Soul Suspect turns that statement completely on its head, giving you several advantages and powers. It’s fair to say that Roman is a better detective dead than he was alive LOL Well, I must say that I missed a game with a good and catchy story. And oh, we can possess cats!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I Pre-Ordered this game and was worried when I started to read reviews. I installed it Friday and decided to fire it up last night and see if it was as bad as I've read. Let me tell you that "professional" reviews don't know what they are talking about, some franchasies with annual releases continue to get 80-90% every year for the same game. New games with new ideas often get trashed.My initial trail was intended to be to check the opening scenes, I found myself getting pulled in and played for more than 3 hours straight. I can't wait to continue this game. They premise and story is very cool so far, the main character is well acted and the other actors are ok too. I can really see this game being a cult classic if it continues to be as good as the first few hours. It isn't perfect, there are some cheesy or wierd things. The possession stuff, especially the cats is very chessy and seems to be a step down in quality from the rest of the game. The side quests seem cool but usually are unrewarding, I find myself collecting all the items and I enjoy the spoken story at the end but the static picture feels cheap and it would have been awesome to have some animated stories, even animated comic frames would have been a huge increase. The jump to pre-renedered cutscenes isn't terrible but can be a bit jarring, it would have been nice to see it renedered in game since it does appear to use the game engine but the subtitles are a bit blurry becuase it appears it may have been recorded in a lower resolution like 720P.This reminds me of older point and click adventure games where you have to find clues but uses a modern 3D engine and it works pretty well. The game also looks pretty good, and runs well. I can easily max the game out at 1600P with no problem on my computer.I don't think I have ever written a Steam review but I had to for this under rated gem. The game so far is a solid 7.5/10 for me, it seems interesting and overall pretty fun. I've been getting bored with the same old games recently and it is nice to see a different take. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this game, I think a lot of people would like it and I think the review scores are misleading.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												My review of Murdered: Soul Suspect:ATTENTION: This review is long, so you can just skip to the conclusion if you'd like.I always liked supernatural fiction.That's why I took an interest in Murdered: Soul Suspect when it was first shown, back in 2013.First of all, I have to say that this game is unique.Where else can you find a detective game where the main protagonist is a ghost? Answer: You can't.Murdered: Soul Suspect is more than just a detective game.It's a story about Ronan O'Connor, a detective that was killed at the beginning of the game during an investigation, and became a ghost.Now, as a ghost, he has to find his killer in order to finish his unfinished business in this world, and be at peace with himself so he can go on to the next world and be with his dead wife, Julia, once again.The killer is called "The Bell Killer", a serial killer that roams the streets of the town Salem.The killer was searching for something in an apartment building when Ronan interrupted him and wanted to make an arrest, until the killer overpowered him and threw him out the window, badly injuring Ronan. Ronan becomes a half ghost as he's about to die, and when he wants to get back to his body, the killer shoots him several times, thereby killing him.Ronan became a full ghost immediately after. Later, Ronan meets Joy, a medium who's looking for her missing mother.She helps Ronan find the killer because her mother is possibly connected to the killer in a way, and by finding him, they will possibly find her too, so they help each other.The story is an excellent detective story, with great characters that are well voice acted, but it's really short. It only took me about 6-7 hours to complete, which is not enough.So, after you die, you immediately jump into the ghost-detective action.Since you're a ghost, you can't physically touch anything, which could be a problem when you want to investigate further, but as a ghost, you can do certain things you wouldn't be able to do as a human, such as possessing people and eavesdropping on their conversation, or influencing witnesses into remembering what happened at the crime scene. You can analyze evidence which will give you more clues about the case as well. Ronan also has the ability to see the memories of victims through their ghost residue, which helps him see exactly what happened at the crime scene. All of these will help you solve cases, and it's executed pretty well in the game.On the other hand, the choices you make as a detective are meaningless, since you will eventually make the right choice no matter what, and there is no grading and EXP system to motivate you to do your best. It's really disappointing.As for the town of Salem, Massachusetts, it's a really, really small town. It's so small that it kind of makes it hard to believe that there's actually a serial killer in this town. Also, the game gives you the feeling of a semi-open world game, which in reality, there's so little to do in Salem when you're not playing through the main missions.The only side quests in the game involve helping other ghosts finish their unfinished business, which means finding the truth about their deaths. It’s pretty neat. Aside from that, there are a ton of collectibles scattered around for you to find, and if you collect enough of them, you will know more about the people that lived in Salem in the past.There's also a side case for Ronan's life with Julia, which tells a lot about Ronan's past.Lastly, there is a side case which includes special collectibles that are hidden in the main areas of the game, which, if you collect all of them, will uncover stories about ghosts that are haunting those places, and also each place has its own collectibles that tell you about the history of the place, but, that's about it for the side content.By the way, you can also possess a cat which will get you get to certain places you can't normally reach, which is pretty cool.One thing I didn't like in the game was the demon encounters.Demons, as the game explained, are lost souls that stayed in this world, and they're the only enemy you'll ever encounter in the game. They can only be killed stealthily by executing them from behind, and if they see you, they will chase you. The only thing you can do in this situation is hide from them in ghost residues. They will come looking for you in them, so you have to switch between one residue to another in order to avoid them, until they will eventually stop looking for you.Sounds exciting? I didn't think so. It's utterly boring, and I would prefer if it wasn't in the game at all.Luckily, there are only a few demon encounters in the whole game.When you play through the game, you are accompanied by a creepy, intense soundtrack, like one from a horror movie when there's a scary scene. It's fantastic, and it immerses you into the dark and gritty atmosphere, and the great number of ghosts haunting the town makes it even more immersive.Speaking of atmosphere, the visuals in the game are fantastic. Textures are great, although I did encounter a few texture pop-ins when playing the game, and I had a few frame rate issues at certain points, but that's it.The dark atmosphere makes the game look amazing, and the graphics looked great on my PC.Overall, the game is a good adventure game, but it had so much more potential, and it could have been an amazing game if it had been done right.While Murdered: Soul Suspect definitely has its unforgivable flaws, it tries to compensate for them with its great narrative and the amazing atmosphere, though with not great success.It's not a horrible game by any stretch of the imagination, but it's not an amazing one either, and it certainly didn't live up to my expectation.Pros:+ Great story+ Incredible atmosphere and soundtrack+ Side cases are interesting+ Great graphicsCons:- The game is short- Boring enemy encounters- Choices as a detective are meaningless- The town is really smallMy final score for Murdered: Soul Suspect is 6.5/10.I would wait for a big discount before buying the game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Just finished the game. Over all, it was pretty neat. The graphics were nice and the story was pretty interesting. While I thought the dialogue might be a little cheesy, it was bearable and I have no real complaints about it. I enjoyed playing a ghost detective and getting to posess and influence people to get what I needed. Also, the demons you come across in this game are pretty terrifying. It seemed like the more you crossed paths with them the more they recognized you and then became harder to take out. It was a nice challenge to a game that doesn't really have many  hard obstacles apart from the demons.There are just a couple cons about the game:1. No map. While you can play and beat the game no problem without a map, it was still annoying at times trying to navigate without it. Since the game took place at night and a lot of the buildings look similar, I found myself lost a lot and running around in circles. The game DID come with a code for an interactive map, but I could never get that to load for me and thus never used it. 2. Retracing your steps. Partly due to the lack of a good map, you also have to retrace your steps a lot in this game. That can get tiring. You can also get a bit dizzy from walking/running through walls etc. while retracing said steps.So yeah. The game was pretty awesome and worth the money. I give it a 8/10.

I would recommend the game and I think the metascore should be around and 80. Had the game been longer I would've given it a better personal score.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												I Pre-Ordered this game and was worried when I started to read reviews. I installed it Friday and decided to fire it up last night and see if it was as bad as I've read. Let me tell you that "professional" reviews don't know what they are talking about, some franchasies with annual releases continue to get 80-90% every year for the same game. New games with new ideas often get trashed.My initial trail was intended to be to check the opening scenes, I found myself getting pulled in and played for more than 3 hours straight. I can't wait to continue this game. They premise and story is very cool so far, the main character is well acted and the other actors are ok too. I can really see this game being a cult classic if it continues to be as good as the first few hours. It isn't perfect, there are some cheesy or wierd things. The possession stuff, especially the cats is very chessy and seems to be a step down in quality from the rest of the game. The side quests seem cool but usually are unrewarding, I find myself collecting all the items and I enjoy the spoken story at the end but the static picture feels cheap and it would have been awesome to have some animated stories, even animated comic frames would have been a huge increase. The jump to pre-renedered cutscenes isn't terrible but can be a bit jarring, it would have been nice to see it renedered in game since it does appear to use the game engine but the subtitles are a bit blurry becuase it appears it may have been recorded in a lower resolution like 720P.This reminds me of older point and click adventure games where you have to find clues but uses a modern 3D engine and it works pretty well. The game also looks pretty good, and runs well. I can easily max the game out at 1600P with no problem on my computer.I don't think I have ever written a Steam review but I had to for this under rated gem. The game so far is a solid 7.5/10 for me, it seems interesting and overall pretty fun. I've been getting bored with the same old games recently and it is nice to see a different take. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this game, I think a lot of people would like it and I think the review scores are misleading.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Got this game via. a Humble Bundle and despite the recommendation, I'm glad I didn't pay full price.This is not a bad game. However, it isn't a spectacular one either. I enjoyed playing it, and think it's worth the purchase, but only within the $5 - $10 range.The game isn't particularly long--7 - 10 hours not including collectables--and due to the murder mystery-esque storyline, has little replay value.Combat is non-existant, and instead the few enemies met in the game are dispatched using "sneak up behind them and perform a button combination" tactics. The encounters are never difficult, and with the exception of perhaps one or two near the end, pretty straight forward.The meat of the game involves crime-scene investigation, or at least a simplified version of it. Once you get the hang of what the game expects from you, they become fairly simple, but several times throughout I found the prompts given to help you select relevant clues had little to do with the actual clues the game expected you to select... not that the game really penalizes you for choosing the wrong ones.In short; decent game, buy it cheap, play it once, enjoy it, and move on.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												This game is what I would call an action-adventure with simple puzzle elements. The gameplay itself is not very original and repetitive, but the game stands out due to the excellent presentation and good storytelling.In "Murdered: Soul Suspect" the player steps into the role of Ronan O'Connor, a police detective who gets killed right during the intro. In this first cutscene, Ronan sees his dead body and realizes that he has become some kind of spirit (which reminded me of the similar scene in the 1990 movie "Ghost", starring Patrick Swayze). As a new inhabitant of the spirit world he sets out to find his murderer, seemingly some kind of serial killer on the loose targeting women who at first don't seem to have anything in common. Ronan saves Joy, a young medium, from the killers grasp. She is in search for her (also medially gifted) mother. The two start to work together to unravel the mysteries behind the killings.The game is set in the small town of Salem, USA. The entire story occurs during one (very long) night. The streets of salem provide the starting point and are also the main "level hub" during the game gaining access to different locations which are unlocked by advancing in the main story line. Allthough story and level design are quite linear, this allows the players to travel back to previous visited places to look for clues or collectables they may have overlooked, giving the game a small whiff of "open world".While following the main storyline, the player is free to pursue side quest for other ghosts, in other words doing detective work on their "cases" to help them find peace and thus the way into the afterlife. Most of the time you search for different clues, either physical or mental - Since you are able to slip into the bodies of every human NPC you encounter, you can read their minds to find valuable clues or just spy on their thoughts, which is quite fun most of the time and adds to the atmosphere. When you have enough clues, you can "solve" a crime scene by combining the clues that matter, which I found sometimes confusing and not very logical. Since you can try the combination out as often as you want, try-and-error is always the way to go, making these puzzles somewhat obsolete.One of the most fun elements in the game are the few cats throughout, you can possess their bodies to jump and climb into otherwise unreachable areas to open passages or unlock secrets. A feature I could definitely have had more of.Scattered during the different levels are several sets of collectables which, upon completion, each unlock a small, fully voice-narrated ghostly short story.There are no time-limited missions, which I found very comforting. (Unfortunately, the developers decided to change this in the final battle, see below). The player is always allowed to take hers/his time to inspect the surroundings (with the exception of the recurring hide-and-seek from the demons), giving the opportunity to enjoy the remarkable atmosphere the developers created here.The only physical confrontations in the game happen in some scattered events where "demons" show up. These entities are described as former ghosts of humans that were unable to solve their "soul quests", and as a result descended into madness and turned into vile creatures, preying on other spirits. If they spot the player, they rush towards him and attack, resulting in a game over after a few hits. The only way to defeat them is to perform a sneak-attack. To avoid being seen, the player can use one of the variuos "ectoplasmic residues" (some astral, human-shaped clouds that are found all over the game world) to hide inside.These sequences work like a stealth game where you approach your enemies from behind and finish them of by a quick keypad-key & mousekey combination that is displayed. I despise quicktime events in general (in my opinion they are the distinctive mark of the lazy game designer), and I found these short "battles" against the demons just annoying. If you hit the wrong button, the attack fails and you have to flee and hide again, while the monster search the hiding spots. Most of the time you hop from one hideout to another, till the demons stop looking for you. This can be quite frustrating if you are in a limited space (like the asylum) and three demons are hunting you simultanously. These sequences often feel random and half-baked, resulting in hectic hopping-around until the enemies let go. In some levels there are spectres of crows placed in certain spots which the player can activate to distract the demons. These are quite helpful, but there are few of them and they are seldomly encountered inside buildings.When I started playing, I was drawn into the eerie atmosphere and loved it. Unfortunately, the feeling vanished the more I approached towards the "final battle" sequence. Without spoiling the story, it is basicly just a longer quicktime event. You have x seconds to find out that you have to push key y, then you have x seconds to do z. Otherwise you lost. I tried to beat the sequence about four times, then I uninstalled the game (yes, I am a wimp!). The strength of "Murdered" lies in its strong storytelling and stunning depiction of the spirit world, and if it were not for the uninspired gameplay mechanics, it could be one of my all time favourites. Since steam does'nt have a "thumbs sideways" button, I give it a thumbs down, although it would deserve better.I recommend it for people who are into "haunted house" stories (It reminded me of movies like "Ghost", Peter Jackson's "The Frighteners" with a pinch of "Se7en" in the mix.), and who are not easily frustrated by quicktime events like me.  Pros: - great graphics & sound design - superb eerie setting - interesting main characters- some interesting side characters  - reading minds of NPCs - fun with possessing cats - some good sidequest-stories - small, fully voiced short stories as rewards for  collectable-sidequests   Cons: - game mechanics very simple & repetitive - clue investigation just simple searching and puzzle solving by try & error - demons annoying - final "fight" scene annyoing - NPCs barely react to "poltergeisting" at all

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
One of the best story I've ever experienced.I actually doubted to buy this game or not. Eventually, I did and I just finished the game. Main story takes 5-6hrs to complete so it's too short but there're like 4-5 side cases so it can last 7-8hrs to completely finish the game. When it's first half you can guess your killer. So you might say: "Okay it's so obvious, I know who's my killer just end already." but game's ending is proves you so wrong. And believe me, ending is worth it.Good old point action and newly running simulator.Unfortunely this game hasn't got any insteresting gameplay. You just walk and collect (not it's not Pokemon Go). I wish at least we can have a "ghostly gun" to kill demons. But being an exorcist is kinda fun. Also those demons scaring the s**t out of you. Even I had to disable their AI to speed up the game (sorry I cheated death, again).If you want to have fun DO NOT disable them. But if you're so sick of them like me: Go to your steamapps/common/Murdered Soul Suspect\FateGame\Config folder. Open DefaultAIPerceptionData.ini with notepad. Search for StimTypes=(TypeName=Player,BaseTypeName=Ghost,Result_Awareness=High) and change High to Unaware. Demons won't see you now but you have to kill them ofc. Good and bad things:+Very good voice acting.+Humor between Ronan and Joy.+Salem's creepy athmosphere.+Wall hacking (yes this is a thing).+Story.+Real investigating to solve puzzles/cases.-Gameplay bores you over time.-30fps cap in game, you can unlock it but cinematics are still capped.-Too many cinematics. Every question you ask is a friggin' cinematic. Why not in-game? Seriously.-A minimap could be useful. I lost in that damn mansion.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This game had a great idea, with shoddy implementation.Seriously, the whole ghost detective thing had a lot of potential. Unfortunately, the gameplay completely fell flat. The piecing together of clues to solve the crime was laughably simplistic. For example, you'd often need to posses someone to prompt them to think about something. When posed with the question along the lines of "What clue can you use to make them think about the murder?", one of the answers is literally "the murder". And the whole adding in of the demons thing to give it some aspect of stealth combat was irksome; I know they felt they needed to add something in to make it more challenging (since the mystery portion certainly wasn't doing it), but that aspect could have been done away with completely and nothing would have been lost. Less ghost splinter cell and more ghost Sherlock Holmes would have been great. It wasn't all bad; the plot was interesting, the graphics were good. But the stupid stuff the game made you do to reveal the plot was not worthwhile in the least.

												So far Fahrenheit/Indigo Prophecy was my favourite adventure game,Murdered comes very very close.It is definitly the best adventure game of the last 10 years or so.In the game we play as Ronan former criminal who became a detective and died,yes died.We solve the case of our own murder,now say what you want i havent play something like that yet!Its great,original,very climitical,the atmosphere is a mix of modern times with old sql noir,which works perfectly and the action takes place in the city of Salem,how cool is that?Its a cinematic game,like imo every adventure game should be so i love it.On the visual side Murdered is fantastic,gret graphics,pretty good map design,animations are fine theres really nothing wrong with visuals.On the gameplay like I said as its a cinematic game,on times you gonna feel like playing a movie,similiar to Fahrenheit,again for me this is great.So what we have here is a great,climatic,adventure game,that is original in pretty much every sens,some people say its short,idk imagine a movie 7-9h long ;)I dont want to give you any spoilers,Im just gonna say that story got me engaged,interested and entertained from the begining to the end.8/...sorry this game allowed me to posses a cat :3 9/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												My review of Murdered: Soul Suspect:ATTENTION: This review is long, so you can just skip to the conclusion if you'd like.I always liked supernatural fiction.That's why I took an interest in Murdered: Soul Suspect when it was first shown, back in 2013.First of all, I have to say that this game is unique.Where else can you find a detective game where the main protagonist is a ghost? Answer: You can't.Murdered: Soul Suspect is more than just a detective game.It's a story about Ronan O'Connor, a detective that was killed at the beginning of the game during an investigation, and became a ghost.Now, as a ghost, he has to find his killer in order to finish his unfinished business in this world, and be at peace with himself so he can go on to the next world and be with his dead wife, Julia, once again.The killer is called "The Bell Killer", a serial killer that roams the streets of the town Salem.The killer was searching for something in an apartment building when Ronan interrupted him and wanted to make an arrest, until the killer overpowered him and threw him out the window, badly injuring Ronan. Ronan becomes a half ghost as he's about to die, and when he wants to get back to his body, the killer shoots him several times, thereby killing him.Ronan became a full ghost immediately after. Later, Ronan meets Joy, a medium who's looking for her missing mother.She helps Ronan find the killer because her mother is possibly connected to the killer in a way, and by finding him, they will possibly find her too, so they help each other.The story is an excellent detective story, with great characters that are well voice acted, but it's really short. It only took me about 6-7 hours to complete, which is not enough.So, after you die, you immediately jump into the ghost-detective action.Since you're a ghost, you can't physically touch anything, which could be a problem when you want to investigate further, but as a ghost, you can do certain things you wouldn't be able to do as a human, such as possessing people and eavesdropping on their conversation, or influencing witnesses into remembering what happened at the crime scene. You can analyze evidence which will give you more clues about the case as well. Ronan also has the ability to see the memories of victims through their ghost residue, which helps him see exactly what happened at the crime scene. All of these will help you solve cases, and it's executed pretty well in the game.On the other hand, the choices you make as a detective are meaningless, since you will eventually make the right choice no matter what, and there is no grading and EXP system to motivate you to do your best. It's really disappointing.As for the town of Salem, Massachusetts, it's a really, really small town. It's so small that it kind of makes it hard to believe that there's actually a serial killer in this town. Also, the game gives you the feeling of a semi-open world game, which in reality, there's so little to do in Salem when you're not playing through the main missions.The only side quests in the game involve helping other ghosts finish their unfinished business, which means finding the truth about their deaths. It’s pretty neat. Aside from that, there are a ton of collectibles scattered around for you to find, and if you collect enough of them, you will know more about the people that lived in Salem in the past.There's also a side case for Ronan's life with Julia, which tells a lot about Ronan's past.Lastly, there is a side case which includes special collectibles that are hidden in the main areas of the game, which, if you collect all of them, will uncover stories about ghosts that are haunting those places, and also each place has its own collectibles that tell you about the history of the place, but, that's about it for the side content.By the way, you can also possess a cat which will get you get to certain places you can't normally reach, which is pretty cool.One thing I didn't like in the game was the demon encounters.Demons, as the game explained, are lost souls that stayed in this world, and they're the only enemy you'll ever encounter in the game. They can only be killed stealthily by executing them from behind, and if they see you, they will chase you. The only thing you can do in this situation is hide from them in ghost residues. They will come looking for you in them, so you have to switch between one residue to another in order to avoid them, until they will eventually stop looking for you.Sounds exciting? I didn't think so. It's utterly boring, and I would prefer if it wasn't in the game at all.Luckily, there are only a few demon encounters in the whole game.When you play through the game, you are accompanied by a creepy, intense soundtrack, like one from a horror movie when there's a scary scene. It's fantastic, and it immerses you into the dark and gritty atmosphere, and the great number of ghosts haunting the town makes it even more immersive.Speaking of atmosphere, the visuals in the game are fantastic. Textures are great, although I did encounter a few texture pop-ins when playing the game, and I had a few frame rate issues at certain points, but that's it.The dark atmosphere makes the game look amazing, and the graphics looked great on my PC.Overall, the game is a good adventure game, but it had so much more potential, and it could have been an amazing game if it had been done right.While Murdered: Soul Suspect definitely has its unforgivable flaws, it tries to compensate for them with its great narrative and the amazing atmosphere, though with not great success.It's not a horrible game by any stretch of the imagination, but it's not an amazing one either, and it certainly didn't live up to my expectation.Pros:+ Great story+ Incredible atmosphere and soundtrack+ Side cases are interesting+ Great graphicsCons:- The game is short- Boring enemy encounters- Choices as a detective are meaningless- The town is really smallMy final score for Murdered: Soul Suspect is 6.5/10.I would wait for a big discount before buying the game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Just finished the game. Over all, it was pretty neat. The graphics were nice and the story was pretty interesting. While I thought the dialogue might be a little cheesy, it was bearable and I have no real complaints about it. I enjoyed playing a ghost detective and getting to posess and influence people to get what I needed. Also, the demons you come across in this game are pretty terrifying. It seemed like the more you crossed paths with them the more they recognized you and then became harder to take out. It was a nice challenge to a game that doesn't really have many  hard obstacles apart from the demons.There are just a couple cons about the game:1. No map. While you can play and beat the game no problem without a map, it was still annoying at times trying to navigate without it. Since the game took place at night and a lot of the buildings look similar, I found myself lost a lot and running around in circles. The game DID come with a code for an interactive map, but I could never get that to load for me and thus never used it. 2. Retracing your steps. Partly due to the lack of a good map, you also have to retrace your steps a lot in this game. That can get tiring. You can also get a bit dizzy from walking/running through walls etc. while retracing said steps.So yeah. The game was pretty awesome and worth the money. I give it a 8/10.

												My girlfriend decided to give this game another go since we both tried it out on PS4 when it first came out in 2014, we were unimpressed and returned for a full refund here at EB Games.Roll forward to Dec 2015, it was on a 90% discount from Steam so I picked it up here for $2.99 USD.Roll forward another year to January 2017, and she decided to play this. The gameplay and story was good in her eyes, although she did complain alot about the Demons mainly because as she says, "they were scary".She said that the ending was rather "underwhelming" - the last mission was way too easy compared to the rest of the game and she expected a final challenge.All in all the game was very easy for her. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												PROS:- Nice to see a big-budget game break out of the AAA industry’s increasingly rigid mould.- Above-average script elevates a straightforward story.- Exploring to find weird little characters and creepy ghost stories is weirdly enjoyable.CONS:- Utterly terrible stealth sections that clash completely with the rest of the game.- Puzzles often appear interesting only to phrase themselves strangely, resulting in answers that don’t seem to make a lot of sense.SUMMARY:A mild experiment that’s neither particularly great nor notably bad. Definitely not worth considering for anything near full price, but a pleasant enough diversion if you fancy something laid back. Still, it’s a bit sad that the most interesting thing about this game is that it’s anything other than a brown shooter. Like complimenting someone for only breaking one of your legs rather than both.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I was afraid it would be a bad idea to play this but it turned out to be quite OK. The gameplay is a bit like as if someone took a point and click adventure and turned it into a TPS without the weapons - or the shooting for that matter and realized  afterwards that there must be a degree of difficulty too so they added these dementors to the game. These demons are the biggest letdowns in this game BTW... Anyway, graphics are OK, characters (the inhabitants of Salem) are repetitive, the story is OK (excpet that I don't get it: why on earth do you need to collect objects completely out of scope and proportion to be awarded with something? eg. boiler or whatever), side "missions" are so-so (I am being positive here), controls OK (except for the demon "fight" and usual camera mayhem) - and the game is way way short (7 hours or so on normal difficulty). Of course since it is "open world"-ish you can wander about for long but I do not see the point in doing so.I would recommend it more than not but be warned: this game will not appeal to all.
