content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												I really thought I'd enjoy this game but I mainly didn't.The story's not compelling, the character's are pretty cliché and bland, and I even find the main character a bit ridiculous at times with his ghost cigarette always on. There's a twist at the end I saw coming since the beginning but there's a very final one I have to admit I didn't but nothing to get really excited about either.The main problem are the clunky mechanics. Holy ghost is it bad. You end up runing in circles ALL THE TIME because you missed a clue. But not because you didn't see it but because the game is poorly executed ! You see what seems to be a clue, get near it but no interraction possible. So you think it's not a clue and keep looking elsewhere. But it actually is a clue, only you need to be at the exact spot with the camera facing the exact side the developpers decided in order to get a command prompt. It happens literrally all the time and it's very annoying.And I'd rathyer not talk about the demons phases which are the most frustrating and annoying things I've seen in a video game for a long time, it really got on my nerves having to start over and over again what, in my opinion, shouldn't even be in a game like that.Also, the city streets are of no interest whatsoever. It's just empty corridors that get you from a mission to another with nothing interesting to do and filled with tons of useless collectibles. There's so many of them, I stopped reading entries after a while, it's way too much. It reminded me of the first Assassin's Creed in that way.Graphics are okay and voice acting is pretty good though.It's not a bad game per say, but it's not a good one either in my humble opinion. I didn't have a good time playing it and although it's only a 6 hours long story, I really was longing for it to end after less than 2 hours.I had just finished Life Is Strange before playing Murdered: Soul Suspect, so maybe after playing such a masterpiece I was feeling particularly picky and this game didn't stand a chance before I even started. Anyway, whatever the reasons behind my feelings, I trully can't recommand that game except on a massive sale or part of a bundle, but 30€ is way too expensive for what it has to offer.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												In Murdered: Soul Suspect you play the role of a deceased cop whose spirit is trapped in our world and unable to pass on tot he afterlife due to the mysterious circumstances surrounding his brutal murder. It combines crime scene investigations with ghostly manipulation, set tpo the backdrop of a modern day Salem.First and foremost, Ronan (the main character) has easily become one of my favorite protagonists in recent history; here you have a kid raised by the streets who knew nothing but a life of crime until one day he grows up and is offered the chance to turn it all around and make something of himself - thus he ends up joining the force and becoming a detective, though his past still haunts him and his newfound reputation. He's got a tattoo from every major event in his life - the good and the bad - and he totes a massive glock both gifted by and named after his mother. What's not to like?The story is pretty straightforward - get killed by bad guy, hunt down and stop bad guy, pass on - but it's all brought together quite nicely. A strong voice cast and shiny graphics go a long way, too; Salem is looking just awesome!Gameplay, as stated earlier, combines crime scene investigations with ghostly manipulation. That last bit probably needs some elaboration though. Basically, you're a ghost. Most buildings will be off limits, though they tie this into the story - being you're in Salem (home to ancient witch hunts), many of the houses have been consecrated long ago. However, open doors or windows are free game. You can also pass through interior walls and doors (so long as they don't lead to the outside world) and a variety of other solid objects. You can also possess people to read their minds or even influence them in certain ways, or manipulate certain objects to attract attention (TVs, radios, even vaccuum cleaners).All in all, this title is living up to just about ervery expectation I had for it and then some.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
General GameplayMURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™ is a simple mystery game, solving crime scenes is extremelly fun and the lack of complexity makes it less frustrating, some players may not like it though.The stories around the characters and the town itself are interesting, even though some of the outcomes are predictable.Gameplay Rating: 4/5EngineUnreal Engine 3Graphics OptionsIgnoring the fact that you can't rebind keys (I played with Controller anyway), the game has a good set of options.Graphics QualityStandard graphics for the previous generation (PS3, X360).PerformanceThe game is capped at 30FPS with V-Sync On, meaning it suffers from framedrops.Engine Rating: 2/5Overall Rating: 6/10NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and engine (how the game looks and runs). If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												If you are interested in adventure games focused on the story, it is a decent game. The investigation bits aren't developed compared to other games like sherlock holmes, it simply adds to the story. It is not a very long game, even if you are into collecting all the pieces to unlock other non-playable short stories, which is kinda boring IMHO. My biggest problem with this title is the unnecessary addition of quicktime events during gameplay. Quicktime is alright if they are few and far between, but in this game it is added in several mechanics, from fighting demons to escaping from demon pits. They should've done away with all of that if they didn't bother adding a different mechanism of fighting and evading danger.The graphics are alright and the dialogue is okay - if your graphics card isn't at least a medium-end one I'd say skip it mostly because you might run into a few issues with fps, which will probably take away from the game as you have to walk all around places and kill demons to get to the objectives.I can recommend this game only if you enjoy story focused games and even in this case, if its on a sale. I wouldn't recommend people paying over $15 on this one.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												A very disappointing game. I expected a relaxing adventure game with nice graphics, a nice story, some easy puzzles and some exploration. Unfortunately only the graphics held up to my expectations. The story wasn't very original up to the point where I quit, but at least it was interesting enough to follow it. So it could have been a decent game - if it weren't for the abysmal gameplay. The whole game is basically one of those crappy hidden object games. You walk around with your ghost character and search for clues (objects or people you can interact with) so you can walk up to them and press a button. Doh. Once you've found enough clues you can combine the most important ones  (which again means mindlessly pressing buttons, don't get your hopes up) to 'solve' the scene and move on with the story.Oh, and apart from that sometimes you have to fight demons. Sounds exciting? It is not. You just have to walk up to them from behind and press a button combination. Just another very dull gameplay mechanic.Murdered: Soul Suspect would have been a better game if it was one of those Walking Simulators like 'Dear Esther'. And that says something. The gameplay is simply too boring and annoying to enjoy the (not even outstanding) story of the game. Not recommended.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Sorry I can't continue playing this.Story is possibly good, but I don't feel intrigued enough to go through the game.The main reason I can't recommend this game are the controls.Nobody cared enough to implement mouse/keyboard remapping option, so you have to stick with the key bindings chosen by the developer, which are personally for me are very uncomfortable.It's like they designed by somebody who never used mouse /keyboard in their life.There is absolutely no reason to play this with gamepad, this is not hack&slash game.Apart from this:Game space feels very confined (any time you are trying to walk away from current mission scene, which is 10x10 feet, you are immediately returned to that scene, etc).Graphics are so so (if you max it up and use 1080p screen, there is nothing great about them, textures are bland and washed out)Combat simplistic and boring, similar to playing hide and seek.This game was obviously made for consoles.I regret I made this purchase, even though I didn't pay the full price.I missed the times when I owned PS3, when I could sell unwanted game on ebay or trade it in for pennies, at least I didn't have them in my library and remember all the pain they caused me.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												After completing this game with about 85% of the achievements, I can say that I must agree with the mediocre opinions of other reviewers like Zero Punctuation. It really seems like a lot of potential got wasted here. The demons can be annoying, the clues and collectibles a pain to find, and the puzzles strangely insulting to the player's intelligence. The gameplay almost seems like an afterthought to the story. And in my opinion that is where this game, well if not shines at least sparkles slightly.Unlike the gameplay that sold me for dumb, the story was just smart enough that I didn't quite see everything coming. If you play the game as an interractive TV episode of some supernatural detective story it is actually quite enjoyable. And if you do have the patience to find all the collectibles for each section you are rewarded with some nice "Tales from the Crypt" type ghost stories. They are just voiceovers to a fixed image, but they are generally well acted and gripping.So if you like a bit of a ghost story and some detective adventures AND you find it on sale for under $10 give it a go!

While there are some interesting game mechanics and well, playing a ghost is different from other games, the game felt too much scripted for me. Which means that the player is a little too oriented for me. It's pretty much a game about collecting items laying on the floor or around... and putting the puzzle together with the help of the game itself. You have to solve "a" crime, an investigation while following a trail, a way... maybe THE way. And that's what I can't play such a type of game for too long. However I liked the graphics, the environnment, the mood it gets you into. And the story seems interesting (as far as I've gotten). The problem is that everything I like is not related to playing a videogame, but rather to a movie... although I must say, getting control of that cat and moving around with it was cool ! I would recommend it as an interfactive adventure... as a movie, but not as a videogame - I didn't like it enough.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game with a really cool idea, but with terrible execution. Even on sale, I couldn't recommend this game. (overall worth? about $5.00). The idea of being a detective ghost, and getting the chance to investigate your own death is very cool. The writing is surprisingly good, and it didn't really feel cheesy. Likewise, the voice acting was pretty good and I didn't find myself hating any of the characters. Usually teen girls in games can be a little, overacted?However, that's all that is good about the game. Any writing that isn't related to the main story was terrible. The little story snippets that you get are not scary, nor interesting. Yay, a guy bathed in nasty dead body water.This is compounded by awful, and I mean awful, level planning and game design. Your ghost powers, which could be AWESOME, are hindered by invisible walls. In this case, invisible ghost walls that have no reason to be there, prevent you from taking better shortcuts, or are there just to make you weave through the miniscule levels in a particular way. And then there are the demons, an utterly pointless addition to the game. All the way done with the investigations in a level? Well, lets just add some extra demons on your way out, to annoy you. Oh, how about some demon hand pits that you have to avoid. The only reason I can see for these being added to the game? To make the game feel longer. To make the final scene completable. Whoever planned this game, and designed the levels and town should be fired. This game is a perfect lesson in how NOT to make levels.Then there are the pixel hunting items. Where you'll spend a few extra minutes per level scrounging around to find half invisible items that don't do much but give you a codex and a short voiced story after finding them all. Without these items, some of your ghost powers would be utterly useless. And many of these items don't contribute to the main story. Those items are real world items that don't use your powers. They could have done so MUCH with the reveal and teleport powers, but after getting them you use them maybe once or twice. But mostly only to get those silly little trophy items. Also, any action in the game is dumbed down to quick time events. Yes, quick time events that don't even register your keypresses properly. It's a game of chance if the game decides to excorcise a demon. On top of this, you often have to kill multiple demons in a row. Failure to kill, sometimes resulting in death, makes you have to start all over again. Meaning if there are four demons, and you kill three, but your kid happens to distract you... Then you have to start the whole process of killing all four OVER again. What a terrible game mechanic. There were also still a number of bugs. The most noticeable were the freezing bugs, where when you go to "peek" through someones eyes, the game will not let you click anything. So, you have to restart and hope the same bug doesn't happen again. Would I recommend this game? No. It's one of the most atrocious amalgamations of horrendous game design and mechanics on the market.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												I really thought I'd enjoy this game but I mainly didn't.The story's not compelling, the character's are pretty cliché and bland, and I even find the main character a bit ridiculous at times with his ghost cigarette always on. There's a twist at the end I saw coming since the beginning but there's a very final one I have to admit I didn't but nothing to get really excited about either.The main problem are the clunky mechanics. Holy ghost is it bad. You end up runing in circles ALL THE TIME because you missed a clue. But not because you didn't see it but because the game is poorly executed ! You see what seems to be a clue, get near it but no interraction possible. So you think it's not a clue and keep looking elsewhere. But it actually is a clue, only you need to be at the exact spot with the camera facing the exact side the developpers decided in order to get a command prompt. It happens literrally all the time and it's very annoying.And I'd rathyer not talk about the demons phases which are the most frustrating and annoying things I've seen in a video game for a long time, it really got on my nerves having to start over and over again what, in my opinion, shouldn't even be in a game like that.Also, the city streets are of no interest whatsoever. It's just empty corridors that get you from a mission to another with nothing interesting to do and filled with tons of useless collectibles. There's so many of them, I stopped reading entries after a while, it's way too much. It reminded me of the first Assassin's Creed in that way.Graphics are okay and voice acting is pretty good though.It's not a bad game per say, but it's not a good one either in my humble opinion. I didn't have a good time playing it and although it's only a 6 hours long story, I really was longing for it to end after less than 2 hours.I had just finished Life Is Strange before playing Murdered: Soul Suspect, so maybe after playing such a masterpiece I was feeling particularly picky and this game didn't stand a chance before I even started. Anyway, whatever the reasons behind my feelings, I trully can't recommand that game except on a massive sale or part of a bundle, but 30€ is way too expensive for what it has to offer.

												Another glitchy xbox port. From what i understand, this was Square's attempt to appeal to a western audience. The plot is that you are a detective who must solve his own murder, which, as a game, had so much promise... but the coding was top heavy. My system struggled to run it even in safe mode, the story was surprisingly predictable, and the controls were unruly to say the least. I would have been more into it maybe if fighting demons weren't WAY harder to combat than they initially let on earlier in the game. The demons can ♥♥♥♥ right off. The investigations don't really involve any real problem solving on your part: just treat it like a 6 hour movie. :/ Save yourself the trouble and watch an LP. You might miss the side missions (of which there are a gazillion of them), but it's really not worth the trouble of playing it yourself. It was such a good idea that fell flat on its face.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Take the basic premise of the Patrick Swayze movie "Ghost", ditch the pottery wheel scene, add some gameplay elements from Heavy Rain and L.A. Noire, and wrap the whole thing around the historic Salem witch trials. The result is Murdered: Soul Suspect.As a game, it's really easy, but the gameplay is varied and competent enough to avoid being a chore. Intriguing mystery plot, likable characters and haunting atmosphere are the main reason to play this title, even though there's no replay value whatsoever - consider getting it at bargain price. I should also mention that this is a rare case where collectible hunts are actually worth your time. Those ghost tales are cool as sh!t.

												I really like the story in this game! It draws you in pretty nicely and I really want to find out more, but trying to beat the demons prevents me from spending too much time on this in one setting. If it wasn't for that I would be spending many more hours on this. As it is now, I play for a little, get frustrated, and then come back to it later. Eventually I get past the demons by beating them, but I don't consider this part of the game fun.Although I'm not sure of the real reason for Airtight Games going out of business, I would like to think it's because they threw this stupid difficult platforming into their puzzle games that adds nothing but frustration to players like me who are in it mostly for the puzzles. (these folks are also the culprits behind Quantum Cunundrum). The recommendation is a yes for the story and progression of the game but a no for the gameplay. If you like platforming games and are pretty coordinated, this part of the game won't be an issue for you; however, you might then be bored with the rest of the gameplay which is just simple puzzle/exploration.

												I had a lot of fun with Murdered: Soul Suspect. The story is really engaging; the ghostly and other supernatural powers (walking through walls, reconstructing crime scenes through ghostly shards left behind, getting visions of the past from touching people's hands, etc) are really thrilling, and I especially liked all of the crime/mystery sequences. The game is criminally short unfortunately, and slow paced - it's more about storytelling than it is about actual gameplay,  although there is a light stealth mechanic, and there's what felt like a somewhat rushed ending, so if that isn't your thing, this may be a game to avoid. But the atmosphere is incredible and the storytelling is engaging, and I'm really glad I took a chance on this in a sale.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Grab the closest fedora, to save m'lady from ultimate danger as a knight so white your transparent being a ghost and all.  Murdered Soul Suspect plays like a hidden object game with an open world utilizing hubs like Deus Ex.  Ironically many of the cops cant solve this case because their too busy playing Deus Ex which is on their screens at the Police Station.  This game is very very short which is a plus for completionists hunting them achevos since its a pretty easy run to get 100%.  The story is just about the right length without being drawn out.  Investigating crime scenes means hunting down clues, at first the puzzles make no sense when asked to select a word since their not explained, but after doing a couple every player will feel like a PI.  Fun game to play late at night so only play it when the lights are off and best played during shocktober to go with the whole Salem Witch trials thing.  Game goes all 2spooky right from the start with a tale of someone in a water thing and people drinking it or something just like that real life story of Elisa Lam.  Get ready to get spooked! No major bugs in the game, besides sometimes the character stops walking for some reason, just reload the last checkpoint.  All found items are saved after finding them so reloading means you lose none of the items which is awesome.  The game has NO in game map, only preorders got that which sucks for everyone else.  Outside of that its really not needed, the game does an excellent job of telling every clue found by name.  Just use google on any missing ones to mop up, be sure to find the following before entering the "Judgement house".35/39 Info About My Killer34/38 Julia's Thoughts5/6 Profiler's Memories22/25 Salem's History8/9 Witch Trials HistoryMystery Fans:  Rating:  10/10  Value:  $14.99Non-Mystery Fans:  Rating:  4/10  Value:  $4.99

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												THE GOODMurdered: Soul Suspect has a fantastic atmosphere and environment design and it is all supported by a good story and each collectible (of which there are 242 in the game) also comes with a flavour text. It creates an really immersive experience. You also get to do some detective work, both in the main plot and for a couple of NPC ghosts in Salem, but...THE SO-SO...Murdered's core gameplay is more akin to a visual novel, but in 3D. You look at stuff, you collect information and you solve "puzzles" by putting piece A and piece B together. It's nothing spactacular and probably not for everyone. Also while the game does have 242 collectibles, there is no way to tell if you missed one or have collected everything in an area. People that like to explore may like that, people that just want to collect everything may not.THE UGLYThe Stealth gameplay where you have to have to evade demons feels incredibly tacked on and unpolished. You go up behind them and kill them with a QTE. If you mess up or get spotted you have to jump between hiding places with a button press until they calm down, at which point you can try again. There is no grace period for getting spotted so you might as well reload from checkpoint because it's faster than waiting for the demons to go back to lurking. SUMMARYIf the sudo-Stealth segments don't turn you off and you don't expect some action-oriented gameplay, Murdered Soul Suspect is a great experience. It's a little frustrating because had they spent just a little more time on the gameplay, this game would get a blind recommendation, but as it stands this game is still RECOMMENDED FOR FANS OF SUPERNATURAL MYSTERY STORIES AND PLAYERS WHO WANT TO GET IMMERSED IN A WORLD

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is about a wannabe detective/previous gangster, who was over his head as usual. The game is almost a point & click game at times. You are pretty much just looking at evidence, reading some person's mind, then solving a case with the most straightforward answer, which confuses you at times because the answer does nothing to help the case, & it just trips you up.Pros: + Good Graphics+ Music is good, is repetitive when examining evidence+ Good Voice acting+ Your a ghost+ You can possess a cat+ Can see women naked, jk XDCons:- When you're solving cases, almost all the answers are straight forward, making it pointless to collect evidence- Controls are a bit messy, it seems like this game was mainly developed for console- Gameplay gets repetitive after the 3rd case, which is look at this evidence, read mind, now conclude caseConclusion:- If you someone who played L.A. Noire, Vanishing of Ethan Carter, those Sherlock games. Then I recommend you not waste your money or time with this game, because the story isn't much & the gameplay gets very repetitive, but if you still want to buy it. I would wait until this game is %80-%90, because there are better detective games out there right now that are cheaper or of the same price of Murdered: Soul Suspect.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												I can't really recommend this game nor tell anyone not to play it. This is a particular game suited for those with a taste for ghost stories. In fact, I really wouldn't call it a "video game", but if it has to be labeled as such, just know that this game is a collection adventure to unlock ghost stories, while discovering parts of the main ghost story itself. The game's basic idea: Walk around as a ghost, explore, collect "ghost memories (collectables)", and solve simple psychological puzzles from time to time.Pro's: It's not bad for what it is.It's stories aren't distasteful, as far as ghost horror stories go, but don't expect a dark twist at the end or something incredibly cool (like 6th sense, The Others, or a double twist like Shutter Island). There is a twist (as there should be, in any good ghost story) but it's the most generic twist ever, so much so, I don't feel guilty for spoiling it. Still, when all is said, I can't really gripe too hard at the story, because it's a basic ghost/suspense story that's delivered quite well through interactive play. Con's:Really, there isn't a whole lot of things wrong with this, as far as the game itself is concerned. Although, it did have some issues with a 360 controller and my Roccat Tyon mouse (I had to disconnect the mouse to play). But, in all honesty, in a market that has been tapped completely dry, this game could have been so much worse. Also, I had to attach a -dx9 launch option for this game, seeing as my intel HD 3000 didn't recognize the forced dx11.Final Thought: It's fun, but I can't recommend it to just anyone. It's nothing new in the genre and unless you are really digging the ghost stuff, in which you would have already gotten this, I can't recommend it. However, if you ARE into ghosts and goblins, then I will say you won't waste your money with this game, as there is A TON of bad ghost horror stuff out there that, luckily for me, this did not turn out to be.

												A boring cluefinding simulator! There is no AI in this game, everything is static, people either stand/sit on the same spot forever or walk in circles forever. The only 2 things youll ever do in the way of gameplay is to find clues and backstab demons. Thats it! The rest is only for show!Here is how EVERY "mission" you ever get goes: Talk to a ghost, find clues on the ground, pick the most relevant clues and youre done. If you want something more than that you better not buy this game then!It MIGHT had been a good movie but as a game it is absolutely abysmal!

												I bought this game because I thought the idea of playing a ghost trying to solve his own murder sounded interesting and so far I am very pleased with the purchase. Using ghostly powers to distract and manipulate is fun and trying to solve the puzzles is engaging, if not terribly difficult, but my favorite part has been the notes and memories scattered throughout the game; they offer further insight into the main character's life, giving both him and other side characters more depth than I expected and many of the moments revealed I have found both surprising and touching. And the beautiful graphics are an added bonus, for sure. I do wish the controsl weren't quite so sensative when I'm trying to interact with the environment but that's about my only complaint.

The little girl's scripted "MOMMY" sequence replayed again. Why does reloading a save cause everything to reset improperly? This game is not worth your time or money.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I don't get why places like IGN and other respected game sites gave such poor reviews of this game.  I find it quite appealing and quite fun.  This is not an action packed, fast paced game.  On the contrary it's a slow paced, thoughtful mystery and  ghost story with above average production values.  While this is a supernatural themed game it is by no means gory, nor does it rely on jumpscares (this game isn't really scary at all) but it does have some violent, creepy, and to some, disturbing content.While nothing about this game will blow your mind there is very little that dissapoints.  The story is somewhat predictable, and as a mystery you'll generally figure something out before you character does so it's not a brain challenger.  There is no combat in this game, and only minimal action which is easily overcome and there are no traditional puzzles. Puzzles amount mostly to selecting relevant information from a list of choices about a specific question.If I have any gripes about this game it's that sometimes the controls can wonk out on you where you'll be posessing a body and your controller stops functioning altogether.  There was one instance where one insignificat ghost was talking but I heard no sound.  And some of teh minor characters could have had more background lore on them.  And lastly one of the gameplay aspect, helping other ghosts, was used too little.  Started off good but fades away a lot as teh game progresses.  Also no manual saves, only checkpoint saves and that can be a problem in a couple of areas, but nothing major.  Also, the game is short.  11 hours in and I am almost finished with it.All in all if you like creepy settings, ghost stories, mysteries,  and gathering collectible lore this game has it surrounded by a good setting .  If you're looking for something challenging look elsewhere a sther eis not much in teh way of combat and puzzles.  This is a slow paced, story focused, adventure game, not a supernatural shooter.I highly recommended for the mystery/ghost story lover.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												The ghost of a good gameThe PC version of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT is on a hiding to nothing right from the start, when you first encounter the abysmally clumsy UI. No effort whatsoever has been made to make the PC experience a smooth one and this frustrates and annoys throughout the game. And then there are the graphics to consider, which are below par when compared to other games from 2014, and the absence of any physics, which is also a disappointment. The gameplay itself is thoroughly unremarkable, the city of Salem is a dull and lifeless place, and the combat (a horrible QT-based system that requires the mashing of random keys and mouse buttons) is laughably poor. Basically you spend most of your time in MSS pixel hunting with the occasional button-spamming session thrown in. So what’s good about it? Well, the premise behind the game is an interesting one and the story involving enough (just) to keep me playing through to the end. The voice acting is good throughout, and you get to play as a cat, which is cool. Sadly, however, the opportunity to make a good game out of these positive aspects has been missed. 2.25/5

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Summary: Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural thriller blended expertly with a gritty detective story.  You won't see a lot of action here, but if you would love to take part in unraveling a very well-written story with great characters and entertaining crime-scene investigation mechanics that are neither irrationally obscure nor insultingly obvious then you won't regret letting your trigger finger relax for a few hours while you try to solve the mystery of your own brutal murder.  Hours of fun: 8 hours (full game + best extras)Suggested Retail Value: $20Graphics: 8/10Voice-acting: 9/10 Music/SFX: 10/10Uniqueness: 8/10First Play-through Experience: 10/10Replay Value: 4/10Murdered: Soul Suspect is not an action game. You'll never draw a gun let alone have a shoot out. You won't be pushing blocks to solve puzzles. You won't be leveling up, gaining new equipment, or trying to decide how you want your character to develop as the story plays out. You won't make decisions that change the plot. I think those are the simple truths that turn a lot of people away, and I can understand how this game is an utter disappointment to anyone who came into it with any of those goals. But if you're looking for something else, something outside of that all-too-common list, then read on. You play the part of a ghostly detective with nifty abilities that make movement through the world and interacting with technology, the living and the dead all very interesting and in ways that come together to present a style of play wholly unique to the game. You'll move through the world in a largely linear fashion, and while exploration will play a key role in progressing through the very well-written narrative it's in seeing that dark, gritty, supernatural detective story unfold that the player truly becomes invested. Or Not. That's the dividing line really. Are you here for the story? If not, you probably won't even finish the game. The characters will draw you in, and even the "collection" elements of the game (of which there are admittedly many) are used more like pieces of a puzzle that, once finished, have their own enthralling stories to tell. Did you find every ghostly rifle at one location? Well be prepared to hear an audio telling of a great ghost story tied to it. You'll also collect things that are sort of memory remnants: objects and places that enable you to witness the memories and stories of interesting people (your friends and family included) and feel the world come alive even as you draw ever closer to understanding exactly what is going on in the small town of Salem.The central mechanic of the game is you move around in the scenes with a careful eye for clues, and when you feel you're ready you use the clues you've found (you don't need them all and quite a few are "red herrings) you choose to "solve the crime scene". The visual and auditory cues for each scene's clues are apparent and make sense, though sometimes it can be a little too easy given that if you're a pace away from them and looking in their direction you get a sort of "press button to select it" prompt. Some of the puzzles could have used some less obvious "red herrings" as you'll seldom struggle to answer the questions before your three strikes are up (each scene gives you 3 chances to correctly). A few samples (without spoilers) of the questions that will need answering:- How did they die?- Who is responsible for event X?- Who is withholding secrets and why?- Where did they go?- Who do they know?- What is missing?- Why were they there?All of the scenes, clues, and problems will make sense and its a lot of fun to both solve the scenes and see how the story develops. I'm not the most observant person and I can honestly say I was never just clicking randomly. I suspect any occurrences of such are rightly blamed on negligence, forgetfulness, rushing through or skipping dialogue or cut scenes, and a general lack of attention to detail. The voice acting is great overall. The main characters are top notch. The only exception is that, though the random NPCs that move about the city are voiced well, many of their lines repeat as dialogue seems chosen randomly though it is tied to certain areas and events. Some reviewers have offered complaint regarding the combat with demons. I didn't mind this much as it was a nice little break between scenes and they were few and far between. Without spoiling too much it's largely a stealth mechanic akin to Assassin's Creed's stealthy take-downs. It's very basic though, but does lend some suspense to a game that is otherwise a (very entertaining) whodunit. Others have suggested that it's too short. I disagree as I felt it offered the exact amount of entertainment I felt I wanted from it. It's long enough to tie all its loose ends, introduce twists that don't break immersion, but short enough that it's not drawn out or diluted with filler. A rushed play through of the main story would take about 5 or 6 hours, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice as a lot of the story is told via discovery of the very well-done collectables. Those wanting to see the whole plot unfold will be looking at roughly 8 or 9 hours. The good news is that's also the same time as a completionist run because, again, they've cleverly tied each collectable to an interesting story, either the main plot or a well written aside. The game's got a great gritty detective movie atmosphere, a well-written plot, and really establishes the mood of a supernatural thriller. If you like story-driven games, appreciate mystery and logical investigation puzzles, and want to see better developed characters than you'd get in most run-of-the-mill action shooters, then you'll most likely enjoy your time spent playing this game.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Finished the game in about 7-8 hours and here is my review.+Unique story+Unique gameplay+Very good voice acting+Completionists and supernatural fans would enjoy this very much above the usual casual gamers+Sheds light to the history of witches and Salem+Characters are very interesting and have separate background stories+/- Impossible to fail, not very challenging+/-Has a very niche audience, not your average game-Tends to have some weird issues (Couldn't put AA over high or else a green hue would overshadow everything, lost control of mouse and/or keyboard, which could only be resolved with restarting the game, crashed a few times)-Very short, i completed in about 7-8 hours, while still getting over 200 collectibles and completing most sidequests.-For the content you are getting kinda pricey-Feels rushed in some parts, there are a lot of fillers "collectibles" so that you wouldn't complete the game faster-No replayability, some people (including myself) see this as a bit similar to L.A Noire, however your options don't have any consequences and you can't go back to mend your mistakes or replay a story in a different way like you would in L.A Noire-Extremely sandboxed/linearOverall rating would be a solid 7 out of 10 spooksHowever if you don't like detective games or anything to do with the supernatural i wouldn't recommend this, although it wouldn't hurt you to try out a new genre for yourself.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												The ghost of a good gameThe PC version of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT is on a hiding to nothing right from the start, when you first encounter the abysmally clumsy UI. No effort whatsoever has been made to make the PC experience a smooth one and this frustrates and annoys throughout the game. And then there are the graphics to consider, which are below par when compared to other games from 2014, and the absence of any physics, which is also a disappointment. The gameplay itself is thoroughly unremarkable, the city of Salem is a dull and lifeless place, and the combat (a horrible QT-based system that requires the mashing of random keys and mouse buttons) is laughably poor. Basically you spend most of your time in MSS pixel hunting with the occasional button-spamming session thrown in. So what’s good about it? Well, the premise behind the game is an interesting one and the story involving enough (just) to keep me playing through to the end. The voice acting is good throughout, and you get to play as a cat, which is cool. Sadly, however, the opportunity to make a good game out of these positive aspects has been missed. 2.25/5

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Summary: Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural thriller blended expertly with a gritty detective story.  You won't see a lot of action here, but if you would love to take part in unraveling a very well-written story with great characters and entertaining crime-scene investigation mechanics that are neither irrationally obscure nor insultingly obvious then you won't regret letting your trigger finger relax for a few hours while you try to solve the mystery of your own brutal murder.  Hours of fun: 8 hours (full game + best extras)Suggested Retail Value: $20Graphics: 8/10Voice-acting: 9/10 Music/SFX: 10/10Uniqueness: 8/10First Play-through Experience: 10/10Replay Value: 4/10Murdered: Soul Suspect is not an action game. You'll never draw a gun let alone have a shoot out. You won't be pushing blocks to solve puzzles. You won't be leveling up, gaining new equipment, or trying to decide how you want your character to develop as the story plays out. You won't make decisions that change the plot. I think those are the simple truths that turn a lot of people away, and I can understand how this game is an utter disappointment to anyone who came into it with any of those goals. But if you're looking for something else, something outside of that all-too-common list, then read on. You play the part of a ghostly detective with nifty abilities that make movement through the world and interacting with technology, the living and the dead all very interesting and in ways that come together to present a style of play wholly unique to the game. You'll move through the world in a largely linear fashion, and while exploration will play a key role in progressing through the very well-written narrative it's in seeing that dark, gritty, supernatural detective story unfold that the player truly becomes invested. Or Not. That's the dividing line really. Are you here for the story? If not, you probably won't even finish the game. The characters will draw you in, and even the "collection" elements of the game (of which there are admittedly many) are used more like pieces of a puzzle that, once finished, have their own enthralling stories to tell. Did you find every ghostly rifle at one location? Well be prepared to hear an audio telling of a great ghost story tied to it. You'll also collect things that are sort of memory remnants: objects and places that enable you to witness the memories and stories of interesting people (your friends and family included) and feel the world come alive even as you draw ever closer to understanding exactly what is going on in the small town of Salem.The central mechanic of the game is you move around in the scenes with a careful eye for clues, and when you feel you're ready you use the clues you've found (you don't need them all and quite a few are "red herrings) you choose to "solve the crime scene". The visual and auditory cues for each scene's clues are apparent and make sense, though sometimes it can be a little too easy given that if you're a pace away from them and looking in their direction you get a sort of "press button to select it" prompt. Some of the puzzles could have used some less obvious "red herrings" as you'll seldom struggle to answer the questions before your three strikes are up (each scene gives you 3 chances to correctly). A few samples (without spoilers) of the questions that will need answering:- How did they die?- Who is responsible for event X?- Who is withholding secrets and why?- Where did they go?- Who do they know?- What is missing?- Why were they there?All of the scenes, clues, and problems will make sense and its a lot of fun to both solve the scenes and see how the story develops. I'm not the most observant person and I can honestly say I was never just clicking randomly. I suspect any occurrences of such are rightly blamed on negligence, forgetfulness, rushing through or skipping dialogue or cut scenes, and a general lack of attention to detail. The voice acting is great overall. The main characters are top notch. The only exception is that, though the random NPCs that move about the city are voiced well, many of their lines repeat as dialogue seems chosen randomly though it is tied to certain areas and events. Some reviewers have offered complaint regarding the combat with demons. I didn't mind this much as it was a nice little break between scenes and they were few and far between. Without spoiling too much it's largely a stealth mechanic akin to Assassin's Creed's stealthy take-downs. It's very basic though, but does lend some suspense to a game that is otherwise a (very entertaining) whodunit. Others have suggested that it's too short. I disagree as I felt it offered the exact amount of entertainment I felt I wanted from it. It's long enough to tie all its loose ends, introduce twists that don't break immersion, but short enough that it's not drawn out or diluted with filler. A rushed play through of the main story would take about 5 or 6 hours, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice as a lot of the story is told via discovery of the very well-done collectables. Those wanting to see the whole plot unfold will be looking at roughly 8 or 9 hours. The good news is that's also the same time as a completionist run because, again, they've cleverly tied each collectable to an interesting story, either the main plot or a well written aside. The game's got a great gritty detective movie atmosphere, a well-written plot, and really establishes the mood of a supernatural thriller. If you like story-driven games, appreciate mystery and logical investigation puzzles, and want to see better developed characters than you'd get in most run-of-the-mill action shooters, then you'll most likely enjoy your time spent playing this game.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												A non-biased quick look @ the game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Murdered: Soul Suspect' (GeForce GT 640, Win 10) 

			Views: 36		

			This game is available here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/233290 A non-biased quick look @ 'Murdered: Soul Suspect' - Wow, this game just blew me away, it's so refreshing to have a unique game...		

Wow, this game just blew me away, it's so refreshing to have a unique game style and direction. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a supernatural detective thriller which challenges players to solve possibly the hardest case of all… their own murder. When Ronan O’Connor, a detective with a chequered past, gets caught up in a violent burglary, his life is brought to an untimely end by a brutal and relentless killer. Shocked to find himself in the afterlife, his only escape from the limbo world of ‘Dusk’ is to uncover the truth behind his killer, track him down and bring him to justice using his detective instinct and new-found supernatural abilities. As Ronan, you have the freedom to explore the modern-day town of Salem: its New England-style wooden houses, narrow streets, gothic churches and mental asylum for clues. Battle demonic spirits to save your soul and uncover the shocking revelations about who is responsible for your death. - Highly Recommended!

Posted: March 12, 2016
												        I could not recomend this game to anyone expecting engageing gameplay or meaningful motivation to seak out the many hidden clues litttered through this game. After spending a breif yet adequate amount of time with this game i had found myself stuck twice hunting for the very last clue in one of the games closed "investigate" areas usaly holding about twelve clues scattered around containing only three releven ones and yet deming it necisary to hinder your progress untill such a time you find all of them then opening a blande menus houseing all the clues and instructing you  to chose the correct three gradeing you on which of three chances you guess correct and utterly discarding of all the other clues they had just forced you to find.          So I didnt like the story so what it has several side storys for your to hunt down like collecting 10 scattered water heaters, and 16 1970s era jurry cans with a cardbord sign taped to them labled "need gas" or somthing similar to that. hell I even had to walk circles around a drunk driving incident collecting trinkets only to discover i just had to wander to a gas sation around the corrnor and reinact a breif memory of who was driving the car that killed every one else within.       I would liken it to collecting the feathers in Assassins Creed 2 only instead of being thanked by an old lady for catching them all you get a dim blue menu containing a half-cliche half-based-in-fact story of a murder with its boring white text and mediocre plot that was given away by the name of the side quest.  And this trend did not seem to be destined to reced as the game progressed if anything it slowly grew more mundane and trivial as i progressed forward.       That being said I admit i was only willing to devote three hours to this game with the only true interaction with the game's enviroment came from a breif few moments in possesion of a cat to platform your way to the top of a building and do you know what wonderful prized awaited me....remember those jurry cans i was speaking about erlier, their was one of some rediculuse number suposedly littering the game. It is always a posiblility that the game does a complete 180 at the last moment but i dont hold high hopes. So no i canot recomend this game to anyone exspecting anything but trivial collectable insperations to make a game. This doesnt mean the storys within where not enjoyable but they mostly seemed more likly to belong in the local tabloids rather than a "detective" game.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Do you like ghosts? Do you like the supernatural and paranormal? Do you like hats and detectives and investigations? Do you like short games ideal for the busy people and that you can 100% in a sane amount of time?If the answers to most of the above are "Yes", then this game is for you!The game runs perfectly fine, even on medium configurations thanks to the Unreal Engine of Wonders that Runs on Almost Everything. Story-wise it could've been slightly better (the game appears to take place in the span of a long night and, given its length, I think they intended to make it so) but hopefully there wasn't much pretentiousness. Just a good old compendium of ghosts stories and lore about Salem.There is no shooting in this game so look elsewhere if you were planning on murdering from the afterlife.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a very intriguing noir-style adventure-game and experience. You experience + play the game as Ronan - who is a cop that gets killed by this serial killer only known as The Bell Killer that he's chasing; becomes a ghost; and is trying to find out who killed him + why. Not only that, but Ronan is also trying to find out why the Killer has been also killing people. The game is set in Salem, Massachusetts - which is widely known historically for the Salem Witch Trials; and is an excellent setting for this game's story. Throughout the game, Ronan is on this mission of finding the killer - and embarks on this excellent story that any fan of noir, thrillers, and murder-mysteries should experience just for that alone.Ronan is a ghost. With that, Ronan comes by some interesting abilities. Ronan can jump into their bodies and possess them. Ronan can influence other NPC's to do things, once he has possessed them. Ronan can even possess cats and even more around in their body. Ronan can read their minds. Ronan later on can even teleport to hard to reach areas or out of danger, similar to the Blink ability in Dishonored for Corvo + Daud. In one of the most legit uses of letting your character clip through walls, doors, and even other human beings. You can manipulate objects like a poltergeist - such as TV's (so they go static) and printers (and knock the paper out) to distract enemies. All of this is at first very odd and strange - but this is also makes this game interesting, unique, very cool, and very different; especially once you get used to it.Unfortunately, there are stealth sequences in the game. Not that this game needed any, since they feel so half-baked and are, for the most part, not fun. A great concept is in place: since ghosts and their residue linger, you can teleport to these spots to hide. You have to avoid demons, who when nearby have a lethal scream that can damage you and even possibility kill you. If you can get behind the enemy, you can attack them and one-shot kill them - which feels like a Quick-Time Event that tells you what button + movement on the gamepad (yes, I played this with an X360 gamepad - by the way; and it played fine with that). In theory, this all sounds pretty cool - but, it really isn't. It's not executed that well. Unfortunately, these elements feel half-baked and you can die very easily. Not only that, but like many games with auto-saves, don't be surprised if the game reloads at place that's a bit away from you'd have liked the save to have been at; and/or have to do a certain section over and over many times that really shouldn't need to be done again b/c the save was so poorly placed (i.e. before a cut-scene, at a long-winded walk before you reach a location where the saved should've been).Sometimes, you'll be escorting a character safely from one spot to another - and your objective is to move + manipulate objects like a poltergeist, just to distract them so the NPC can move from one location to another. These elements are very cool and really play into the ghost theme that the game is going on in this game. These certainly were much better than the stealth elements than were in the game.When investigating crime-scenes or locations, whether on the main quest or the very few story-based side-quests - you often have to find a handful or so of clues, more or less, in the game-world or specific game area. Sometimes, you then have to also answer a few questions (that you're asking yourself - or well, the game is asking, as you're piecing the story and events together); and come by the right answer to push the plot + stort forward. When investigating: you are scored from 1-3 badges. Don't make mistakes, you get 3 badges. Make another mistake, 2 badge-score. Make more than that, 1-star score - no matter what. There's no real punishment for failing - there's no reload screen for failing; and/or you aren't really aren't scored with a total score on how well or poorly you did. So, there's no real consequences for failing - you can pick the wrong answer, get a 1 score, and not even worry about your score. You could guess, if you can't figure out the answer - narrowing it down via trial and error, if you feel so inclined.There are plenty of collect-a-thons for side quests. From finding info about your character, to seeing old memories, and other things - the game is loaded w/ collectibles. Many of these, they actually do reveal more about the Salem setting, Salem's history, the game-world, the killer, and the characters in the story. So, if you want to get the most out of this game's story, setting, atmosphere, and characters - you'll likely want to find a good deal of these. Finding this stuff certainly actually does enhance the already interesting, fantastic & excellent story.Performance on this game with most things on higher settings on my PC (i7 950; 1 GB VRAM GeForce GTX 560 Ti; 16 GB RAM) at 1080p was a bit over the place, frequently jumping between 35-60 frames. Locking VSync On to half-refresh rate via the NVidia Panel certainly solved this problem, keeping the game regularly not budging at all from 30 frames per second. While the graphics in this game do look good, they certainly are not the best technical quality that is out there.After the 10 hours or so I spent with this game, according to Steam - the mystery was over. I came to the game's conclusion - thrilled with the plot, story, game-world, setting, and characters. But, I was certainly not thrilled and often frustrated with the game's half-baked stealth elements. While I do wish the game had more story-based side quests + that the game's (so-called) "puzzles" were a bit harder, I still came away really enjoying a good deal of the actual experience itself. If only the gameplay elements - namely, the stealth elements - were improved quite a bit (or removed entirely), we'd certainly be talking about the best adventure game of 2014. Fans of murder-mysteries, the supernatural, and noir - if you can tolerate the not-so-great stealth elements, this game most definitely should be experienced alone for its setting, story + character elements.Final Grade = B-

												Pretty average game. The core mechanic consists of searching around for objects, something similar to most collecting sidequests in modern games, which becomes boring very fast. Occasionally, you'll have to connect some of the clues you find, though these are mostly very obvious. There are also sporadic stealth-combat sections, but like the rest of the game, these offer no challenge at all.The presentation is also average. While the games looks very nice, the character design is uninspired and most character models are used over and over. The music is sparse, and while usually fitting the mood, it gets boring due to repetition. The story is uninteresting, has a lot of cliches and is mostly forgettable, though there are a couple of twists.This is not a bad game by any means and I can appreciate the hard work put into this. While I dislike writing bad reviews, with so many better options out there, it's hard to recommend this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Positives:+ Interesting Story and main character+ Graphic Style is impressive+ Voice Acting is generally well done+ Lots of items / snippets of information to collect to flesh out the backgroundNegatives:- Combat is extremely basic and probably could have just been left out- Controls are a bit annoying.  You have to stand at exactly the right distance and angle to interact with many objects, and if you need to do this in a hurry or can't find something, this can get frustrating- Very limited side quests- More "invisible walls" than needed in a game where one of the draws is being able to walk through things- Story is fairly short (I finished in 7.5 hours and took my time wandering around, it can probably be finished in 6 hours or less if you rushed through the main story)Comments:A game with an enjoyable story and character, but extremely limited combat and somewhat frustrating controls.  It's too short for me to recommend at full price ($29.99), but worth a playthrough if you can pick it up on sale.Overall Rating: 7/10

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial was once called the worst game of our time. It was so bad, it was credited with bringing down the very industry that helped create it.Murdered: Soul Suspect is every bit as terrible, and if Square Enix had decided to release it in proportionately similar numbers, the videogame industry would surely once again have been brought to its knees.That may seem harsh, but you're looking at a game that lets you possess cats without ever making it fun, or interesting. Let that sink in, for I still don't know how it is even possible.Sadly, today there's no way for us to tear it from its digital unlife within the Steam network, and consign it to it's rightful place at the bottom of a deep hole, in a landfill somewhere around Almagordo, New Mexico. Instead, it will simply continue this undignified existence as a warning to developers and gamers alike, of just how bad a game can turn out.I cannot fathom the depths of malice and perversion that must have possessed Square Enix, in order for them to bring this game to market. The fact that it is still being sold, is nothing short of a declaration of contempt for you as a gamer, and a consumer.Do not buy it. Do not accept it as a gift. I beg you. Forget this game, and then forget you ever read this. Please, just go on - Blissfully free from the notion that it ever existed.

Posted: June 6, 2014
												Frame rate capped at 30 and for something that doesn't look that great is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. For a square Enix game I'm very disappointed, the story is somewhat original but the gameplay is glitchy and handles terribly. The main activity of the game is to point out evidence of a crime scene and use "detective skills" (read as trial and error) to determine what happened. There seems to be no fail if you choose everything wrong despite having three attempts.It's not a bad game but it's not worth $60, had it have been cheaper then I'd recommend it however if you want this then I suggest waiting until the summer sales and a price drop.

Rating: 7.5/10    |     Murdered: Soul Suspect To apriciate this game you have to play it for yourself. Atmosphere in this game is creepy and at the same time mysterious. While the main story is great I also enjoed additional storys unlocked after finding collectibles. Possesing people is a bit limited and so is exploring Salem, but its worth checking to know more about Salems past and his residents. Graphics are fantastic and looks similar to next gen titles like Infamous Second Son.Overall if you like games like Alan Wake, Heavy Rain or Infamous Second Son, you have to try Murdered: Soul Suspect.PROS: + Great main story + Awesome main character+ Voice acting+ Beautiful graphics+ Investigating crime scenes+ Cat possesion sequences+ Mystery and creepy atmoshere+ Creepy unlockable storys(collectibles)+ Easter eggsCONS:- short (main story took me about 8 hours)- QTE when fighting demons- no chapter selection after ending- sometimes stutters on cutscenes

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												If you are a fan of alan wake or L.A Noire, then don't play this. I felt they could have done so much more with this game, there is no sense of urgency when you have to take out demons. The "investigation" sections are repetative and offer no real challenge and there are no consequences for "guessing" conclusions to the investigations. As for the story, it's not bad but I never felt like it drew me in, and the plot twists were quite predictable. Graphically this game is quite pretty and gives off a spooky vibe. I feel they could have done more with the battle system, since there really isn't one, as well as done more with the open world provided, there is no real incentive to go and explore the world apart from the option collectibles which offer nothing more than bits of lore about the history of the town and events. I felt this game COULD have been the next Alan Wake but the developers fell horribly short. I felt no sense of achievement in finishing this game in a little more than 6 hours.4/10 - wouldn't recommend.

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Plot 5/10:The game relies on one of the most overused tropes in regards to Salem's history for it's primary plot. At least in high schools in Mississippi, The Crucible is required reading. Any experience with it and you'll have guessed the killer's name by the time you first meet. The only thing that will come as a shock is who the person targets and manipulates.Gameplay: 4/10It was playable, but the audio would skip occasionally in cutscene, the game stuttered regularly, and the "stealth or not" portions were absurdly easy. You'll be forgetting to hold down a button for getting rid of demons more than you'll actually be bothered by them. Also, the walking through walls, possessing people, and such loses its flair pretty quickly. Especially considering half of the NPCs share the exact same 2 lines of inner monologue when you possess them even though they're 15 feet apart, and that's not exaggeration. Plus, you'll spend the majority of the extremely short story trying to look for the clues that require you to aim directly at them before the prompt appears. Extremely frustrating at times.Overall, your best bet is to not waste your money till this game goes on sale.

Beautiful graphics, great music and sound effects. Easy to play using the controller. Hope they do a sequel or at least another game in the same gender and style. I definitely recommend. It's worth. Best game of the year!

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Understand beforehand that Murdered: Soul Suspect is a cinematic puzzle adventure game with all the trappings you expect from such. I felt it was reminiscent of Dreamfall and Indigo Prophecy. Its also not REALLY a detective game you just mouse around and collect clues then piece them together to complete the "puzzle" to further your investigation. Like an advenure game really. Overall I enjoyed it, the game is visually stunning, the sound and voice acting is top notch. What really blew me away was how detailed and expressive the characters faces were. The only problem is this is $50 for a puzzle adventure game! Since this is a Square title though you can expect the price to drop drastically and if it cost half as much and you like the genre I would say pick this game up for sure.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												I was interested in this game from the moment of its announcement, and now having played it, I definitely do not regret the purchase. It has a very interesting twist right at the beginning and overall it reminds me of a blend of a number of games, including Blade Runner and Max Payne, however odd that might sound. I most certainly haven't seen all of it yet, but the effects, possibilities and abilities you have as a spirit are well implemented. Your main character being a spirit is certainly believable. The amount of interaction is just right and the story so far as interesting as it is sad.The only major problem and complaint I have with this game is the inability to remap key bindings for any of the controls. Considering the game is Unreal engine based, that is neither understandable, nor really acceptable. However, having found a way around this problem (see my guide at the end of this review), "Murder: Soul Suspect™" is as playable as it is fun. If you enjoy a spooky, dark and well told detective story, then this is definitely for you!Please check out my guide that can help with using different key bindings:


Key remapping guide 
A Guide for MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: jssrfx

			Murder: Sould Suspect™ will not allow you to remap your key bindings and game controls, and for people like me, who for various reasons don't like the default controls, this should help to resolve the issue.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an interesting witch tale set in modern times.The game itself is a very linear experience. It is semi-open world, otherwise I'd call it a movie-on-rails. Salem, the town the game is based in and which is the main hub, can be explored at will and travel from there to the various other destinations as they become available. Everyplace can be returned to later as you see fit. Unfortunately there is no map and that can be a little frustrating when intentionally exploring rather than progressing the story forward. There is a digital collectibles map, I'm aware of, but because this game came with my video card, I did not receive access to that map.This game is easy. The only enemies, Demons, are token representatives of resistance which only serve to draw out the amount of time you spend in a few areas rather than actually representing a challenge to be overcome. They are simply annoying obstacles. The game would have been better without them, in my opinion, as they just slowed down the story, which was frustrating at times. Investigations are the main action the player goes through to progress the story forward at each juncture. They are similar to those in LA Noire, although they are far simpler to investigate. You will search the scene for clues and then pick the most important clues. Several times clues seemed much too obvious and I overthought them, choosing wrong, believing something much more subtle was going on. But don’t worry; your rating on investigation outcomes is meaningless. The most obvious answers are, unfortunately, the correct answers. This game is not subtle in the least. So don’t come looking for a challenge in either enemies or story puzzle elements.There is a great deal of collectible items. If the game narrative is one half of the game, the collectibles are the other half- they make up a significant proportion of the story, in the form of supplemental background information and well written ghost story videos. These are not difficult to locate, most can be found without any effort at all. Good news for those who are practically OCD about collectibles or achievement ♥♥♥♥♥s, as there are plenty of achievements for collecting. In summary, it’s a good story to experience one but is not really worth replaying. If you like easy, single player games with modern day fantasy stories, this game may be for you. I definitely recommend buying this game if it is on sale, you really can’t go wrong. It is bug free and complete out of the box, no need to worry about patches or the possibility of DLC. This game is pretty much a console port, so it worked with, and felt designed for, my Xbox 360 controller.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game feels like it HAD to meet a deadline. Everything about it is clunky and unfinished. Despite being a ghost, the protagonist has a terrible habit of getting caught on every piece of geometry ever. There's also very little to no player agency throughout the entire game, making it feel like one giant cutscene, all things considered. The game looks dated, the writing is poor, and the characters are flat and unlikeable. The plot is *okay*, but the ending is abrupt and predictable. This is likely worth your time for around $5, but otherwise I'd advice against it.

												I beat this game in 8 hours with all but 5 of the collectables found, and, overall, I enjoyed it.Pros: The story, detective style gameplay, and the settingCons: Some of the controls were a little odd (press r to reveal an item then again to collect it--really could be streamlined to one button press), the sections with the demons were more annoying than entertaining, and I really wish the game were longerI recommend Murdered: Soul Suspect with some reservations. 												I just finished the game.  I thought it was very well done, but keep in mind this in not an action, FPS kind of game.  It's a detective game.  I thought it could have done without the demons.  I didn't feel it really added anything to the storyline; it just made things irritating.  Other than the demons, I thought the storyline was interesting and I liked the character development between the main characters.  I like the way they handled the clues and the "mini-game" kind of feel for figuring them out.  You actually have to pay attention to what's been going on and things you've investigated in the past to do a good job solving the questions.  Eventhough I enjoyed the game, like most mystery type games, it's not very replayable (unless you're a "completionist") considering you know how it ends.  Interesting twist at the end.

												One of the best games I've played in recent memory. Brilliant murder-mystery detective game. The demons in the game are honestly the most terrifying I've come across in a long time, making for some qenuinely tense moments.The sound design stands out by far as the best aspect. Posted: June 28, 2014
												A fun premise: solving your own murder, possessing cats and being able to walk through walls.Too bad investigation is simply a treasure hunt followed by a guessing game.  Walking through walls sounds like it should be freeing, but the majority of walls in this game are unpassable which makes the entire experience strangely claustrophobic.This feels like a game whose design had many more elements, but wasn't given the resources to expand much beyond the primary gameplay elements.For a game whose plot is so central I would have hoped to have more twists and turns. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game cuts a lot of corners, and in a bad way. I will start off by saying that you shouldn't expect anything innovative in terms of gameplay and story because there is literally nothing to this game. Have you played Heavy Rain or Beyond Two Souls? Remember how there was some gameplay in that? Take that,  but remove more of the gameplay and make it a noclip simulator 2014 edition because all you'll  be doing is walking around and looking at things. Slight spoilers ahead.The detective bits? Bland, and obvious as the story is. Sure you won't figure out who the killer is but you will pick up what the deal is with the Killer and still have the protagonist and everyone else bumping their heads into the walls being clueless. Anyone could of picked up the patterns since it was so obvious but near the end of the game that you'll be eager for it to end. Unless you're easy to please. Oh there's a twist to the plot but it doesn't make any gatdam difference to the plot nor does it change anything at all for the later part.Now let's get to gameplay, aka wonder around a building trying to navigate and occassionally posessing people just to influence. There's no point in posessing other people that aren't vital to the "INVESTIGATE ZONE" since they all have two lines in mind read and that's it. Reused model heads on different bodies and that's it, find a creeper ghost in some kid's closet only to find five more of him with multiple jobs. Investigate zones are what I like to call areas that you'll be trying to search every nook and cranny to find enough clues to conclude the level, and that itself is also really annoying. Most of the clues are hard to see, and I understand how it is but if I have to look hard through one big room just to realize I need to examine some bloody cat prints for no reason that aren't even remotely related to the case then what's the point? This game is more hollow than how I felt when I beat it.As for the supposed combat? Horrible. There's nothing to it, and it's the most bland thing you'll ever experience. The demons that you face are always set on a path, they won't hunt you down unless they see you nor explore any rooms other than the patrol paths that they'll never stray from. Killing them is also a chore. Press direction + button = instant victory. That's all to it. They're just there to hinder you and nothing else. They'll arrive in the area you just left and have to backtrack to because they can. You can't get by them either so you have to fight them. You can hide and wait patiently. It just feels like they threw them in there just "because." They don't have any real point to them other than to add more than just walking around and "examine" things.There are side quests though, and that's just more INVESTIGATE ZONES for you to burn time away in to make the game last longer. Will you get anything for it? No. There are collectables, will you get anything for it? No. Only thing you will get is achievements, and  that's it. There are no rewards, there's no good feeling having to help ghosts and frustrate yourself in INVESTIGATE ZONES that are so damn open or have clues so hidden that you can't complete it. A good example is one quest where you have to find out if a guy killed his friends or not, and the objective is "Who saw the driver?" No one in that area, not even the Taxi cab driver who was probably called the other night. There's no point in any of these side quests, nor the collectibles to find out "Salems history" or backstory.If I want to read about Salem's obvious history that I learned in history class, I'll use gatdam google3/10Don't buy it unless it's on sale for like ten bucks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I'll start off by saying this isn't a game for everyone.  If you're all about being a big badass and toting around guns shooting everything, then you're probably not going to enjoy this.  Murdered: Soul Suspect feels like a watered down version of Alan Wake - thriller with a story that tends to pull you along with the "I need to know!" vibe.  I play games a lot for the story and this definitely gave me one.I enjoyed the take on some of the history of the Old Salem witch trials; a lot of their information being factual.  The witch trials were a huge interest for me as a kid, so it spurred a lot of nostalgia in me for that alone.The graphics were pretty.  Not OHMYGODNEXTGENBEAUTIFUL, but very pretty and fun.Controls were simple enough.  It's a very point and click style game.  You don't get story-determining choices as you do in TellTale games, but you're actively searching, interacting with the enviornment for clues, hiding from demons, or possessing cute lil' kitty cats to get you into places you couldn't go otherwise.My main gripes were very minor.  - You can complete the game easy in a day.  - Some of the cutscenes were distorted and compressed - which I felt took away from the appeal of the otherwise pretty graphics.  - Not much of a soundtrack.- Some of the clearly older ghosts wearing modern clothing, which like choppy cutscenes, will yank you out of the "mood".- Glitches.  Holy moly.  I didn't have crashing issues or "sticking" problems as some people have reported, but it absolutely infuriated me that some areas/quests were not accessable once you left that area... ala; girl on the beach being the main culprit.  So unless you're willing to sit through a game twice or have the manual on hand, this will more than likely agitate those who are achievement hunters.7.5/10

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game flows similar to crime drama TV shows. If you like that sort of thing, then have at it. If not, you will probably not enjoy this game.For those that have stuck around, this game has a plethora of stories to endulge youself in. The animation is good, and the world is semi-open. Certain areas have to be unlocked to explore, but you can explore areas you've already visited to look for clues, collectibles, and side-stories.Unfortunately, no game is without it's drawbacks. The cutscenes are a little slow paced and will usually end by focusing on your next objective. This can be seen as a helpful hint, but I found myself rolling my eyes since they were being so blunt about it. I've found a couple of bugs, and the animations get a little funky sometimes (i was talking to a particularly animate ghost who kept spinning her arms like windmills), but nothing game breaking. Overall, I have enjoyed this game and I highly encourage anyone who is familiar with the sleuthing genre to check it out.
