content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This game, man, this game. I first discovered this game while at a friend's house. She was playing through it on the Xbox 360 console. I loved what bits I saw her play. As soon as I got home, I searched the game up and was ecstatic find that it was also developed for PC. I put in on my Wishlist and waited until I had the money to purchase it. And so came the Steam sale for this Autumn. I bought it immediately. Bottom line: It was so worth the money, and would be worth paying full price in order to play this gem of a game.Atmoshpere: CreepyYou would think, that being a ghost, you wouldn't have to worry about getting creeped out. Ha. Ha. This game proves that wrong. Graphics: BeautifulRan really smoothly on my PC as wellStory: AmazingThe voice acting is really well done. The story, oh god the story, is fantastic. I wasn't expecting the ending, which was a pleasant surprise. If you're a fan of horror and mystery games, buy this. It's worth it.10/10

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												This game is worth a try, because the concept is something different. It may be lacking in some execution, but it is well worth the ideas and imagination you can spring from it.First of all, I had problems trying to get the game to launch at all. A quick google search however and an edit of the Launch settings in steam quickly fixed that.Murdered: Soul Suspect brings a lot of enjoyment from being a ghost - picking up trace memories, reading minds, influencing people, poltergeist, walking through walls and objects etc. Couple that with a detective story where you have to solve YOUR OWN murder means you really are motivated to get the guy. Added to this are the potential dangers of the ghost world in the form of demons (although the are very easy opponents) means the story of Ronan in Salem is very immersive. The story itself has enough twists and turns to keep you exited as well as a string of pretty gruesome murders that I find myself revolted by. There are plenty of collectibles to find although most seem dotted in obvious places.The game does sort of feel a lot older than it is, but it is still worth the 10 hours of story.

Posted: November 30, 2015
												This game is definitely worth a look purely because of the concept. You play as a ghost investigating your own murder and really does have an interesting idea. It has a small, free-roamy playing area which is quite fun to explore and the ability to walk through most objects (you're a ghost, remember) is one of my favourite gameplay mechanics.I feel it falls down on a bolted-on combat-ish system with demons which are just annoying and probably don't do anything for the game. The story is OK and follows an investigation-driven gameplay, although it does seem very simple. It is quite nice how extra abilities are slowly added throughout the game and most collectables are interesting; again a lot of this area is very simple and you may find yourself shouting "I already knew that!" angrily at your monitor.

												The game is about 10 hours of story, with lots of cutscenes, and lots of collectibles. The price tag at £20 is a little pricey, but if you see it on sale, definitely go for it.The story and gameplay mechanics are interesting. The combat does let it down, but thankfully there is not a lot of it. The game looks great, and the voice-acting is fantastic. The faces are not so great, and can damper the emotional impact of scenes sometimes. There are some bugs/glitches which can be game breaking. I did not encounter any on my first play through, but on my second some areas did not load properly causing me to become unable to progress (the museum).Important things to note:- The game uses an autosave feature only with no hard save- The collectibles do carry on through gameplays for those achievement hunters- Very little replayability, as with most linear story-driven games- There is no key remapping

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Picked this one up on the Black Friday sale and I'm so glad I did. I've been wanting to play it but was put off by the high price tag. The controls feel a little strange, even though they're relatively typical for a PC game. I found the mouse movements to be incredibly sensitive, however, and wasn't able to find a way to easily slow it down. Once I got used to it, though, it was fine.  Don't expect super complex controls. Basically, you have forward, backwards, sideways and interact. Pay attention to what the screen tips are telling you about the type of interaction. The storyline is fascinating and if you like solving mysteries it will really pull you in. There are a few side mysteries to solve and ghost stories to find. The game doesn't send you running around all over the map for the mysteries, but it also isn't in your face about where you're supposed to be looking for clues. It's a nice balance. You get more shields (points) if you get the answer right the first time but you'll have second and third chances.The atmosphere is suitably spooky, the sound effects and background music is really creepy - especially with the lights out. Fighting demons is interesting and can be challenging. Overally, I'm really enjoying the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												"...a game that tries far too hard to be likable..."This game is that of a failed attempt at greatness. The entire time playing, you get the sense that the story is there to try to elicit some emotion from the player. The problem is that the subtle nuance and grace that would create such feeling is missing. As a result you get something that simply feels unfinished. It's like a game that tries far too hard to be likable. Everywhere you turn the areas feel as if they've been patched together with duct tape and bailing wire. The best thing I can say for this game is that it's a good waste of time if you have nothing better to do. I bought it on sale for less than half the going rate at the time and, after playing it, I can honestly say that I would have spent not a cent more on this title had I known what lied therein.All that being said, the voice acting is quite acceptable and the story is engaging enough to allow you to finish the game. The gameplay is unique for a time but becomes tedious and downright boring as the game wears on. With a bit more variety in gameplay, and bit more thought in plot development, this game could have been a diamond in the rough. Though as it stands, it is nothing more than an unfulfilled dream... and it shows.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an interesting game. Think of it as a point-and-click adventure game, (I'd compare it to the Blackwell series, specifically) but with a massive budget. The gameplay is all about finding clues to further the story. Expect no action. Seriously.Pros:-Interesting story-Open hub area to explore-Lots of collectibles-Interesting game mechanics-You're a ghost, you can do ghost things-Posess cats, climb stuffCons-Short for a $50 game-Can be slow-Demon stealth encounters interrupt gameplay*-Story feels rushed at the end-Salem is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed labyrinth-Collectibles are meaningless *(A quick google search will turn up a simple and quick way to make this a non-issue by changing a line of code in an .ini file.)I bought this for $15, and at that price I feel satisfied, but much more and I'd feel like I paid too much. If you're interested in the story or the ghost things pick this up when it's on sale, otherwise I recommend avoiding it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Unfolds like an unpretentious B-movie, which I see as a virtue. Your protagonist wears a fedora and chain smokes, and you visit requisite horror locations like a graveyard, mental hospital, and an abandoned mansion. It's to the credit of the writing that this game hardly ever feels cliché, with the ending in particular taking advantage of the game's premise to twist a familiar trope into something more unpredictable. Theres almost no way to screw things up in the main story which might bother some people but I was fine with how laid back this game felt (also, I ♥♥♥♥ed up every time I had to decide if someone was lying in LA Noire, so I was happy to not have to do that again). The stealth/combat sections are indeed the worst parts of the game, but they're easy so it is hard to regard them as much of a problem. I experienced no technical issues and overall was pleasantly surprised by the experience. If you're interested in the premise I would recommend this for under $25. Don't let the low review scores scare you, this was never a game that the gaming press would embrace en masse anyway.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												This game flows similar to crime drama TV shows. If you like that sort of thing, then have at it. If not, you will probably not enjoy this game.For those that have stuck around, this game has a plethora of stories to endulge youself in. The animation is good, and the world is semi-open. Certain areas have to be unlocked to explore, but you can explore areas you've already visited to look for clues, collectibles, and side-stories.Unfortunately, no game is without it's drawbacks. The cutscenes are a little slow paced and will usually end by focusing on your next objective. This can be seen as a helpful hint, but I found myself rolling my eyes since they were being so blunt about it. I've found a couple of bugs, and the animations get a little funky sometimes (i was talking to a particularly animate ghost who kept spinning her arms like windmills), but nothing game breaking. Overall, I have enjoyed this game and I highly encourage anyone who is familiar with the sleuthing genre to check it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Let me save you the time, and let you know that while this will be a review, it is going to read as more of a rant than anything else. Understand going in that I am not going to recommend any one play this game, at all. The reasons will be detailed below, but I am writing this as a way of venting my frustrations with the game, and treating the main purpose of this as a "buyers beware" because let me tell you, I am not going to let the store page lie to you. I will get to that in a second. That being said, Murdered Soul Suspect is the most dissapointing game of the year for me. Hands down. When it comes to expectations (what little I had asked from it in the first place) Not only did they fail miserably, they somehow managed to fail at even the BASIC expectations.  So what were my expectations? I just wanted a good mystery game. Interact with the environment/clues, piece stuff together. Learn about the mystery and basically just immerse myself as a detective. It didn't have to be a compelling narrative or anything, but for the story, I at LEAST wanted a likable main character.  I didn't EXPECT an L.A. Noire esque mystery game, and I would have even allowed a Deadly Premonition esque kind of mystery game. But this......WHAT IS THIS?Where do I even begin with this game. I hope if you are foolish enough to read my tirade you will at least have the respect for yourself to have a snack. Buckle in boys and girls, here comes the salt.  I want to address the store page bullet points real quick. To get this out of the way now. It's a good starting point as any. I won't address them all, just the ones I object to, and you, the future buyer, deserve to know the truth of. -"A twisting storyline supported by a great cast of characters constantly raises questions over the secrets that Salem hides."  This is cute. What great cast of characters? No. I am not being facetious, I mean what great cast of characters? Where are they? There are characters, sure, and I would have loved to learn more about them, but 75% of the cast occassionally drops in for that ol "THEY COULD BE THE KILLER" scooby doo schtick.  No in reality the game really only focuses on Ronan (main character) and Joy, his spirit medium. Every other character isn't any more developed than the last beyond fulfilling the cliche role they were intended to fulfill. There is no "constantly raising questions over the secrets that Salem hides." It's no secret. No, I want you as the reader, right now, to mentally say the first thing that comes to mind when you hear the word Salem. If you said "oh the Salem witch trials right?" then you my friend, are one smart turkey. Tadah. Oh, and there is only one main twist. I don't know where this twisting storyline business comes from. That implies it's constantly twisting.-" Move freely from one haunting location to the next and even if you have completed your investigation, return to previous scenes to follow new leads." Sounds compelling right? By move freely they mean you are essentially in a little invisible walled off box, and boy let me tell you there are a TON of invisible walls. Yes, you can return to previous scenes, but "to follow new leads?" What on EARTH are you TALKING ABOUT? The only time you return to a previous scene is if you forgot some disposable optional collectible you wanted to collect for 100% completion that doesn't do jack for you unless you are trying to get all the achievements. None of this "new lead" bullcrap. You don't change the outcome of anything. You are merely just taking a guided tour through this game.-"Seek-out hundreds of collectibles, side-quests and cases from Salem’s citizens past to learn facts about the town and its people, improve your detective ranking and help you piece together the truth about the killer." If there was ever a burning point I wanted to address, it's this one. This one, singular sentence on their page. It's complete false advertising. First off, while there are a COUPLE hundred (not hundreds) of collectibles, there are NOT hundreds of sidequests and cases from Salem's citizens. There are FOUR cases (not a typo) where you help out deceased citizens, and  EIGHT collectible sidequests that reveal a story of a previous murder not really tied to the main quest murders. The other collectibles that involve the main quest killer? They don't help you piece together ANYTHING about the killer other than he likes killing  and little blurbs from tabloids. How does that HELP anything? and honestly, with how poorly fleshed out and planned the characters were, you can more or less figure out who the killer is within the first 2-3 hours of gameplay.  The twist was nice, but again, you kind of expect it. The really sucky part about all this is they should have done more with the sidequests involving helping the citizens come to term with their death. But no, you get 4 quests, and the other spirits you run into, you get a two choice branch that changes nothing and it just falls flat. Or hey! hey! better yet! more of those collectible stories involving the side murders but you know, without the cheap copout collectible requirements! MAKE THOSE ACTUAL MISSIONS.  It would have been a farcry better than what we actually received.-"Survive powerful demonic spirits who devour souls in a belief that they can regain their own. Strategically use supernatural abilities to evade and outwit them before they tear away your soul forever." HAHAHHAHA, "strategically?"  STRATEGICALLY?! Are you kidding me?! What STRATEGY? Wh-what, you mean, exploiting the terrible AI of the 3 enemies at any given moment by hiding in plain sight, waiting for them to lose aggro, then mashing a QTE prompt? Or, or, using the various distraction options available (j/king you can only distract them with one thing, a crow) and then rinsing and repeat? Get out of here with that nonsense. Stop dressing up this lazy nonsense to sound fancy. Shame on you.Now that is out of the way, let's talk "gameplay." Well, you can basically consider this game a semi-rails game. Or, more or less, a guided tour game. You aren't actually playing the game. I mean, yes,you are controlling Ronan, and he is responding to your controls, but literally 60% of the gameplay is you collecting stuff. It's like a giant collectible scavenger hunt. When you aren't collecting things that have no rhyme or reason or impact to the game, the other 40% of the game is you "solving" crime scenes. But, YOU aren't solving SQUAT. The GAME has that covered. Look, there is no penalty for guessing wrong or deducing something wrong. All the clues are in the same room. There is no interacting with clues. Hell, the game will sometimes literally zoom in on the primary clue in a cutscene before you even start, rendering all your clue collecting pointless. AND, when you DO have all the clues collected, guess what reader? The game is like, "soooo what do you think happened" and you piece together 1-3 of the clues to "solve the scene." BUT AGAIN, there is no penalty for failing. It's as braindead as you can possibly get. My favorite moment occurs when the killer is looking at a picture, and the game asks me "Well, what do you think he is doing?" and 6+ words flood the screen and you gotta figure out what he is doing. He is clearly startled and up to no good, and literally half the options are the exact opposite of the mood being displayed. What is this, Dora the Explorer? Agh... this game, I haven't even scratched much of the surface, there is so much I want to talk about. So much...so much rage. But I have already spent too much time talking about the game. Look, I don't like it. I think it's highway robbery they would seriously ask for $50 of YOUR HARD EARNED MONEY for this crap. TL;DR: I  hate this game.

												To start off I just want to say that I'd only recommend purchasing this game when it is discounted. It took me 14 hours of playtime to clear the game with 100% completion, and would have taken less if I'd have used a guide to find all the collectibles. So consider that if you're moving along at a decent pace and you're only torturing yourself over the ghost story collectibles so that you can get those extra short stories unlocked you should expect about 8-10 hours of playtime to get through this.So to me, a price of 20-30 dollars sounds reasonable (about 2 dollars per hour of entertainment).This game plays and feels very similarly to other story-driven cinematic games where much of what you are doing is exploration and interacting with the environment. There is no real combat in the game, only a dozen or so sections where you need to sneak up on enemies and button-combination eliminate them without being noticed. If you've played Heavy Rain or Indigo Prophecy/Fahrenheit you know what sort of gameplay to expect.As far as the game itself (and by game I mean movie) is concerned I found it enjoyable though the ending is fairly predictable. If you've ever seen the movie The Frighteners with Michael J. Fox the game feels very similar (in a good way).

												So far this game is very good.  It's a great detective game with a supernatural twist.  You are playing as Ronan who is now a ghost and he is trying to solve his own murder.  It's a great concept and very well done.  You search for clues in the different environments while avoiding or destroying demons.  You also have some side quests to do which involve helping lost souls pass on.  All in all I am very pleased with the game and glad I was able to pick it up during the summer sale.  The only issue I have is there is no save feature.  It is auto saved so if you want to stop playing you have to get to a check point before you can stop or you will lose all your progress.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I would only recommend this shoddy excuse for a game during a sale. The game treats you like you are the world's biggest idiot the whole game. Look around a crime scene pick out the most important detail. If you get it wrong the first time it doesn't matter because there isn't an apparent penalty for being wrong other than a red flash and something along the lines of ''No. I need to find something that would actually help me figure this out. I'm a moron for thinking this could help." It literally feels like an indy game with the gameplay of a flash game but with the graphics of a good game... speaking of graphics... hope you dont have a♥♥♥♥♥♥computer like me, or else you are going to wait 2 minutes for every cinematic to load on the lowest quality setting... Do you know how many cinematics this game had? Alot. Literally the only two reasons I kept playing it to the end was because I spent 30 bucks on it like an idiot and because I kind of wanted to watch the story. It sucks that this writing staff made such a great story, but the people who decided on game mechanics were like... this game is going to be played by 5 year olds right? I mean Jesus Christ! It never gets any harder than the begining. And just when something different happens: I won't spoil what it is, you realize that its just a crappy last minute add in to the... movie... im just gonna call it a playable movie... thats what it is. So I guess if you like movies, murder mysteries, have a good computer, and don't mind being treated with the intellegence of a newborn lemur then this game is for you. Otherwise... please buy it on a sale and don't make the same mistake i did.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Worth a play if you can get it on sale. Soul Suspect is a detective adventure game. Calling it a horror game does a dis-service to actual horror games so I'll just say it has a dark atmosphere. The story is kinda mediocre, somewhat predictabe and relatively short (I finished it in 8 hours, while doing a pretty good amount of exploring). The controls are kinda sticky at times.  Some interacions should be based on proximity instead of the current system of it being based on where the camera is centered. There is very little character progression in regards to powers and the powers are a tad lame. 'Battles' in this game consist of sneaking up on enemies to trigger a QTE to defeat them. If you are spotted by them or fail the QTE, you're forced to run and hide until the enemy gives up at which point you can try again. There is only one enemy type in the entire game, save for the 'final boss.' The crime scene system (not sure what it's officially called) is interesting but will often penalize you for not being able to answer their vaguely asked question in the exact way they want you to. Not sure if this is a localization thing or someting else. Some of the clues are absurd to be called 'clues'  and I wa somestimes annoyed that I had to click on it to make the observation into a 'clue.' Also, as mentioned about the controls, because the camera has to be centered on the item for prompts to show up, I would often miss clues because a prompt didn't pop up -- this would just add unnecessary time as I'd be searching for that last clue and then realize that I hadn't properly centered the camera on the item for the prompt to come up.I got this during a recent sale for under $10 and I think that's a fair price for the game. It wasn't spectacular but was interesting enough to keep me occupied. Frankly, games like this should not be released at full console retail price when the quality of the product doesn't warrant so.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Remember The Darkness? This game plays a little bit like that, with the 'other world on top of this world' vibe... Except that Ronan is a WAY more likable and funny guy than Jackie, who - if Im going to be generous - had the personality of a piece of sopping wet cardboard. (Yes I've read the comics. I stand by my statement.)Gameplay can get a little clunky, but you arent asked to do action sequences more than a few times, so mostly it's just atmosphere. Said atmosphere can, at times, get a little repetative, but it did manage to maintain a pacing of steadily getting creepier and creepier. The tense string instruments make you want to turn around and slap the musicians for scaring you like a little girl. Play at night with the lights off for maximum effect, obviously.Power through the story if you get tired of the levels; they dont take long. The story itself had a few 'whodunit' twists and a few others you can see a mile out, but still. It's not terrible, and history nerds get a nice stroll through Salem that doesnt overwhelm people who dont give a rat's behind about what happened in 1800-and-who-cares.Conclusion: A nice timekiller that wont take up more than a day of dedicated play or a few days of off and on. WARNING: The menu in here IS glitchy as all heck, so stay out of it as often as you can.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I'm a big fan of adventure games, more so than shooters and racing and such. There are a lot of good ones out there, and a lot of bad. I wasn't at sure at first which this would be. It's not your point-and-click type. But it's also not overly NOT point-and-click. Which then gets more into RPG and such.The premise - you're dead to begin with - on it's own made me thing "huh?". And it works beautifully. As a "ghost", the game doesn't completely rely on, but is mostly based on, things you can (and can not) do, as a "spirit".I think it works nicely. Without a map (I think, a "where you've been" map of at least the current items (not the ghostly ones) would be a little more helpful) I found myself running around in (and through) circles a lot.The main plot is fairly linear. If you just follow the "now you have to go here" line and do what you're "told", it's pretty straight forward, you go to a location that it tells you to. You collect evidence at that place.That alone would still make a good game because of how it's done. But the additional stuff, while key to the whole story, isn't necessary to "win" the game, make it not just a Point A to Pont B game. Overall - play it! I'm going to again, because I didn't solve some of the sidelines, and I meant to. A semi-negative. Which did make it harder to complete some side quests, and to a little degree even the main quest: "Actionable" items were sometimes weird. Not that you weren't right on top of them. But that you had to face just the right direction, look the right direction. A lot of items I "accidently" found, just because I happened to notice the "action" text popup for a second. Altough sometimes I thought it might be, but it was just the XXm to next destination text moving positions.Anyways, great game, great concept. I hope there's a sequel. Or well, not sequel, but a similar concept. Possesing a cat just rocks :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Shortly: Very impressive game with a bit lacking port to PC. Maybe not worth 40€ but if it ends up below 25€ you can get and be sure it was worth it.Game is heavily focused on story, and as such it has very good voice acting and great animations. I like it a lot. It is not as long as L.A. Noire, but still I can reccomend it without hesitation. If you like to snuff around and read a lot about the character and world you'll not regret this. One thing that I don't like is the quality of PC port. It feels 'consolish'. If you can get over it you'll have quite nice detective game experience. I wouldn't recommend getting it for 40€ though. 25€ at most. Not that I think it was not a lot of work for devs - It definitely was judging by overall quality - but it wasn't the best PC port I've ever seen and I ended it in about 10hrs. I could use a bit more sidequests. Especially challenging ones.But as I already wrote - I can recommend it without doubt anyway.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Murdered: Soul SuspectIn Murdered: Soul Suspect you play the role of a deceased police officer who is murdered by the mysterious serial killer The Bell Killer it's now up to you as a ghost and a couple of other characters to catch this murderer and bring him to justice so that you can finish your part in this life and be with your beloved wife.Pros-Interesting and great narrative-Amazing voice acting-Great graphics-Lots of collectibles-Different settingCons-Shallow Gameplay (fight off demons by sneaking behind and investigations)-Not enough NPC models so you can find 2 or 3 of the same kind in the same area-Not enough replayability once you know what happens there's no reason for a second playthrough-very short wish it was longer finished in one sittingIn the end Murdered: Soul Suspect is a fun detective ghost story with some great voice acting a strong narrative being the strongest points of the game, so if you want a game based on the gameplay then this is not for you but for those of you willing to purchase the game then this is very good however I would recommend you buy this on sale or from any other means I got this through the Square Enix Humble Bundle 2 which is great!Murdered: Soul Suspect7/10

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												This game is short and not very challenging. 99% of the investigation puzzles I got right on the first try. The "combat" is slow and not particularly rewarding, and you only fight one enemy type throughout the entire game. A keen mind will recognize the primary villain immediately, but there are some creative twists that get thrown into the mix and spice up the story a bit. As a game, it's subpar, a step above a narrative journey. Not even the backstories were particularly interesting. However what I really liked about the game was its take on the spirit world, spirit powers, and the way spirits interact with the mortal world. It is a very unique theme and approach, and would have made a very exciting game if they had tried a little harder.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I was expecting either a run of the mill horror game or a glorified walking simulator. I couldn't have been more wrong. 1) Horror: I decided to play this right after Outlast because I was in that type of mood. Soul Suspect still managed to get my heart rate up and creep me out in a few spots. 2) Walking SImulator: I think the only one I ever played was Gone Home. It was a great story, it was kind of creepy but it was so human at the same time. Sure there are ghosts and demons and witches, but the story is about people. You really get to learn about the people by just walking around and clicking on things.3) Police Procedural: The only other ones that come to mind are the CSI games and LA Noir, none of which I've played. Althought the "puzzles" if you want to call them that were simple, they at least made it feel like I was involved in hashing out the next step.My only gripe is that some of the collectables were in places I'd have never looked had I not eventually given up and looked them up. I'm not a fan of these things though and they are totally optional so it doesn't really efffect the game unless you want it to.I've been playing video games since the early 80s and I've been using steam since the Orange Box was bundled with video cards. Two things I hardly ever do are complete a game 100% and write a review. I've now done both for this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												I say no with some hesitance. Over all this game is not down right poor, but it has some glaring problems, such as story telling, character personality, and the mystery portion, none of which are well done. The mystery portion is constantly interrupted by "demons" which become a nuisance to the storyline, even stopping you at times by setting up silly puzzles to figure out. They've an overbearing feeling of being tossed in in since they are never truly explored or explained which leaves them as a pointless adversary just to "make" the game more difficult. They fail to add any atmosphere of fear to the world. The enitrety of the puzzle ought to've been focused on the mystery portion rather than setting up mini-antagonists for the protagonist to fight. The character feels flat in a world that shouts immersion, his story never comes to fruition and his prescence feel limited and small in the world the writers attempt to set up. The entire process of solving mysteries is interesting, but leaves you feeling and wanting more each time you solve the mini-games. All in all, as a mystery game it sets up well in the beginning but quickly loses motion towards the end, and the distraction of the demons truly impacts the ability to explore freely and find clues. It's a catchy concept but could've been better executed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												For a game that plays pretty much like an elaborate point and click adventure game, definitely not worth the full price. However, if a serious puzzle-filled detective game is your cup of tea, $20 is a pretty good price for the game.The puzzles generally involves picking up clues (which are mostly not highlighted, but prompts appear if you aim at the correct objects) and then piecing them together to answer a question. It is somewhat refreshing that the game does less hand-holding than most recent titles, however smaller clues can be easily missed and makes the game slightly frustrating if you're missing certain important clues. While losing badges may look somewhat intimidating, it is impossible to fail the game for the most part; the only ways to fail are the stealth sections and easily avoidable patches on the ground.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is probably best described as a story driven puzzle game. You don't shoot anything and the only time you feel like you are in danger is when you have to face demons that you can destroy by walking up behind them and perform a takedown action.The story revolves around a cop, name Ronan, who dies on duty chasing a serial killer and he can't ascend to the next plane of existence until his business on the mortal realm is resolved, so you have to hunt down the serial killer by solving crime scenes to determine what to do next.Overall I enjoyed the game and story, although once you finish you probably won't touch the game again unless you are trying to obtain 100% of the trophies. My recommendation is to buy the game when it is cheap, maybe around the $20 range or less.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												This is more like a thriller-horror novel for those who are too lazy to pick up a book than a game. So if you aren't interested in stuff like that i dont recommend buying this game. Overall the game is great! It actually requires lots of reading (wall of texts ahead!) to fully understand the plot (and trust me, it worth it). The side ghost stories in the game are spooky as well.The story is good. Basically you're on a case to find out about a serial killer called ''The Bell Killer''. While persueing the suspect alone, you got killed and kinda stucked in between the two worlds. You need to find out about the truth in order to ''move on''. Gameplay was simple, feels a bit repetitive; great atmosphere overall, can be a little spooky due to random ghosts. I got this game on sale so i wont be complaining. Definitely worth a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												The game at full price is a bit to expensive for the content that you get to my taste. On sale it is worth a look as it does give a rich story.The game plays very well and it gives a real immersive feeling to the story. This is something not a lot of games are able to do well in my opinion. Most games try to tell a story without making you part of the story. The story for me is the main selling point. The gameplay as such is interesting enough to keep you playing. The gameplay let's you investigate a scene looking for clues until you found all the clues. When you have all the clues you select the most important ones to conclude your investigation. What I found appealing is that the clues and getting to a conclusion do actually make sense. In some puzzle games you get to do a lot of trial and error for finding the correct answer.Although my feeling about the game is positive and I would recommend it if the regular price was right. For me 10EUR or less would be the right amount for this game looking at gametime and richness of content.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Although this game is extremely buggy, it is a great game if you can get it to run. Your character is a detective who, as a ghost, spends the game trying to figure out the identity of a serial killer. There are a lot of CSI-style investigation scenes. Because your character is a ghost, he also uses supernatural abilities to solve the case. The game takes place in the town of Salem where the infamous witch trials took place. The graphics are stellar and you can view the area around your character in all directions as he explores Salem. Although most of the game is confined to investigations in limited areas that proceed in a somewhat linear fashion, you have some freedom to explore each area openly, and you must determine how to properly use your powers and wits to solve the case. The downside of this game is that the game did not start at all after I first downloaded it. SquareEnix support was no help. I went to CrashWiki (a website) and downloaded some dll files to my System32 folder in order to get this game to run. But the game did run after I downloaded the dlls. The game still crashed every now and then. There is also no support for the 32-bit version of Windows. You must have the 64-bit version of Windows for the game to run. I do have 64-bit Windows, but I still experienced some problems. You will not be able to run the game at all if you have 32-bit Windows.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												I recently finished Murdered: Soul Suspect..............I read many negative reviews, but loved the concept of the game and wanted to give it a try. Imagine my surprise when the game turned out to be polished, nice looking, and so much fun I stopped playing other games I was involved in till it was done. (I was playing Dragon Age:Inquisition)One thing i haven't seen in the other reviews is how this game is really similar to Deus Ex: Human revolution. In fact, the computers in the police station are runing the menu screen for DE:HR, which is a nice little nod. The game's layout is similar, in that the City of Salem is the Hub of the game, and there are areas that you branch off into once you get to that part of the story, but return to the hub afterwards. There are many sidequests and collectables though out the game, some in the hub, some in the plot areas. Collect the items in the plot areas and get a ghost story which I enjoyed.The demons you have to avoid and sneak up on remind me of DE:HR as well, the game kept some of its mechanics for sure.The plot was good and the voice acting was excellent, if you listen closely you will hear voices you might recognize from other games. The music and sound effects are well done, especially the demon shrieks, and the ghostly and gloomy enviroments set the mood well. I admit I wish they would have made the game a bit longer, I finished at 13 hours, and wanted more when it ended. If I had not looked for the collectables, I could have went through it much faster.I highly recommend this game, especially if you can get it on sale at a good price. It's sad that airtight games closed its doors, as I would love to see a sequel, which will probably never happen. I don't understand the low scores the game has recieved, it deserved better.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												The type of game that makes me wish for a recommendation of "Only on sale"One of the few games out there that lets you play as a ghost doing actual ghost like things, the game is marred by several issues that really prevent it from working enough for me to give it a pass at normal prices.It's a puzzle game first and foremost that felt it had to add in some action in the form of stealth segments where you must avoid getting caught by demons, which usually boils down to accidentally getting spotted and having to waste time teleporting around safe spots waiting for them to resume patrolling so you can try again at doing a QTE to get them out of an area so you can go back to exploring.And then there's the puzzles, that boil down to trying to find every object in a given area and putting 2 or 3 of them together to solve a small mystery, sometimes operating off of logic and other times suffering from the Phoenix Wright problem where you're ahead of the game's characters but are forced to answer extremely handholding questions in order to advance (such as "there was a murder" as one of an early mystery's "most relevant" clues when you are asked to investigate a murder).However, that's not what really hurts this game. Instead, it's the simple lack of content. There isn't enough dialogue recorded for a game that features a mind-reading mechanic. There are very few side quests and after you complete them all the hub world you are forced to travel through seems very boring. Collectables are decent but don't seem to ever really be enough considering the amount of ground you cover between them. The main plot ends way too early for something that came out above $20. And those demons mentioned above? They are thrown in purely to prevent you from breezing through levels in 10 minutes.As you'll probably get through most of the content you care about in the first run, the game really lacks a lot of replay value, so your first run through is going to be about as long as you spend with the game. I went through with the "I'm going to try to collect as much as I can, but more than an hour without any result and I'm moving on" mentality, and I clocked about 8 hours (which includes a bit of idling time spent away from the computer).It's kind of sad, because the game isn't devoid of value, just not enough to justify purchasing it normally.Its writing, especially concerning some of the ghost stories you come across, is engaging, even if it's not the best you'll ever experience. Meanwhile, it completely nails the "I'm playing as a ghost detective" thing it was going for, even going so far as to have the first thing you do be trying to get back into your still barely alive body by trying to slip into it. If you liked Ghost Trick or Geist and wanted more games like that, this scratches that itch nicely.This game is worth playing for those who have a weakness for a somewhat noir detective game or one where you play as a ghost, but because you'll probably only need to play it once, get it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Really liked this one. 9 hours to complete, missed only 17 pickups out of 242. A good example of why Metacritic can suck it.A thief turned cop gets killed during an investigation, but with things really unresolved he just can't leave yet. So you go after your killer and help a bunch of other (sometimes not-so) recently deceased and meet up with a medium.There is nothing revolutionary, but it is a very well done adventure game (the only 'arcade' parts are dodging/killing demons from time to time.. and that was by far my least favorite part of the game) good focussed writing, a tale about ghosts in Salem that manages to stay interesting and not repetitive, good VO, nice density of hidden stuff to collect (only Abigail's graffiti were annoying because very little clues were apparent).I think most people disappointed in this one were expecting an action heavy game, and it really is n adventure game.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												You can control cats. 11/10Okay, now to the short and serious version.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a fun game and in my experience was an enjoyable game to play. The game gives a good ghostly detective story and will keep you occupied for a while. The game took me about 9 hours to beat, along with thoroughly indulging myself in finding all the collectibles (without them the game would've taken maybe around 7 to 8 hours).Things that I didn't like about the game was the lack of NPC's.... Mostly everyone you encounter (5 to 6) will have the same lines of dialogue (2) and will look the same, another thing was seeing some living NPC's walking through walls (which was hilarious to see), lastly- and the thing that bothered me was how the game would have random FPS drops in some areas.Overall : Murdered: Soul Suspect is a fun game to play that gives an above average story, but it's better to buy it when it's on sale (like right now since it's Steam Winter Sale). Game Rating : 8/10One last thing : The game has 0 replayability and is best played with V Sync off

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												It's a wonderful exploration and collection type game with a spooky (but not scarey) vibe to it, with detailed environments and lots of goodies to hunt down.There's only two issues that make it only worth buying when it's on sale and not at full price.The first is that it's fairly short.The second is the performance problems.  The frame rate is all over the place, so it feels like it's always stuttering.   This is one game where it might have been better if they limited the frame rate and tuned the game to that frame rate.   Only the demon hunts require any sort of timing and hand eye co-ordination, but you don't need 60 frames per second for that.There is a final thing that comes up and it depends a lot on what kind of gamer you are.   The game's mini-games aren't very challenging, and the solutions don't always make sense.  On the upside, aside from score keeping, the game doesn't really punish you for a wrong move.   If you screw up a demon hunt, you just respawn -- the demons you already took out don't respawn.   When you make a wrong choice in your investigation, you just lose a badge point (these aren't even important except for score keeping).   Even with no badge points left, you can keep picking until you get it right and continue the game.   There's very little frustration to this game.Worth buying, but don't pay more than $20 for it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Murdered Soul Suspect is a 3rd Person Ghost Walking Simulator. You are a cop, who has been murdered in the intro and must now try to solve your own murder (and several others). As you can barely interact with real worlds objects, you mainly walk around and look at things. From time to time you have to answer questions about the things you looked at, these questions are normally either embarrassing easy or the answers do not make much sense.There are some nice "ghost mechanics" included, mainly walking through walls, but they do not carry the game for its full (or half or quarter) length.So, what else can carry a game with stale gameplay?Visuals? They are nice, but no unique sales point.Music? There are mostly mysterious sound effect.That leaves us with: Story. And the build-up is great. Your dead cop character has a checkered past and is full of hurt, you have your run of the mill serial killer to follow, your teenage side kick complains a lot etc. The first third of the story is good, then not a lot happens, then a few foreseeable plot twists and it ends with ... a deus ex machina. In a nutshell:+ really good concept, no open end- gameplay is mainly walking around looking for stuff- story starts out good, then becomes less so and leaves you unsatisfied

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												TL:DR - 12hr run time if you hunt for collectables. Average plot, decent but not groundbreaking and ultimately predictable. Decent mechanics and character abilities. Reasonably well written characters. All of this is hindered and spoiled by the frustrating need to kill demons when the kill sequence is buggy as hell and only serves to slow the game down and annoy you. Still worth playing, but be prepared to be thoroughly annoyed for about a quarter of the game.Overall it's got a decent plot, decent set design, interesting game mechanics. The Investigation side of things is pretty typical, doesn't stretch very far from the conventions of the genre but does involve a few quirks to give it it's own identity (e.g. you can uncover clues and information through possessing people and manipulating them into giving up information).The plot is, for the most part, pretty predictable. For example, *minor spoiler, no specific details*,  the story centres on the witch trails of salem, which becomes pretty obvious about halfway through when a flashback to one of the murders is shown. After that, it's pretty clear that the overarching motive is to do with killing witches. This wouldn't be nearly as obvious to the player if the game was set somewhere OTHER THAN SALEM, which is famous for KILLING WITCHES. As soon as strange symbols and similar things get mentioned, the connection is almost instinctive .The only real twists and turns occur right at the end and even then don't do much to flip the story on it's head, they just make the overall story a little more original. Around halfway through the story, a lot of people will figure out the second half of the plot pretty quickly and then will just have to play through the game and wait for confirmation of what is sadly quite obvious.All that aside, the biggest detractor from the game is the BLOODY DEMONS. A few sections of the game require you to get your stealth hat on and exorcise demons from behind by distracting them, triggering a quicktime event, and hoping that the stars and planets are correctly aligned when you press the buttons, because the system is buggy as hell. For starters, this style of gameplay is totally unecessary and poorly implemented. There's absolutely no flow to it and it just seems like something the developers put in to make the game last a little longer and make it more exciting/different (which it does the exact opposite of). For a dectective game, it really kills the immersion and slows the pace right down. It's incredibly frustrating when all you want to do is get on with the investigation.Basically, if you're drawn to this game and like detective games, go ahead and play it. It's pretty fun and pretty clever at times. Just don't expect to be blown away by the story, although it has some pretty good moments. And definately expect to get extremely fed up with BLOODY DEMONS.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17
												A well done murder / detective game, Murdered: Soul Suspect was an enjoyable game overall and is worth getting (on a sale) if you’re into this genre. The plot is straightforward. You play as Ronan, a criminal turned detective who is shot and killed by a mysterious man. Your quest is to figure out the truth behind your murder and why it happened. Gameplay is mostly good. First off, you play as the ghost of yourself. Therefore, you can walk through most walls and objects which is fun to do. This is carried through the story where characters that are alive cannot see or hear you. You won’t be shooting anyone or have any big action moments. This is story driven first with some puzzles, clue finding scenes and a few small “stealth” parts thrown in. The puzzles incorporate clues you just found or found in the past. You use them to answer questions the game asks you. “What would help Mary remember?” or “What is Joy doing?” for example. The answers are sometimes illogical but you can just guess again.Clue finding scenes are exactly what it sounds like. Find all the clues in a particular area in order to figure out what went on.Stealth sections are the weak point of the game. Luckily, there’s not many of them and it’s not too hard. There are demons that can float around certain areas or inside buildings. To kill them, you need to go up behind them and execute them with a quick time event. However, the controls for this were not predictable and I died several times because the controls wouldn’t respond how I anticipated. The environment, graphics and sound are all very good. There’s definitely a creepy atmosphere that surrounds the entire city. Although, I found that a lot of the characters looked the same and would mistake certain characters for others. I thought the voice acting was fantastic. A definite strong point here.Run the game in 60FPS+Turn off VSYNC in the game options+Enable/force VSYNC in the Nvidia Control Panel Note:Cinematics will still be 30FPS as they are pre-renderedOne of the biggest complaints I have with the game is the lack of a map. It became frustrating to try and navigate around Salem and forget how to get to certain areas you want to re-visit. The game gives you a navigation marker for your current objective, but that’s it. Throughout my playthrough I was never really familiar with the city. For a game with lots of collectibles, it would have been a great addition. I initially tried playing with a keyboard and mouse. It seemed to work fine but when entering the in-game diary, it wouldn’t register me trying to move around. I eventually just used an Xbox 360 controller and everything worked perfect.Pros+60FPS (see note above)+Good story+Great voice acting+Well done animations+Creepy environmentCons+No map+Stealth combat sections+No save feature, only checkpoints+Puzzles are too easy+Steam overlay doesn’t work+Keyboard/mouse controls brokenEven with a few faults, I thought Soul Suspect was a good game and enjoyed playing it. It’s a little short, with maybe 8-10 hours to complete. Even less if you don’t collect the various collectibles. So at the current price of $30, it’s a little steep. Grab this on sale.7/10 Good

												Murdered: Soul Suspect, is very underated as a game. I put off playing this game for quite some time due to the negative publicity. My loss, because this is well above average in many regards.The negatives are its total lack of replayability and pointless combat system. But forget about all that and don't even bother with the collectibles, the majotity of them are pointless and offer nothing in relation to world or charcter building. The npcs found everywhere are likewise pointless, dont waste your time with them.However the reason I love this game is the story, the main story is gripping and the main characters are likewise compelling. This is not an fps or an rpg, its a very good interactive story. If like me you appreciate a well told story in a great setting and don't mind it being linear with no sidequests and the rest of the fluff then this is a winner. If you spacebar through conversations and skip cutscenes then avoid this like the plague.Love Arch

content:
Posted: March 18
												Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed this game. I thought it was fun and the story was compelling enough to make me want to finish it. Speaking of the story, however, this main character is easily the dumbest person I have ever encountered in my life, let alone the fact that he's a detective. Ronan didn't die because he was hunting down a murderer, he died because the writers couldn't come up with a good enough excuse for supposedly-respectable police officers to allow this kind of stupidity to act freely in their police department. So they killed him off so that no cops would have to actually deal with how utterly moronic he is. I figured out the story about two and a half hours into the game, and i played a good 5 or 6 hours total to beat it. All along the way, Ronan kept going "Huh, I wonder what this means" when the meaning is so blatantly obvious that a 7-year-old could figure it out, given that this 7-year-old had the utmost basic knowledge on the historical significance of Salem. There was genuinely only one part of this story that surprised me, and even then, it wasn't that impactful because of how upset I was at Ronan for his 6  straight hours of nonstop idiocracy. What really emphasized his stupidity, and I personally find this thoroughly ironic, was when he finally ended up talking with Baxter. Ronan spent the entirety of the game talking about how stupid Baxter is, and when it came down to them actually working together, Ronan had gotten to literally the EXACT same place as Baxter in their search for the killer. Also, overall, Ronan's facial expressions were a huge disconnect. You could tell it was supposed to be a dramatic moment, and Ronan still looked like the infant that I think he really is. Except if that infant were 5'10", had a stubble, and wore a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fedora. Mechanics-wise, it was lacking, but not in such a way that made it hard. Just somewhat tedious. At one point where Ronan should be hauling♥♥♥♥♥across all of Salem, he's instead jogging briskly, taking detours because of how confusing the map is. The teleport mechanic comes in handy, I guess, but honestly it would be so much better if it were just a set distance that you could sorta spam to move faster, instead of having to hold left click, wait for it to charge, and let go, only to travel a repeatedly disappointing distance. Trying to get from the musem to the church was honestly one of the worst sequences for this. I wanted to care about trying to get to the church as fast as I possibly could, but all Ronan could care about was the brunch he was gonna go have with his dead wife after this was all over, resulting in me wanting to start running down my street so that one of us could feel like they were attempting to go quickly towards anything.tl;drstory was predictable, Ronan is a moron, and the controls are meh. 14/10 would Julia again.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												Heading into this game, I knew bare minimum about it other than seeing a trailer or two. And that was the best way to get into the game.From start to finish I thoroughly enjoyed the game. It felt like I was playing a ghost version of the game L.A. Noire, but mainly just the clue aspect. I am from MA, so getting into the game and finding out it's about Salem, made the game that more interesting for me personally. Anything that involves somewhere familiar tends to do that. The story for this game was far more compelling and addictive than I had thought it'd be. It was a game I wanted to play, but unsure of how much I'd actually like it. With that in mind, I bought the game as part of a Humble Bundle, only a few days ago prior to writing this. Within a few days I've shelled out about 10 hours I believe and finished the game. I have been immensely addicted to the game, playing it as much as I could. Each chapter had a similar order of how things went, which normally would be annoying. But surprisingly it wasn't that bad. At the end of a chapter you would always end up going back the way you came, which gave you an added chance to find the extra little clues and such the game has. Along with bringing you some combat with the demons. Having to do that bit was always my least favorite but other than fighting the demons, there would have really been no other combat.So don't go into the game thinking it's going to be some gun swinging combat. It has it's own charm for it's combat.Because the game chose to be all about clues, it really has you immersed into the world of the game. Trying to find every clue you can and figure the plot out before Ronan does. It is a wonderful story and immersive game. Liked it so much I might just go back and replay it to try and find every bit of clue I can to get a whole story I probably missed.

												Sadly, even after a pretty decent discounted price, I can not bring myself to recommend this game. It has great production values but fails to land its ending. Murdered: Soul Suspect offers a look into the possible future of adventure mystery games but presents repetitive gameplay and cookie cutter characters. If the developers could have just dove a little deeper below the surface of each, thought through their killer's motives, and removed unnecessary mechanics (stealth segments with demons), the game could have been a solid new game. Get this as cheap as you can. Some aspects are neat but really not worth half its release pricetag.EDIT: An unnecessary apostrophe.

												Pretty decent game (65/100), but the gameplay gets repetitive very fast.+ Good story+ Solving the cases with gold badge can be challenging (but there is no point to it)+ Scenematics are good and try to draw you into the story+ Not a bad buy if it's heavily discounted- Gameplay is always the same (go to point, find all clues, click the right pieces, conclude the case)- I think they only made 4 npc's or something and together they have about 5 lines of speech through the entire game- Replay value = 0- The AI of the 'evil' ghosts is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and they are very easy to beat- The game itself isn't very long but they tried to extend the game lifetime by adding way to many collectiblesAll in all a decent game experience but I feel they could've been more creative with the puzzles.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Just finished Murdered: Soul Suspect. Most people who I talked to about the game heard it was♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can understand why. The game had a couple CTD bugs, was laggy if you used the anti aliasing at all, and generally felt like a very poorly done port. The combat was a stealth based sneak up and kill a demon that otherwise can just kill you, and at first it helped to break up the story nicely; unfortunately later on when the story was going on, it became tedious as the story was captivating. Outside of combat the gameplay mechanics were pretty much what I expected, collecting info through examination to solve your own murder, one step at a time.All in all, the story was excellent, the combat was poor, there are a few bugs and it was short. Square Enix would have been better off turning this game into a movie, but I still enjoyed it despite the problems. I would not recommend getting the game at full price, but on sale I would.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
This would make for an interesting film or Graphic NovelIt does not stand up particularly well as a computer game. I think the wrong medium has been used to tell this story; or at least the 'game' is at several levels below what the story should merit. Terrible and unintuitive combat system, which adds nothing to the game and serves to irritate. Zero penalty for identifying incorrect motive or misaligning clues; basically you can just 'click' your way through by trying multiple combo's, which detracts from what could have been an engaging "detecting" experience.Hundreds of collectibles hidden in obsure places. You'll need to collect them all if you want to experience the full back story. I couldn't be bothered investing several hrs of mundane searching for a 20 sec cutscene, which is a shame. No map. What sort of 3rd person game doesn't have a mini-map.Get it cheap and ignore ALL the filler content. Blast through the main story in six hrs and enjoy it for what it is. Good narrative. That way you get to avoid most of the tedium and enjoy this as an interactive B movie.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Overall a good game. I feel the story was concrete and actually pretty enjoyable, and the gameplay kinda blends a mix of detective activity and stealth. The ghost stories that you can unlock through the game by discovering their respective artifacts are also pretty good for adding some more flavour to the history of Salem, although it can be sometimes frustrating looking through every nook and cranny to find a hiding artifact. But hey, if you enjoy that sort of stuff, there's loads of it in this game. One slightly disappointing factor of the game is that there isn't really an option you can use to manually save the game; it works by checkpoints. So if you end your game in between checkpoints, you'll be forced to start again from the last autosave. However, the game seems to preserve anything you unlock or discover, regardless of the inconvenient autosaves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												 Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game I hadn't heard anything good about. Even prior to release, all the buzz was fairly negative. I can sort of see why. Soul Suspect is a strange cousin to a few genres. Its engine feels like it should be third person action adventure, but there is little action. The action (when it occurs) relies on limited stealth and is a bit rubbish. It operates mostly like a point and click, but investigative sections are few and far between. The main crux of the game is the deductive reasoning which is frankly utter tripe.Now none of this looks very good for Soul Suspect... You know what let's get this out of the way - the title is dreadful. Soul Suspect is a play on words that doesn't really make sense, except that you are a soul, having been murdered in the opening minutes of the game (spoiler!). But that's it. It would have been acceptable, but the "Murdered" title makes it unwieldy. Are we to expect a spate of games in the "Murdered" series? I would suggest "Murdered: Going Ghostal" about a murdered postman. I digress.On the surface, Soul Suspect is very much on the ropes here, so let's take it back to the beginning, where the game actually makes a very good first impression. Essentially, you play a policeman who is killed by a serial killer while investigating said serial killer and has to solve his own murder before he can move on to heaven. A neat, fun premise that isn't too demanding and immediately has you suspending your disbelief. What I found exceptional was the telling of your character's history in a well done cutscene showing his tattoos and reasons for getting each one. It really adds some layers to your character and I have to say that I liked the guy. There, I said it. He isn't too much of a wisecracking smartarse, he isn't all whiny and angsty about dying, and his voice actor does a cracking job. Great. I'd go as far as to say that all the characters are well written. You eventually befriend a teenage girl and even SHE is well portrayed, with the right amount of attitude to stay interesting without getting annoying.Now, sadly it starts to go downhill. Not quickly or dramatically, mind you - you just start to feel that many elements could have be far better implemented. The meat of the game is made up of investigating crime scenes, very similar to L.A. Noire, but without the depth. It can feel a little bit clumsy walking around the crime scene waiting for the "investigate" prompt to come up. It tells you how many clues you need to find, but finding some is needlessly difficult, requiring some odd maneuvering into the exact position. Using the clues themselves is even more frustrating.An example from early in the game is when you have to investigate a young woman who tells you she was murdered by an old couple and needs to know where her body is so she can move on. After investigating the old couple's apartment, you are given the question "What happened to the young woman's body?" and you have 6 clues to work with. Intuitively, you might select the ones that give physical evidence or point to what happened to her body, but you'd be wrong. The clues you have to select are actually 1) the girl is dead; 2) this person murdered her; 3) yes, this person definitely murdered her. It doesn't make any sense, because the clues you have to use don't really point to the question asked. This is a recurring problem throughout the game, but swings wildly between obtuse clues and such stark simplicity that you are constantly thrown. For example, later you are asked "What made that cracking noise?", a rope, branch or something cracking into a tree. Here it seems like the answer with "crack" in it is too obvious, but that is the actual answer!This all leads to a rather odd issue with the game in that there doesn't really seem to be a way to fail the investigations, you can just keep trying combinations of clues until you get it right. You get 3 shields next to a clue if you get it perfectly, dropping down to one as you fail. I don't really know how I feel about this. I like that it keeps the story moving, but it also makes the game feel trivial.What can slow the pace of the game are the fairly boring stealth sections. There are two types - one where you simply have to distract a living person with a possessed electrical appliance in order to let your companion slip past (I never failed any of these sections), and the second is when demons decide to show up. These sections are incredible dull and annoying simultaneously. You need to either slip by the demons' very short, predictable patrol paths or get behind them and kill them with mercifully simple QTE. There is some nonsense about using ghost crows to distract them and hiding in ghost residues if they spot you, but it all seems hastily cobbled together.When you're not taking part in the main parts of the game, you'll be collecting collectibles. Lots and lots of collectibles. There are journals, memories, ghost stories and ghost graffiti to collect and are also the subject of ambivalence. They are very easy to find which is sort of good as they add to the story, but are so easy to find that they seem a bit pointless. The only hard ones to find are the graffiti collectibles, but that's because they're invisible and there's the problem of you being in the right position to tell you that you can interact with them.So all in all, boring, pointless and needlessly obtuse. What a terrible game! Well, no, actually. It all sort of comes together. It gels very well. It initially feels weird moving around the levels and into crime scenes because you might feel like you should be sneaking, but you are completely invisible, so you walk around completely unimpeded. You can walk through walls, possess people to see what they're thinking and (in a great highlight) even possess a cat and run around meowing. The execution of the game might be lacking, but the intention is so clear that I found myself forgiving it most of its flaws.The story is a high point as well, I have to admit that it drew me in very and had me second guessing myself a few times. There are lots of clues around as to what is happening and if (like me) you pick up on them, you will find yourself slightly thrown as you try to piece it all together and re-evaluate your theories. I even found myself pleasantly surprised by the denouement - it wasn't overlong, over complex or a ridiculous boss fight. I was very impressed by the writing and performances in the game, they turned a mediocre game into a good one.I did get the game very cheap, I have to say, so I don't know how forgiving I would have been at £39.99. I paid around £4.50 for it and feel that that is very cheap, but I would have been happy to pay up to £11.99 for it, and that is praise indeed!

Posted: January 4, 2015
												A hugely underrated game in some circles, wherein I fear that some feel it does not stand up to the graphical quality of the PS3/PS4 games we have today. You have a choice: a stunning story, or pure eye candy. This game stands tall on the story aspect, featuring one of the best introductions I have ever seen in a video game. The setting is a powerful one indeed. All characters are relevant, and it is amazing to see a setting unfold and exposition be provided by so many supporting characters.There are the occasional obstacles requiring strategy guides (a solution to a problem would've been to have interactive objects glow orange or something like that) that can impede gameplay, but it isn't really a problem in the long run. Heck, you can possess (play as) a cat. That also makes the game an instant win in my book :D

Posted: May 22, 2015
												This "game" is one of the worst I've ever "played".  Even if free, it's not worth the time you'd spend.  Certain elements of the game make it clear that the game was rushed to publication, like the "mysteries" that you solve for random ghosts, which appear only in the first two areas and give you no reward whatsoever.  The game mechanics are shady and boring, like when you have to put together three clues and they tell you to put them in chronological order even though the clues have nothing to do with time.  Most of the time I could figure out what they wanted but by and large it was guesswork.  The game itself is only 3 or 4 hours of real gameplay with a great deal of padding in the form of hidden collectables, most of which also do not give you any reward except for the "scary stories" which feature excruciating voice acting and are a giant waste of time.I wish I had the kind of guts Square Enix has to publish this piece of garbage and demand 50 bucks for it.  Do not buy it, do not play it, and remember this the next time you want a Square Enix game.

Posted: April 26, 2015
												A story driven game which reminded me of an old point and click adventure but with a modern style utilizing third person action.  The action in the game itself is limited to some QTEs and some stealth gameplay against some malignant spirits, the majority of the gameplay is on investigating and puzzle solving.  There are plenty of collectables with voiceover story extras which make exploring worthwhile as well.  The story is a bit short yet very engaging that follows a likeable main character.  It does have it's share of cliches but the main characters are realistic and relatable while the side storylines have a bit more into the "what is wrong with these people" traits.Overall the complete package is easy for me to recommend for people who enjoy games with a focus on story over purely gameplay itself.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I'm not really sure why I liked Murdered: Soul Suspect, maybe it was because the investigation parts are just the right amount of challenging without relying on your ability to lip read the faces of the uncanny valley... I'm trying to avoid looking at you L.A Noire... Or perhaps it was the side quests, engaging side quests, where I actually felt like I was doing some good, that I was changing the game world for the better. Whatever it was I did enjoy Murdered: Shoal Suspect. I enjoyed it a lot and (silly name aside) I found myself gripped in a supernatural thriller, which had some level of adventure gameness to it, the controls were solid, the graphics reasonable, and the story (while a little predictable in places) did keep me glued to the screen wanting to find out what happened next, the ability to contribute to that story through the aforementioned side quests, and investigation moments probably helped keep me in during the boring bits.I did find the combat a little clunky, but the moments are so few and far between that it never became more than a minor annoyance, and immersion was spoiled somewhat by the sheer denseness of the player character, watching him piece together the motives of the antagonist was less Sherlock Holmes, and more Scooby-Doo.However maybe you really get off on being smarter than the character... Maybe that is the real reason I like Murdered: Soul Singer. Whatever your motivation for thinking about getting this game, I advise you to.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Just finished this game and I must say it worth its money. My rating: 9,5/10First of all, the Level Design is well layed out with a prety huge map to explore, not to mention that this game is based on exploration. There are many different paths you can take to reach a certain area, the indoor level design is gorgeous, many effects such as lens flares, particles/smoke, cool looking spectral city placed across the map with props all over it and the contrast between colors is tremendous. The more you explore, the more real information about the 1660 time you'll find and secondary cases you need to solve in order to obtain achivements and some creepy stories that are fun to hear or read. Secondly, speaking of textures now, the developers used a really wide range of textures, and the result? The boredom of seeing the same thing over and over again is excluded. Not only did they succeed in creating a sinister environment, but with the accompany of a Various library of sounds , they created a replica of a horror movie inwhich you choose the protagonist's moves. Thirdly, the animations, I must admit, could have been done a lot better. Such automatic, much less cool.Another aspect of the game I want to talk about is the combat system and the enemies. Besides the Killer Bell (the main enemy), are the demons. Yes, it appears that ghosts can be swallowed in by them...who would have thought? To kill one you need to follow this simple step: Go behind it and press the buttons that appears on your screen. Voila you just killed a badass looking demon. There are some demon's spawns on the floor which will make you cast a certain combination of keys the moment you step on it. If you fail, some demonic hands will drag you down (in hell maybe).Encountering a demon will only happen in a specific area full of teleportals. Although I used the Teleportals to travell across the map faster I also used them to hide from demons. They can't sense you in a teleportal.Possesing is a protagonist's ability to read people minds but you can't move with their bodies. Moreover, you can even posses a cat.Nevertheless the story is by far one of my favourites. I bought this game mainly for its level design and for the Dark, sinister and twisted story which caught my attention. You need to take decisions based on what you know so far, based on the recent findings and your logical interpretation.  I won't spoil the story don't worry, you really need to figure it out  yourself. The main character has a easily recognisable visual design and you must admit he's a badass looking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from the game's poster.All summed up, due to its story, level design including the textures,lighting,particles and lens flares, with a cold heart character I highly recommend this game.

												Sadly, even after a pretty decent discounted price, I can not bring myself to recommend this game. It has great production values but fails to land its ending. Murdered: Soul Suspect offers a look into the possible future of adventure mystery games but presents repetitive gameplay and cookie cutter characters. If the developers could have just dove a little deeper below the surface of each, thought through their killer's motives, and removed unnecessary mechanics (stealth segments with demons), the game could have been a solid new game. Get this as cheap as you can. Some aspects are neat but really not worth half its release pricetag.EDIT: An unnecessary apostrophe.
