content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												You see I recommend it, but only to certain people.I will first of all admit that this game gameplay wise is absolutely dreadful to play. All of it is either you walking around a crime scene trying to find some obscure clue that isn't showing up when pass it or killing demons by mashing WASD or the mouse buttons at once. I found myself struggling to play the game simply for the repetitive and boring gameplay.But what is good is the immersion and story. That is what kept me going through this. If you treat this game as a game and not a story, it kinda falls flat on it's face in every way. But if you look at it for it's story and where it guides, it is pretty damn good. The ending was also great, something you have to experience yourself when connecting the dots. About half way through the game though the story starts to drag but at the end it picks back up in an extremely memorable way.So in terms of the actual game I would recommend purchase if you are into game stories and not gameplay. Something like the Walking Dead but not near as awesome.Performance wise the game is solid on playability most of the time. Most of the games that are helped made by AMD usually have decent ports with minimal problems, two good examples being Sleeping Dogs and Hitman: Absolution. There are problems though. This game in the options tends to not give you details, for instance the in the settings for anti-aliasing the options for FXAA are thing like FXAA(High) and FXAA(Medium), doesn't really give me an idea of what I am working with. The other issue is also with the mouse sensitivity settings, there are 3 options. There is no slider it is literally three options. I had to adjust my mouse DPI to make this game playable. But on high settings for everything at 1080p I would usually experience 120 fps + nicely. Although depending on the lighting my game has dropped to 30 for no reason (namely the church entrance).As a note I am playing with:2nd Gen AMD A10-5700 Accelerated APU (integrated graphics disabled)EVGA GTX 750 1GB DDR3 FTW ACX Cooling8 GB RAM

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is hard to place into a genre, but the closest thing I'd compare it to is an engaging movie. There is a -lot- a person could dislike about this game, but somehow, the rich environment, colorful lore, and memorable mechanics salvage the gameplay and emphasize the decent story.Without giving too much away, M:SS has you playing a detective in Salem (yes, that Salem), who ends up -- you guessed it -- getting murdered at the very start of the game. You spend your time throughout the game walking through walls, solving murders and helping other spirits find piece, all while trying to figure out your own killer's identity and motives.Now while all that seems like a kickass idea, playing it out can be a little... boring. For one, there's not really much 'combat' in this game, and what little fighting there is, it's basically a game of hide and seek. You spend most of your time hunting for spots to press 'X', whether it be for the 200 or so collectables, clues to your case, or looking for objects to poltergeist. Your powers as a ghost are almost disappointingly limited, despite how cool it was the first dozen or so times you walk through a wall or teleport. The game itself isn't even that long --I 100%'d it within two days.So why recommend this game? Part of it is the story, and the lore that's painted around it. The game isn't what I'd call 'new age horror'. There aren't jump-scares, there are creepy things and eerie stories. You're rewarded for exploration with collectables, which give bits and pieces of the story around you, and those involved. The graphics and sound do a satisfactory job tying everything together, but they didn't stick out nearly as stylistically as games like Alan Wake.All in all, if you're expecting an action or horror game, this isn't for you. If you want an interesting story and you're curious about playing a game as a ghost, I'd give it a shot, maybe around the $10 range. Since I fall into both the latter category, M:SS gets a thumbs up.

Most of these games are sold as role playing games, and it’s the genre where Square-Enix has really dominated over the past twenty-five years. It came as a bit of a surprise then, when I saw a paranormal detective game being released by the RPG titans in the form of Murdered: Soul Suspect.See more at VG Almanac[vgalmanac.com]

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												What a great game, a real surprise for me and a must play game for any adventure gamer or Mystery Thriller gamer, 9/10!The graphics is really nice, it contains both "open world " areas where you can hunt down collectibles and explore the city, and then special smaller subareas within, where you complete the story related quests, find side quests...This game is actually quite creepy, and contains some dark moments... e.g. when you talk to a ghost who turns out to be a stalker of a living woman, enjoying the fact that he can stalk her now for all eternity... also, during the story you witness some gruesome murders, so actually quite an adult game.White interesting riddle mnechanics... you need to find clues, and then select from those the important clues to advance the story. I really liked the main characters, and the story and your ghost abilities are quite cool. Dont get discouraged by those bad reviews bashing the demon scenes... there are only a dozen or so in the whole game, and I died only once in total, so they are easy to kill or avoid, and fit well to the story and increase the feeling of danger and doom.Almost a game of the year contender, I wish for another similar game! Highly recommended!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												The biggest single merit of Murdered is likely that the conclusions it frequently prompts the player to draw are actually quite sensible, which alone unfortunately puts the game head and shoulders above most detective games. The game rarely feels like a pixel hunt, and the protagonist's psychometric ability provides means of intuitively verifying the conclusions, instead of them simply remaining educated guesses, as is often the case in detective stories, both those found in games and other media.If there's one gripe I have, it's the fairly obscene amount of collectibles, which have been scattared across the game world for no reason given. Some of these relate rather closely to the story, but are hidden well enough to cause furstration for anyone who wishes to experience the story in full. Others seem to have little to with anything at all, and appear to only be in the game to add to its otherwise quite short length -- despite what some reviewers have states, the game world is definitely not "vast", and even a casual completionist like myself who checks every nook and cranny and walks everywhere finished it in under 10 hours. The story is focused enough to by no means feel rushed, however, and while the dialogue is nothing much to write home about, the character arcs all draw to a satisfactory close and the story in general holds together very well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												This excellent AAA adventure game (never thought I'd use that term - nothing against the predominant mostly excellent indie Adventure games mind you) has had an unjustly tough time with professional reviewers. It has interesting characters in an unusual setting - exploring Salem's witch hunt history as well as the ghost world while finding out about your own death and how it connects to the latter two. The investigation mechanics are quite good and borrow elements from Miles Edgeworth (a Phoenix Wright spin-off) involving finding clues at the crime scene through influencing the living, examining evidence and even talking to some ghosts who saw it happen and logically connecting them to come to a conclusion regarding the events having unfolded there and where to find the next lead. The main character has entertaining ghost powers such as (obviously) going through walls, restoring remnants of past sections of a building and reading and influencing the mind of the living. The game has investigation side quests along the way and many collectibles fleshing out its world. The graphics are great although they suffer from repeated NPC syndrome in the hub world connecting each level. The story is entertaining with an actual ending (no cliffhanger) although it does have some hammy writing occasionally.The game does have some flaws though: the combat involves at times infuriating QTEs but these scenes are thankfully very rare and combat is mostly optional as the game is meant to be a stealth game in the rare "combat" segments. The length  is a bit on the short side but as you can see from my play time if you like finding collectibles and finishing side quests (actual side quests involving their own small mystery in each area of the game, not Assassin's Creed-style futile repetition) you'll have a fairly reasonable game length, especially considering the game has no filler content whatsoever to pad it out needlessly. It could also use some more variety in what happens in between the game's various crime scenes such as more interaction with the world at large but it remains nonetheless well paced.Give this game a fair shake and you will be pleasantly entertained. The studio that made this game sadly closed 2 months after it released, I for one was looking forward to what else they could make in this world.

												You are a recently deceased detective, who has to solve his own murder.I would say this game is a graphical adventure with exploration and lots of collectibles, and a few (very light) stealth combat parts.It has a great ambience, cool characters and a good story, which surprised me at the end.It doesn't have many side quests, and the rewards for completing them aren't precisely rewarding.It's a short story, which I completed in 7 hours, but i skipped most of the collectibles and side quests. It doesn't have difficulty leveles or replay value.I would surely recommend it, but only if it is on sale.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												This is more like a thriller-horror novel for those who are too lazy to pick up a book than a game. So if you aren't interested in stuff like that i dont recommend buying this game. Overall the game is great! It actually requires lots of reading (wall of texts ahead!) to fully understand the plot (and trust me, it worth it). The side ghost stories in the game are spooky as well.The story is good. Basically you're on a case to find out about a serial killer called ''The Bell Killer''. While persueing the suspect alone, you got killed and kinda stucked in between the two worlds. You need to find out about the truth in order to ''move on''. Gameplay was simple, feels a bit repetitive; great atmosphere overall, can be a little spooky due to random ghosts. I got this game on sale so i wont be complaining. Definitely worth a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												The game at full price is a bit to expensive for the content that you get to my taste. On sale it is worth a look as it does give a rich story.The game plays very well and it gives a real immersive feeling to the story. This is something not a lot of games are able to do well in my opinion. Most games try to tell a story without making you part of the story. The story for me is the main selling point. The gameplay as such is interesting enough to keep you playing. The gameplay let's you investigate a scene looking for clues until you found all the clues. When you have all the clues you select the most important ones to conclude your investigation. What I found appealing is that the clues and getting to a conclusion do actually make sense. In some puzzle games you get to do a lot of trial and error for finding the correct answer.Although my feeling about the game is positive and I would recommend it if the regular price was right. For me 10EUR or less would be the right amount for this game looking at gametime and richness of content.
